reviews.text: Perfect looking station and most of the time working lift's. But sadly incompetent and useless member of staff
Awesome service
Amazing and inspiring new station
Very Good link from Erith to jump on the fast trains from Dartford to central London. The staff is friendly  and helpful. Can't wait for the Cross Rail to open!!!
Useless staff in there
Absolutely stunning place to go, desolate, completely dirty, seemingly abandoned. It really has that Welsh vibe to it. Extraordinary
Best place to wait for a train.
Most miserable woman alive works behind the ticket office.
Not a bad station needs abit of a tidy up maby a coat of paint or to. 👍
Ticket office is rarely open. Car park located opposite a busy main road.

Don't follow Google maps as took us in wrong direction. Can't find how to report that map is wrong.  Follow signs for park and ride and u will reach it. No toilets. Departure boards. Pay at machine. Large car park. Help point machine. Have to use underpass to reach. Wheelchair accessible. Bike rack.  All weather cover . Free parking. Nestled in the mountains with a noisy cockrel crowing nearby 😂

Part time ticket office. Car park but can o ly have a parking ticket if you purchase a train ticket. Steep slope up to station so difficult if you have a wheelchair I would think. Departure boards. No toilets. 1 platform. All weather cover. 2 metal poles for bikes.

First time I had been to this station Friendly helpful staff helped me to the car park with my bags and found out if my taxi had arrived .
Very impressed with service provided .
Trains all the way down to Barry island via Cardiff every half hour weekdays

It is what you would expect however,  as is typical with Arriva Trains Wales, the stations are poorly maintained and the trains are ancient. Furthermore, there are no public conveniences at the station, with customer having have to walk to Aberdare bus station.

The station is also beyond dirty and it is not uncommon to see used condoms and syringes there. Arriva need to get their act together. I am giving it two stars only because the trains are on time.
Not very impressive as a train station for a town like Aberdare, deserves a little more.

Aberdeen (The Granite City) in Scotland is a lovely place to visit. There are plenty of good hotels and B&Bs to choose from. He main shopping areas can be found in either Union or George Street where you will find a variety of shops. There are some beautiful parks as well the Duthie Park being my favourite to walk through but all the others are worth a visit. The architecture of some buildings are amazing such as the University structures and the town hall. Transport is good with the train station, the airport and of course the ferries from the harbour.

Arrived from a long journey from Munich Today at 6:00pm would like to take a taxi and 3 of them said they don’t accept card, only card if the trip is more than £7,50!! They didn’t take me because I “live to near and is not enough money” They are so rude! Best to book a rainbow taxi to pick you up at station hotel !!! Such a rude guys and such a bad services! AVOID THE TAXIS AT THE TRAIN STATION!!! Horrible service !!! It was the same for 2 more people!!!

Alan ( the taxi driver)  returned my iPhone XS Max to my address. Glad to know the railway station taxi drivers are trust worthy. 

Thank you

Rude staff and poor facilities. I don't need a lecture on why one train company needs to pull its weight and pay for station services from station employees when trying to use the services. Dark age customer services which will only ensure I will never visit or spend my money in this town again.

So I'm a rail enthusiast and i'm autistic so me and my friend went to Aberdeen from Glasgow we used the bus as its cheaper and we got to the station and told the people at the gates we would be taking pictures of trains and the staff at the gate were fine with it about half an hour later I went up to the staff to ask why the train was delayed on route there was a train with its door open (Yes we are still in the days where trains doors are manual and we have to lean out them to open the door) so I shut it and one of the staff was chill just asking if I could keep it open and I said sure then there was a member of platform staff who screamed in my face to get off "her" platform" and that I shouldn't touch "Her" Doors mind you this was an LNER train and she was scotrail staff she was till screaming in my face where I then asked for a supervisor who came down and did not deal with the member of staff at all he said we could stay and that was all I then told him Id like to place a formal complaint He then told me If I want to put a complaint in Id be asked to leave the station witch I have confirmed is not aloud.after this train left we decided to leave (I left with tears in my eyes and only one staff member asked if I was ok) I have been to Aberdeen station before and the staff were lovely clearly scotrail put the worst staff on a sunday.

Outstanding. One of the nicest stations you could ever want to use. Well preserved and maintained village station, which benefits from a frequent service given its size. A huge thumbs up to the volunteers which keep this station in the colour and splendour it is in. This station regularly won awards in its steam days for its keeping, and still does. Contrast that with the stations a few miles either side - the original but depressed glum of Burntisland, or the bland, sterile modern tarmac strip of Dalgety Bay, makes this station a pleasure to use. Limited hours ticket office and toilet facilities, large free car park, and plenty of shelter from adverse weather.

Came here for the day to have some relaxing peaceful time to myself it's the perfect place took my dog a walk round both beaches got some great pictures views simply stunning I was lucky it was a beautiful sunny day, I will definitely visit again.
Nice wee station
Beautiful beach.
Really enjoyed Aberdovey and if you drive a little way out toward Tywyn thee are miles of uncrowded sandy beaches.
Nice clean station but be warned NO TOILET but very nice
Cool
Es una pequeña estación donde comienza el parque nacional Esnoudonia no posee baños. Por lo que conviene ir a turidmo

On request halt near Pwllheli - small car park 200 metres from the beach - just being resurfaced. Short but steep climb up over the dunes onto the beach. Very quiet beach.Close to the caravan park. The circus use the nearby fields when they are in town

Staff are quite kind, have to ask for someone to open up the gate and let you cross the railway if you've got a buggy or wheelchair and need to get to the other platform, can be a bit annoying if you're in a big rush. Nice little cafe attached.
nice cafe
There is a wethwerapoons next door which is handy. The station ticks the boxes but every time I've been the toilets have been locked.

No number to call for information that actually works..... 15 mins hanging on the phone for customer services and complaints, ha ha... what a joke?!?!?   Total waste of time,  it was not even for me, my mother was told cannot buy tickets in advance?? Only when on the train.... another waste of time in so many ways!!   All train companies seem to be all about helping  themselves than others... would not want to be reliant on a train to get a round,  hence why there so many people driving and not using public transport...

terrible, my experience was horrific, there was crackheads wandering around one asked me for a quid so he could buy ket, i'm a 45 year old woman this cannot be happening in my christian suburbs. appalling area will not be visiting again. may the lord be with you all. peace out homeslice

This is a request stop on the Kyle Line. I visited in November it was a mild day. This is a remote station you will either have to have someone waiting for you or if you have bicycle the roads are very good for cyclists. There is shelter for a wet day, the train timetable is on display and there is also an information call point. The platform itself is well maintained and the trees provide a bit of shelter on a windy day.

Just amazing to visit Achnasheen Railway Station on Boxing Day, 2017. As you can see there had been a good fall of snow. It was all so quiet and peaceful. The station is beautifully looked after and the toilets are so clean. I visited again in March, 2018 and this time the train was waiting which was nice to see.
Beautiful point
A  place  that  loves  the  camera
zum Zeitpunkt meines Besuches ein gepflegter Bahnhof mitten in der " Einsamkeit"

Quaint rural station in the middle of nowhere. It is a request stop, so you should hold out your hand if you want to get on the train. This station is reached by a rough track, more than 5 minutes walk from the road, which is itself miles from anywhere. I can't say the station has many amenities, but it has lots of happy memories of childhood holidays and walks.
No toilet facilities

Not the best in suburban train stations. Very basic dreary looking. Nothing to do here. Trains frequently late. Convenient location makes this station instantly accessible for a lot of commuters.  Staff can be a little challenging at times but on the whole harmless.
Nothing to complain about here. Clean and efficient enough.
Gr8 station 7 mins to solihull regular trains.
Nothing wrong with this station six minutes into Birmingham City
ACTON BRIDGE STATION IS THE BEST TRAIN STATION 🚉   IN  THE WORLD 🌎    TRAINS ARE LONDON MIDLAND  😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍😍🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚆🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉 🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉🚉
Great place to visit and trainspot

Absolutely fantastic train station for trainspotting with a variety of freight and passenger. Unfortunately for the average passenger, not great facilities and only about 3 trains a day stopping there. Luckily, it does have a shelter and a bench, although that doesn't compensate for the lack of toilets and ticket offices. Although there is a pub / restaurant just above the station, it's rude to use their facilities without buying something but we shouldn't have to use the pubs' facilities. I'm writing 5 stars from a spotters perspective, brilliant for trainspotting, not so good for the average passenger. Would be nice if they added some facilities.
Great for train spotting
each time I have used this station  . the Train has always  been on time .

Easy  ground level access points via ramps and slopes to the ticket office and platform areas. Clear signage. Interesting raised flower beds being added to the sidings and theres a very nice view of Acton park from the train.

Very polite staff who are able to help and assist passengers here at the station. There's a nice selection of flowers on display and it looks like the station has been kept in a good condition. The subway that connects the two platforms isn't wheelchair accessible however both t entrances are more than accessible so it makes up.
Nice little station, It needs some work done. I had a job there.

(Friday 05/01/2018 8.40 pm) Me and my wife are both wheelchair-users and we need a ramp to board overground train. A station worker was not quite happy to go for an accessible ramp, take it and slide it. We were interrogated by this worker, where we have been, what for... But finally he put the ramp. I was a little shocked because I have never met with such behaviour in the Overground. Maybe he never slide the ramp before and therefore his was reluctant to do it.
Lovely station, reminiscent of the railway children!  Well maintained flower pots in abundance, spotlessly clean and staff very visible.  Feels very safe and efficient.   A pleasure to wait here.
Very good location to go to Heathrow Airport for Acton Residents

It's OK, of course it can become more better,Acton Main Line is a National Rail station on the Great Western Main Line in Acton, west London. It is 4 miles 21 chains (6.9 km) down the line from London Paddington and the majority of trains are operated by TfL Rail.

Mis-sold a £53 single ticket for £82.50. Check the cost of tickets yourself before buying a ticket here. Ticket staff do not understand their systems and will well you a more expensive ticket or not sell you a ticket at all. Terrible . Uneven platform surface, very cold platform waiting room with no doors just wide open, , no ticket barriers or ticket checks.The new Elizabeth line (formerly Crossrail) will stop at this station , when they finish it, way behind schedule.

I had to use this train station as an emergency into the city centre with my 3 year old and 6 month old (in a pushchair). The ticket office was closed, which wasn't as issue as they issue Permits to travel. I was surprised to see that there are no ramps, lifts etc only stairs!! If you're in a wheelchair, struggle with stairs or have young children in a pushchair - this train station is a no go. Train into Birmingham City Centre was fast, but wasn't impressed with this station at all.

It's not the best but gets you to town quick trains hourly around 28 past to new street and around 48 past to Birmingham airport. The ticket place is mostly closed and the ticket machine doesn't take cash and sometimes isn't working.
Please take pride in your local park and use the bins please

What a pathetic station this is. The shelter was leaking in the rain, no step free access whatsoever, minimal seating, one train an hour and a ticket machine which doesn't accept cash. If you want step free access, use Duddeston, which also has a more frequent service.
My daily train is mostly on time. Very rarely late or cancelled, would otherwise get five stars.
Love train stations
Why are you reading reviews of railway stations?
Try not to
Violent abusive traveller. I didn't feel safe here

Never staffed at the times when you need someone, the ticket machines are offline more than online, there is no seating along the platform so everyone has to cram into the minimal seating at the entrance, the trains are never on time, the only good thing was there is/was a Addlestone to Woking service at weekends, but not at the weekdays where it would be useful! Would also be nice if the place was painted properly and had a real waiting area with some heat.
A traditional railway station on the Chertsey branch. Steam trains pass through fairly regularly.

Ticket machine has the worst UI I've ever experienced. Seriously, how did that get through testing?! 😂👴

**EDIT** - seems they've made it much better now!
Great station

This railway station sits on the railway line heading towards Manchester in one direction and Macclesfield in the other.

This railway station does have a small car park but it is only made up of gravel and some grass which gets muddy at times.

There is no designated disabled parking bay.

There is no no designated area for dropping off passengers.

There is no bike rack at this station so don't bring your bicycle here.

There are no obvious signs whatsoever of any security in terms of closed-circuit television cameras.

There are no on-site staff here.

Tickets must either be bought before you board the train, or otherwise bought from the automatic ticketing machine that sits on the Manchester bound platform.

There are covered waiting areas on both platforms.

There is a digital display board to indicate when trains are likely to arrive, although on the occasion when I was there, it wasn't working, hopefully just a temporary fault 

There are yellow lines on both platforms, to tell passengers to keep away from the platform, because a lot of the trains passing through the station don't actually stop here.
Brillant love this place never disapointed .

Pleasant, clean station with a ticket office and a footbridge connecting the platforms.
No lifts although ramps are available. 

Direct services to Manchester, Doncaster, Leeds and Sheffield. 

Ticket office is only part-time although you can buy your ticket from a machine that is now installed. Parking is available.
It's a good station with a ticket / information office and two bridges.

There is a ticket office here. There are two ways to change platform, over the footbridge or via the road bridge. Adwick could be a junction station in a few years if the line direct to Hatfield starts being a passenger route. There is  wasteland nearby which could form a shop, a buffet bar with license and other utilities.
Followed by some chavs, no lifts but ticket office is good
Sound information
It's a nice and clean train station. There's an inside waiting area, a covered area and a toilet.
Surely,  I would say this is a great place. I was careful at the huge step onto the platform. Apart from that it's a great station even if it's not that busy as you may know as you go there
Staff have always been helpful to me - well done guys.
Wonderful kind guy in the ticket booth today sat 10 Feb 1pm printed out my train return times for me without me even asking.thankyou 👍

A pleasant little station, served by half hourly service on a Sunday and every 15 minutes Monday to Saturday to Southport and Hunts Cross, which is OK for a local rail service. Train station seemed well maintained and well presented. I did notice that the disabled toilet was out of order, although good to know they have one when it is working.
A really cool and beautiful station. Look at the flowers as they’re beautiful

The loss of original station buildings may be lamentable, but there is no doubting the stunning architecture of the new ticket office and waiting room on the northbound platform. Worth visiting just to have a look!

Regular trains run to Southport- every 15 minutes except Sunday which is every 30 minutes. The other way trains run to Liverpool regularly and take 36 minutes from Ainsdale to Liverpool Central. Construction is underway currently and they are rebuilding the station building but access to the trains is still open.
So good
Its a train station. Pretty much it.
Having a good time
It got me to where I was going
Looks good
Sleek
Too quiet.
This is the sort of station where no one will ever meet anyone for the first time. And if you do, there will never be any significance to the relationship. Trains don't even run on time.
Great station. Has bathrooms
NOT A STATION - false point on map IGNORE
I live here so yea
Comfortable, well-faclilitied commuter village, suburban rather than twee (though perhaps hovering near cusp)
This is a much improved station, see the photos for a contrast
Pleasant station, but footbridge can be a problem for less able, , also there is NO TOILETS ! Very short walk into lovely village.
What a station. A real countryside treat.
No facilities, no barriers and no ticket machines. Buy tickets on the train or (if you're lucky) alight before a collector has come and at a station without barriers/machines.
Little Country Station with 10 car parking places where you have to pay. Westbound platform being extended. Currently being electrified.

I find everytime the trains I catch are never on time always delayed always over packed with people your like a can of sardines in rush hour the guards are always rude and miserable when I ask them a question the trains are very messy all the time considering the prices I have to pay for tickets every time I plan a journey the trains always mess up or the trains arnt running the station could do with an update at least some paint very disappointing with aldershot train service!!!!
Nice to have a waiting room and toilets

Not perfect but there is a waiting room and easy pick area. There is also a nearby  carpark. One thing that I normally miss in many train stations in the UK is either an escalator or a lift. This has to stop! Enough with the cost saving drama. Do the needful! All stations need updates and should be well facilitated for users. After all they are paying!
Right next to the bus station and great disabled access to all of the platforms. Furthermore, there is a direct train to London Waterloo which comes every half an hour.

Was met with a very rude lady today at the kiosk who made me feel very uncomfortable and she seemed very agitated and inpatient with me. The toilets are always dirty, trains are mostly on time and a lift is available.
For a strip of concrete on the side of a railway line, it's not half bad. If you want a more frequent service, walk down the road to Hove (5-10) mins. Bit dirty but apart from that, no complaints  :)

This station is a disgrace.  The ticket machine rarely works, the permission to travel machine has never worked, the weather shelters are tiny and do not have proper seating and the frequency of trains is too low.  

Update: Southern now pay for two ticket inspectors every morning. The money would be better spent on a station upgrade.

Southern Rail have failed. Again.
Aldrington station is the next stop from Hove station on the Worthing to Brighton line.  A small station with limited facilities.
Very few trains... even those ment to stop don't bother. Best bet get to Hove or Portslade...

Could do with a clean every now and then.
Two stars because of the nice sounding reverb in the tunnel.

Good station to go into Central London trains every 15 minutes. But Going out side of London it's a different story. Overall it's a good station, also Wood green station is around the corner on the W3.

2x nice cafes in such a small station is an unusual bonus. Also great food pub across the road. Only complaint is when there are events held in the Alexandra Palace nearby, the exit can become super crowded
Great link to city centre
Usual train station. Has ticket office, ticket self service machine for card transactions only easily accessible 1 platform operating train services both ways to balloch and towards Glasgow
Hot and close to water and park to the loch
Shabby
Does alfreton train station have long stay car park, want to park for a weekend and how much please

Had problems with train line changing tickets and charging admin fee.spoke to 5 different people and nothing made any sense, went down to Alfreton station explained everything to Barbara and she sorted everything immediately.Brilliant!!!!Nice one Barbara.

Nothing here apart from the ticket office but it has great links to London, Notts, Manchester, Liverpool, Leeds, Sheffield, Peterborough, Norwich.
Not bad for a small station.
A clasp railway station. Steam trains pass through occasionally.
Loved the Train Station. Perfect view of the Trains
Barriers are always broke

Not unpleasant in warm weather, with half-hourly services to Saltburn and Darlington/Bishop Auckland, though Darlington trains only run through to Bishop Auckland once an hour. Covered but not fully enclosed waiting shelters on both platforms and a bike rack on the northern (eastbound) platform. Entry to platforms is adjacent to the level crossing at the eastern end of the station, which also allows for easy wheelchair access. A payphone can be found in the shelter on the northern platform and there's a bike rack on that side of the tracks too, but alas no car park in sight.
True to it's name, I saw Jimmy Saucer 👽
Nice little station.
Trains always on time
The trains always leave on the dot here. So make sure you are there in time
Scotland for work
Visiting tourists. Had to change time of departure. Staff very friendly and helpful.
Full marks for the staff who are so friendly and helpful
great village on coast good bars and food

At the time of writing, I consider the staff to provide excellent customer service. The facilities are average, although they are appropriate for the amount of service the station receives. Parking is difficult at times due to inconsiderate parking and people leaving their vehicles for extended periods of time.
Big train station but hard to get parked

Fantastic day out. Lots very helpful staff, including volunteers - who are more than happy to stop and chat, and explain the workings.. Drivers welcome you into the cab and explain how the engine works, the same with the signalman, inviting you into the signal box - explaining the operation of signals and points.

It was a shame that they've closed access to the workshops - although understandable on safety grounds... They do provide viewing galleries though, various exhibits.

Had a good afternoon and evening riding the train and stayed for the RAT (Real Ale Train). Good selection of beers and great fun having a mini beer festival on a moving train, will do it again though may get local accommodation to avoid my wife having to drive me back to West London with a belly full of beer.
Perhaps the railway could set up a deal with one of the B&B,s in the town?

A wonderful throwback to the golden age of steam. The steam engines, carriages and buildings all lovingly restored and maintained. The volunteer staff are helpful and enthusiastic.
The journey through the beautiful Hampshire countryside makes this heritage railway well worth a visit.
You should break your journey at Ropley to visit the engine sheds and engineering workshops.
This is a wonderful day out. There are preserved locamotives and rolling stock. The station buildings are atmospheric and kept pristine. Altogether a most enjoyable experience to be had.
Even though we had a wet day it was a very enjoyable one. Plenty to see, very helpful people. A great day out.
Nice little town, getting much busier, plenty of pubs and wine bars, a nice Asda.
Nice and clean but desperately needs a ticket machine.

This train station is a stopping off point on the railway line between crewe in one direction, and Stoke-on-Trent in the other direction.

One of the (two) platforms has a covered waiting area, whilst the other side has a little waiting room where people can sit and wait for the train to arrive.

This railway station does have a car park which can accommodate about 10 cars (as well as two parking spaces for disabled people). The only point to notice about this car park is that it is a pay and display car park.

There are no on-site staff at this station although there is a help point where you can ask for help if you need it.

This station does have digital information displays to indicate when the next trains are arriving at this railway station. 

Also there is a bike rack on one of the platforms that can accommodate two bicycles.

A lot of the trains passing through this railway station are electric powered (although there are still some diesel-powered trains that passed through here from time to time).

I would have given this railway station 5 stars out of 5, but I did not, simply because of the need for passengers to pay for their car parking.

There is nowhere on this railway station to buy tickets, consequently anybody wishing to board a train at this railway station must buy a ticket in advance (or on board the train).
Desperately needs a ticket machine.

Please be careful when alighting are this station, as you will alight directly onto the busy A18.
There is no live passenger information available from this station, although there is a new ticket machine.
A clean and tidy station
Unmanned station. No ticket machines. Layby opposite for parking but that is about it!
Dismal station. No departure board, no timetable, no announcements, no ticket machines
Lovely station in the middle of nowhere. Recommended for people who love railways, wildlife, nature and hate cars
i visited Alton as I had a temp job nearby. It was early morning and some individuals were handing out mince pie as Christmas was nearing.  The station is well staffed for the needs of passengers.
Great station with a cafe outside and easy transport links to London.

Nice quiet small station with parking opposite. Staff friendly & helpful. May be slightly slower into London than the alternative for me, but is the better option as quieter plus as it's end of line you always have a seat on the way up.

An OK station with a ticket office, bicycle storage, a nice new footbridge near the end of the platforms with lifts, a few ticket machines at the front of the station as well as interchange with buses towards Farnham, Guildford and Winchester. Also serves the Watercress Line which stops adjacent the mainline platforms.

P. K. H. ALTON "RAILWAY" STATION. 
P. K. H. STEAM RAILWAY TRAIN'S.
Nice clean and peaceful town.

Not impressed at all. One worker, I think his name is Damien, was horrible to my children and has been on numerous occasions including: mocking them, not letting them use the lift when one was in pain and clearly limping, he locked the lift and leading to an elderly woman not be able to use this facility there my children had to assist her with two sets of stairs. The lift was locked many times when it was completely fine. What if my children weren’t there for that elderly woman? I’m really not happy with this behaviour and think something should be done about it
It's annoying in the early morning, and mid afternoon's as the lifts keep being turned off?? Why, this the busiest times, this is a constant issue..
Great little station since they refurbished. Shame you can’t collect prepaid rail tickets here, meaning you have to pay £6 for delivery.

Please get a ticket machine so we can pick up tickets bought in advance. At the minute I have to arrive at least 15 minutes prior to pick up ticket from the desk as there are lots of people asking very detailed questions about trains, tickets, toilets, rail passes etc which hold up the queue.

The passing loop and additional platform here has allowed for an increase of services on the line. Trains are typically timed to pass each other at the same time. The station over is quite bare with minimal facilities and no staffing however the new platform is linked by a footbridge with lifts.
Lovely, light, open station with great views.
Well decorated
Great place
Quite nice village with museum,  pubs, cafes
A beautiful traditional railway station on the scenic Arun Valley Railway. Steam trains pass through occasionally.

Horrible station.  Unstaffed and no disabled access to platform 1. I had to negotiate a very wet staircase after torrential rain.  They could at least enclose it as at arundel the next stop down.  Covered seating only on platform 1 also.

The staff are so friendly, if you ask them a question they are more than helpful!! It makes a difference especially if you dont know where you are going they make sure you know what platform and when the next train is. Thank you to the staff at Amersham underground station.

Very nice station on the Metropolitan Line, one of the terminal stations. Good places to eat and shop a short walk from the station. Efficient Metropolitan Line service into central London (fast, semi-fast, and all station trains).

Terminus station for the Amersham branch of the London Underground Metropolitan Line. Underground services into London, and Chiltern line fast services southbound into London and northbound to Aylesbury.
Reliable, traditional tube train service.

Staff is sound me mate got his tenner chewed up in de ticket machine an They got it back for him try ask de same in central London
No chance
We are lucky to still have a train service which stops in Ammanford and goes all the way up to Shrewsbury.
With the price you pay to use the service this station always feels abandoned and forgotten ,no facilities and always grubby
Can be improved
Basic quiet station. About 5 trains per day.

A handy little station in a rather unusual place.  No vehicular access (pedestrian only), as the station entrance is under the M8 Sliproad flyover.  Not always manned, check schedules as this station was often closed on Sundays (although service does seem to have improved in recent months)
一个经常路过又不熟悉的站，很多火车只开到ANDERSTON，差评

Really annoying car park situation. It's a fixed price all day long so if you arrive in the afternoon to use the train for a quick trip you pay over the odds.

No tarrif is posted anywhere to be seen as you drive around and there are very few pay and display machines meaning a long walk to find one after you've parked. 

No refreshments are available at the station and it's not changed in 20 years from what I've seen. I'll give one star for the heated waiting room on the London bound side to shelter from the completely open wind swept platform.
Good service. Operator took my number and kept me up to date with who was picking me up and what car. Brilliant
Quite a nice peaceful station in the middle of the day. The vegetation in-between the platforms is a nice touch.
Helpful ticket office, friendly outside kiosk. Rude local taxi firm so rang a&b cars for a really good service

pretty basic station ,coffee shop and you can get a paper it is what it is .the local taxi company is a disgrace when you ask them for help .the railway staff are friendly and helpfull its under cover so you wont get wet if it rains and it does what it says on the tin.
Excellent website for checking times for train,tram,,,excellent friendly staff at station
You can’t even check your Oyster card , the oyster machine has been broken and has been kept so for ages

To Google Maps, not tourists of London, I would like to emphasise that this station is indeed CLOSED. Meridian Water is already opened and you DO NOT APPROVE my edit? What is this? Please update thank you

hmm google this station is now PERMANENTLY CLOSED!
Update maps!
Now!
Please!

To Google Maps, not tourists to London. Angel Road closed on the 31st of May 2019 and replaced with Meridian Water station, just down the track. You have Meridian Water station on the map but Angel Road is still there! 
Update your maps now!
This station is incredibly desolate. If you want to go to what feels like an abandoned station, this is the place for you. Though do it quickly, as this station will be replaced in 2019.

Remote and quaint little station on the Heart of Wessex Rail Partnership line between Bristol Temple Meads and Weymouth - the gardens are maintained by volunteers and the scenery around the area is excellent

The whole area is great for walking, sightseeing and cycling - it has a frequent service during the week and on Saturdays (certainly hourly) and a good service on Sundays but as with all train times please check before travelling.

It has two platforms - platform 1 is the northbound platform for bath Spa (for services to the London direction and in-between) and also on the Bristol temple Meads with a range of services - platform 2 is the southbound direction for Westbury and beyond

The down side is that there is NO wheelchair access, it is not staffed and only has an information point with getting through the advisor and the next trains in each direction etc., no toilets, no ticket machine (but it will be Ok to buy the tickets on the train)

As the station has only a small platform limited door opening  by the guard is in operation so if you get on at Bristol Temple Meads please ensure that you are in the front carriage (If you come from Bristol parkway etc., please ensure that the train comes in one direction and then goes out in reverse formation  and please beware that on occasions then it is possible NOT to get all the way through if it Is a 4 car unit, so it will be necessary to get off at Bath Spa (the last opportunity) to get in the front carriage.

The whole area around Avoncliff is well worth a visit and you can spend a whole day there with walking, cycling or sight seeing, eating drinking etc. or watching the boats go by

Beautiful, quiet station tucked away in the quaint town of Bagshot, after which "Bathilda Bagshot" was named in the popular fantasy children's novel series "Harry Potter". There is no known link between the books' author, JK Rowling, and the small Surrey village so one can only assume she was inspired by the gorgeous 60s-era architecture of the station. The class 456 trains which operate here regularly (on a half-hourly basis in both directions, towards Guildford and Ascot!) really add the the dystopian "1984" feel. Incidentally, the trainsets themselves were built in the 1990s, only marginally exceeding the time which Bagshot feels permanently locked in. I recommend everyone visits here at some point. Make use of the multi-purpose area where one can take a bike at any time, and have a ride in the nearby Swinley forest, before returning to the station and making use of Bagshot's fantastic rail links.

Leroy and James, customer assistants, who worked on shift the morning of my accident on the stairs: both need to be commended for their excellent care, compassion and attention to my wellbeing. 

I will describe their actions in the following:

I had an accident on the stairs yesterday in the morning rush to work. 4-5 steps I fell down... Landing ankle first, flexing the foot inward, tearing my left ankle tendon. This is called a level 2-3 sprain. According to my paramedic at St. GEORGE'S A&E. 

Leroy, James and their team immediately took my heavy bags and sat me down to rest the now swollen and disfigured ankle and Leroy talked me into a calm state (5mins). I tried to make it to work and it wasn't happening so a nice man drove me back home from Colliers Wood, where an ambulance took care of me.

Leroy saved my tendon. I commend you sir.

The Dundee bound platform has a quirky wooden shelter (better than the ubiquitous bus shelter found at busier stations) which has a bench in it, and is a great place for dog walkers to shelter when caught out in the rain. You can walk the coastal path from here either to Broughty Ferry or Monifieth and beyond. Batley is a town in the Metropolitan Borough of Kirklees, West Yorkshire, England. It lies 7 miles south-east of Bradford, 7 miles south-west of Leeds and 1 mile north of Dewsbury, near the M62 motorway.

Batley includes the districts of Batley Carr, Carlinghow, Cross Bank, Hanging Heaton, Healey, Lamplands, Carlton Grange Mount Pleasant, Soothill, Staincliffe, Upper Batleyand White Lee.

As Batley shares boundaries with both Dewsbury and Heckmondwike, parts of Batley Carr, Hanging Heaton and Staincliffe are part of Dewsbury, while part of White Lee is in Heckmondwike. There is an area of Ossett known as Healey, which is identical in name to the Batley district of Healey; the Ossett area is sometimes referred to as "Healey Mills" due to the very large congregation of mills that once existed in that area.

Newly improved station with clean waiting rooms
Nice station
a little station

Basic services. Ticket office not always manned as they might have more important jobs like washing the outdoor seats when it's raining!! "Park and Ride" available but the bigger car park is not really attached to the station.
No real drop off on Glasgow side platform - the car park is on the other side of the line and the bridge over the line is not accessible. Old fashioned station with minimal facilities.
Reliable service but the guy working the ticket office isn't keen on people. Get off your phone and provide customer service.
Does the job though it's small and there's no WiFi there

This station has got ticket machines and seating but not much else including toilets. King Street is a short walk if you want food or something.
It's a simple railway station, enough said. However, don't always expect to be able to use the ticket machines as they seem to be out of order more times than actually working.
Great train station, just needs a few more services.
Nice station, easy to use! Clean!

Belper station has hourly trains to Derby, Nottingham and Matlock. There's even a morning one to Chesterfield and Sheffield and an evening departure for Leicester and London. Good facilities including ticket machines, somewhere to shelter from the rain, a departure board and announcements. Just could do with some more services to London, the South West and the North!
Small station in country setting but spoiled by all the rubbish thrown down embankment including dirty nappies beer bottles etc
A basic railway station on the scenic Medway Valley Line.
Station fine.... Could do with a lick of paint
Good road

Train station is ok. Has an indoor waiting area for those cold days. Only gripe is lack of seating both platform 1 and 2. Why can't there be seating along the length of both train tracks. Should be considered, since the trains are either delayed or cancelled nearly every evening.
Easy access
Hardly any trains during the weekends otherwise okay

Benfleet station is pretty straight forward, staff seemed to know what they was doing. I did notice how people did not even say thank you or acknowledge staff members for giving them tickets etc. And I really do not approve of the rudeness people blatantly gave to staff. Station was clean and the trains where running on time.

Sole ticket machine would only accept cards but only one person was selling them by hand so a large queue of customers built up. Eventually another position opened but both pulled down the shutters shortly thereafter as the computer system crashed – cue another large queue while attempts were made to reboot it. Apalling communication with those waiting, most of whom had no idea what the hold up was.

Station itself rather pleasant, at least on a warm summerʼs day. The ticket office, however, is situated on the opposite side of the station to the car park and with no footbridge this means a long trek round to get there (inside the station an underpass allows access to the opposite platform). Large and secure bike rack as well as pick up and drop off point for vehicles.

Always a 20 minute queue for tickets in the morning. Lack of staff.

Ticket machine has been broken for 8 months...weekends a lottery if there are any staff but c2c happy to employ ticket checkers. The disabled facilities at Benfleet are attrocious. C2C should be ashamed no clear signs to the two disabled ramp entrances. No clear instructions on how to operate them.Reliant on someone pressing the button in the ticket cave...very hit and miss non existent at night. For one of the busiest stations it’s an awful little rats nest with sullen snippy staff. An example of failed privatisation all for money and sod the proles, especially if they are disabled.
A refection of minimalist capitalism we had to bump start the train last week.

An incredibly baron and desolate station with the bare minimum of facilities that are only fully usable during the morning peak. Step free access is possible via a foot-crossing, but do be careful as trains can pass at speed without stopping here.

This is a popular station with commuters, and a ghost town for the rest of the day. There are two trains an hour in both directions (Alton and London Waterloo), however due to the length of the platform at this station only a maximum of the front six carriage doors are operational. The carpark gets very busy, week days by about 8am you will be very lucky to find a space. The booking office is only open during the morning rush hour, though a ticket machine is available at the front of the station. Similarly the waiting room and toilets are only open during rush hour.
Truly spectacular
A standard station
No different any other small South Yorkshire station
Pretty little branch line station.  Not too far from the village
Rusting gently
Easy to navigate and placed well in the area
nice old Victorian train station
Visited during the Summer and my visit was spectacular.  Travelled by train from Euston into Berkhamsted station and the trip was fast. Definitely worth getting out of London for the day.
An attractive railway station on the scenic West Coast Main Line.
NO PROBLEMS.... HEY IF ITS GOOD ENOUGH FOR ACTOR GEOFFREY PALMER TO USE.. ITS MORE THAN GOOD ENOUGH FOR ME AND MY SONS.....
Great place to have my commute part of but not the best place to get my bike off the train though

It's a fine train station. It has two tracks, two platforms an uninhabited room with no one inside. I thinks its supposed to be a ticket office. It possess all the bells and whistles that a 21st century train station needs. This includes lights, a bridge, floors etc.

There isn't a ticket machine but there is a permit machine. You can deposit a small amount into the machine for the permit. This means you can present the ticket to the officer on the train. Showing them you intended to get a ticket but the station didn't have a machine. He or she may believe you and set you on your way. Or they may hit you with a £1000 fine starting your day off in the worst of ways.

The trains journeys along the tracks into the train station. Some of them stop at the station. Some of them proceed past the train station. If you board one of the trains it will voyage along the tracks to a new destination.

I often visit Birmingham or Coventry less than 20 minutes away.
Just like any other station but i think the platform is abit low. People with pushchairs might have a hell of a job getting on and off the train 🚄
It does have a ticket machine inside the anti-rain room near the bikes. The only negative thing is the trains timetable. You can wait for hours.
Small nice train station with fast collection ticket machine in the waiting room on Platform 1 and a ticket office but I don't usually see it open.

It's a 10 minute walk away from the retail park and buses but does it's job of being a new station well enough for the most part. Trains only run every hour despite the line linking two busy places. 

The station has a single ticket machine and has step free access via long ramps linking both platforms. Could do with improvement in the future with a more frequent service and direct buses stopping here.
Great place cant wait to go again
Nice little station on the Nuneaton to Coventry line 😃
Great place for the children
Basic but modern station, minimal facilities but good lighting in the dark, and does have electronic display boards.
I enjoyed my experience doing nothing here
what a lovely little station - unique as remotest in england
A perfect place to start or finish a walk through the attractive Norfolk countryside. Be sure to check the train times as very few trains actually come here.
Could do with a local chip shop to supplement the wonderful views.
So scenic and peaceful. It is truely one of the most remote plaves in Britain.
Ok in summer when its warm. But not pleasant in colder times, trains once an hour towards Huddersfield, and towards Barnsley meadowhall and Sheffield so offers good links.

Very poor station overall if you ask me. None of the platforms have step free access, there is very little in terms of seating and shelter, the ticket office is open only during the early weekday mornings and there's only two trains an hour stopping.

I was fortunate enough not to smell the sewage works that's a stone's throw away from the platform.
Known locally as Smellylands station. Dreadful station which looks like it's about to fall down anytime.

Platforms are fine. Ticket machines work well if used properly. Working NFC touch-in/touch-out machines. The ticket office is barely ever open, when it is customer service is OK. Old station, rather dirty but you won't be there very long anyway.

Great station. 
I especially like the fact it doesn't have any barriers, so I can travel for free!
Love this station. I always know I'm at Berrylands when I smell the sewage. Unique.
Nice station with a good car park.
Sweet station in the middle of nowhere

Great station since they refurbished it. It has a proper Costa coffee shop as well as better ticketing facilities. Friendly staff and decent waiting room on the north end of the platform + 1st class lounge on the platform at the southern end.
Nice easy pick up point for coaches.
Born & bred in berwick.

Took my husband to catch London train yesterday, arrived early looking forward to coffee (husband is diabetic and we had come from Jedburgh so refreshment needed!).  We have often found cafe closed but this time it had disappeared all together!  This station which caters for long distance travellers (or rather doesn't!) needs to get its' act together.
Standard train station, a bit shabby in places. 1st class lounge is nothing more than a gimmick and really not worth bothering with. The seating is better in the standard lounge.

VERY quiet country station with offset platforms separated by a level crossing. Quiet. Rather spartan except for the flower containers and painted wooden station signs, although these could do with a refresher.  Basic open waiting shelters on both platforms. No staff on site or even a machine to supply tickets, which must be bought on the train (but see one of the signs in the shelters regarding card payments by phone). No car park and train services are not exactly frequent.

Note for wheelchair users: the short ramps to the platforms narrow at the top, which may pose some difficulties (and there is no obvious reason why this should be so).

Surrey's least used station, and mostly useless. It's near the South Downs Way so is good for ramblers, but is on a fairly busy road with no bus service, no car park and no convenient place to pick up and drop off. Betchworth village is not near. It was on Beeching's hit list, but survived because this is Surrey.
Absolutely nothing here. There is a train every two hours on a Sunday but a warning to mind the gap every few minutes. Good base for walking if you can time it right.

Good little station however half the time it is closed causing a lot of inconvenience for passengers hence my 4 star rating. On the plus side though the staff are amazing at dealing with any help needed!

Great little station. Staff are ever so friendly, polite and helpful. They are quite up to date with the train times and they have great little quotes displayed on the whiteboard every day, which motivate passengers and clients. It is a very clean station most of the time, a pleasure to commute to/from work.

Just a really meh station that, despite it's name, isn't located near the tube station of the same name at all. No step free access here either and the platforms can get quite narrow in places. Seating and shelter is barely adequate but at least trains can be quite frequent at times.
Very nice area of London, lots of green spaces and very close to the city.
My advice would be get off at Cambridge Heath for the underground its easier

🦋This was such a beautiful place to travel to. Peaceful and tranquil it was and you really do feel at one with nature. You can sit with nature and listen to the waters dancing with the rocks or if you feel brave, why not take a walk or climb some hills and mountains. Snowdon isn’t too far from this spot either so if your feeling really adventurous and energetic and your fitness levels are good why not climb snowdon. 
As long as appropriately dressed and prepared (jackets, footwear, harness, hydration-water etc...) this will be a fantastic experience and also very good for the mind. Do it in a day or book one of the local hotels and do it over a few days. Nothing beats that feeling when you’re at peace with nature.
It caters for hikers , tourists with family plus it's a jewel of Wales worth a visit anytime

Food came quickly, chips weren't very hot but weren't greasy either.
Good choice of menu and the 2 ladies taking order's and getting the drinks were really polite and helpful.
Ice cream choices were excellent and portions really good.

This is a wonderful town in North Wales. The train station has a fabulous building that is still very Victorian in look and feel. You can get national rail trains from this station still but there is a great deal more to do there as well.  There are a number of cafés and shops to look at. There is also railway hobby shop over the track bridge to go and look at.
A true Welsh gem and fabulous scenery.
Pigeons nest is around the staff are 😈
Never had no problems. Great little station. well lit and clean.

The train station its self is fine. The staff however not so. I asked some questions as I am new back in the area. I think the lady would have rather have pulled teeth than look at me and be helpful and friendly. Far different to when I visited London where the staff all seemed pleasant and helpful.

Although the train station itself is fine i cannot say much for the staff. my mum is in a wheelchair and everytime we go we get overcharged on our train tickets, even though we are able to get 50% off, so a journey that should cost us £12 ends up costing around £18. we have brought this up with national rail on many occasions with promises it will not happen in the future but nothing changes.

Another well kept railway station other than the pigeons nesting under the train shed but that doesn't bother me! The station is located near the town centre just minutes away. A handy one for students as East Riding College is near its doorstep! I recommend people to visit here especially Flemingate shops and the town centre.
Nice station bit concerned about the man working on the ticket barrier leering at all the school girls, noticed it 2 days running.... watch out kids
Large station with very long platforms. Lower than the surrounding areas so access is via two long covered slopes. Virtually all trains passing through stop here.
Really worried about the random man going by the name of borys who keeps asking me for money
Quiet, clean, with stunning views.
The gentleman who was on duty at the Bexhill ticket office this morning (10/04/18) was really knowledgeable & very helpful. I was most impressed.
Nice little station
Bertie is awesome. What a great station to go through. Excellent staff.

A nice station with a large car park 

The station is mainly staffed most of the time 

They have toilets but understand only open whist staff on duty

A shop selling coffee etc is available most days for the morning

Otherwise clean and tidy and they do their best in the circumstances

A National Rail Station located in zone 5. The trains go to London Charing Cross, London Cannon Street and London Victoria six days per week  (but this is subject to change in the future.)

Facilities wise, there's a coffee shop, a waiting room and clean toilets on the up platform; the down platform boasts a large covered bike rack.

駅の待合室がとても気に入りました。
ロンドンブリッジやピカデリーサーカスに向かうのに何回か利用した駅です。

夜に下車した時に白い何かをホームにまいていて驚きましたが、凍結防止用の塩だそうです。
サラサラの塩ではなく、ガリガリの岩塩を砕いたような塩をまいているので靴で踏むとソールに刺さりそうです。
Really helpful staff, clean station, good coffee shop!

Lovely service from the Security Officer! As an elderly couple we would be lost without help on this new technology! We went to buy tickets this evening 19th March at approximately 20:50 hrs for the following morning and the young gentleman (if I’m not wrong his name was Gazmir) helped us buying our tickets and gave us the helpful information we needed! Well English spoken and great customer service and the smile on his face very welcoming!

Great connections to Oxford and London, clean station and good parking is also available, however the people of Bicester voted to call this station Bicester town station and the council told chiltern to call it Bicester Village station, so can only give it a 4 star review i am afraid.

Whatever you want and have money for it, you'll find it here. However, it is very expensive but very good quality. Not only shopping but also good restaurants and coffee corners. If you don't have extra money to spend, still worth the visit and a cup of coffee or tea, ice cream too.
Convenient station near to Bicester Village, walking distance.  Nice waiting area with old fashion furniture
Small station few staff. Ticket office still operating.

At Bidston I asked a different member of staff at the service desk if he could print my ticked there. He said no and if I traveled without one I'd get fined. I was forced to buy a single even though I already bought a return. The gentelman at Bidston didn't show any empathy/understanding and simply pointed out that the other member of staff on the Pennyffordd - Bidston train was wrong, forcing me to buy another ticket.

Fairly large free Park and Ride facility with disabled parking directly adjacent to station (though as access to the platforms is via footbridge this isn't the ideal station for wheelchair users). Warm waiting room with ticket office inside and frequent trains to West Kirby, New Brighton and Liverpool.

Great parking here. Plenty of space, especially at weekends which was when I used this station. This station is in a good location for anyone wanting to travel into the centre of Liverpool and is at the end of the M53 motorway up the Wirral.  Convenient if you're coming from North Wales, and areas close to the M56/M6 motorways. Staff are friendly and knowledgeable, and will make sure you get the best value tickets for your journey. Trains are frequent. I didn't look at the timetable and was still able to jump on a train within 15 to 20 minutes of arriving.
Amazing waiting room
Open area station in the middle of fields and over the bridge to get to but has a manned ticket station not all night though and coffee machine
Great station very clean
A busy railway station which serves Billbrook in particular.  Car parking is limited

Billingshurst train station is really a beautiful Victorian building steeped in history. It's quintessentially English with hanging baskets and potted plants all cared for by staff and volunteers. The station supervisors are always very pleasant and helpful.
Really lovely railway station located in a scenic village ... great escape to this lovely town hidden down the South of England
A beautiful historic railway station on the scenic Arun Valley Railway. Steam trains pass through occasionally.

Train Station Review:
Good, clean toilets though they're not often open as the Ticket office is hardly open (and southeastern really needs to change that as it's hard to buy tickets on weekdays at 8am when my train arrives).
Extensive shelter on platform 1 and a smaller one on platform 2. Waiting room is always open. Good providing of bins. Slightly too many pigeons but that's nature for you.
Lovely station clean and tidy good connections
All weekday train services stop here usually.
The trains at this station are stuck in time. Literally. It will be 16:15 and the board will still say that your train is expected to arrive at 16:10. The whole northern rail are a joke

Small local rail station with decent links to Warrington, Manchester, Liverpool and beyond. Stairs and lift access is provided as well as a pedestrian bridge. Close to the local birchwood shopping centre; which is just across the road. Waiting room on the main platform has a heater and some seating but the across the bridge its a little smaller.

This station has a waiting room on both platforms but like other reviews it can get a bit cold.  There are some heaters on the wall which can be switched on for you to stand in front of, how often they work I don't know.  The station has recently had some money spent on it and they have built a new bridge which includes a lift for disabled access and parents with push chairs.  This was put in around 2016 I think so its a big help.  Not that many staff around as it only receives about 2-3 trains in one direction per hour.
Nice little and very convenient train 🚂 station.
Come prepared! It gets very cold, and wet, here - primarily as there is no roof on either of the platforms!

The "trains" side of the station is only accessible by steep stairs - there is no access for those with mobility issues or with prams etc.  Maintenance of this platform is minimal.  There is 1 screen showing the arrivals/departures but it can only be viewed by walking along the platform from the entrance, which is a pain when it then says the train is cancelled (quite regularly, as it is not a "priority line") and you have to walk back along the platform and down the stairs to find an alternative route.  Trains are scheduled to run every 30 minutes each direction, but have periods every day where cancelled.

The "trams" side is fully accessible via ramp or stairs.  Maintenance of the platform is fairly good. Trams run every 11 to 15 minutes in each direction and are generally reliable.

A very weird arrangement, two independent single tracks, one for trains, one for trams. The negative (making it not 5 stars is the fact that to transfer from one or the other, you have leave one and enter the other at street level

I don't live in Birchbeck, but I come here frequently. I like small train stations because they are easy to navigate. Personaly, my great aunt really likes this station. She is blind and she says "I really like this station because I can easily move through the station with my hands. As far as  I know, there is nothing out of place." I think people who read this review should try this station. Be sure to ignore those other 3 star reviews. P.S. When I go to this station, I usually walk, so I don't really know what parking is like.

There are two platforms at this station: one platform serves Southern trains going in both directions, and the other platforms serves trams going in both directions. 
Tram platform has an accessible ramp from street level as well as stairs. Unfortunately Southern Rail platform is accessible only by stairs.

when i have visited this station before, the ticket window is normally closed. it is also the station where i always hear kids on the train saying they will get off because then they can avoid paying for a ticket. much prefer the main Southport station.

One of the most picturesque and idiosyncratic stations on the Merseyrail network, complete with original station canopy. Although no longer in use, an old wooden signal box can be seen on the opposite side of the busy level crossing at the north end of the station, so when you alight here it does feel as if as if you're stepping backwards in time. We'll worth a visit if you're passing.

It’s great. I like the underground pathways to the other platform in this station. They have really friendly staff. They were some wheelchair guy and a member it a Of staff actually talked to him about his disability and actually thought about him.
Friendly staff, clean station.

What do I think of this station? I think it is cool. You phony people who like big stations and give this station a 3 star review!! I really don't care about those people. It's small. I walk here a lot, so I don't know what parking is like. The staff are very helpful. Except for Steuen. He is plain RUDE! TRY TO AVOID HIM!!! Over all, the station is nice and cosey.

Staff are lovely and helpful. So quick to get into Liverpool. Trains could be a little cleaner but can't be helped at times. Announcements could be timed better before a train leaves if trains are cancelled or go so far with no transport the other end.
Nice, little station with lift access
To visit Birkenhead park
Beautiful place

Proper old-fashioned Mersey train station, no fuss & frills-croissants or café con leché.🚞 Probably hasn't changed in hundred years with an old wooden housed footbridge. Far prefer this to the neon lit Conway Park.
A very easy to navigate station that is rather large. It is easy to change platforms and has step free access. Very good station.

I checked the National rail enquiries website the day before travelling. My new car has broken down so I'm back to getting public transport to Chester again. The station doesn't open until after 0735 on a Sunday and the first train to Chester isn't till 0820. There's no coffee shops or anything nearby to grab something while i mull over being over an hour late.
There are no drop off or pick up points at this station! No parking at all! 15 min spaces no return within 60 mins!
good but can have problems with the lift but it a ok station

A relatively large station serving as interchange between the North and South Wirral lines into Liverpool city centre.
Clean and easy to navigate, with helpful staff. The station is built on a curve so there is a larger than usual gap between the train and the platform in places.
Not a bad station, but when the lift is out of service on both sides, it can be a pain to try and get on to the other side of the platform, which isn't much good for wheelchair and pram users.
A nice, balanced station that has wheelchair access via lift to get to one or the other platforms

Nice old station buildings juxtaposed with modern (and very expensive) footbridge with lifts on both sides. MASSIVE car park with space for 600-700 cars, but very popular as a park and ride location so spaces still at a premium.

An old victorian station in the Wirral line, with trains to Liverpool city centre and both New Brighton and West Kirby. There is a manned ticket office, platforms are accessed by a new looking walkover, complete with lifts as well as stairs.
best place to get the 410 on weekdays
Bright and clean station building with modern access ramp to platforms. Pleasant in summer and sheltered in winter. Some parking in nearby streets.

Birkenhead Park is two platform station with regular trains to Liverpool city centre, West Kirby and New Brighton. It has a manned ticket office, cycle storage and is ideally placed to visit Birkenhead Park itself.
Toilets often out of order
Frequent services! Living in Dallas for half my life 1 train a week is amazing! In Dallas my old station only had 3 trains a week!
services are super frequent, there are a lot of facilities and ticket machines but very crowded
The station had no facilities to wait in so I got wet and cold .Very poor service as well, it needs improvements
More train services stopping at the station badly needed!
Dingey station. Rat parlour
So called first class lounge providing paper cups! No, paper cups is most certainly not first class. Although, for Virgin, it is probably the best they can do!

Absolutely the worst customer service experience ever. To say this station is attached to an international airport and potentially is the first impression of our country that travellers get, you would expect the staff to be helpful and accommodating. To get my son on the train home(he'd missed his flight) I had to go to my local station to help me so I could get a ticket to him(THEY WERE BRILLIANT THANK YOU ABERYSTWYTH STATION AND COLIN AT TRANSPORT WALES ) . Birmingham international staff at the station did not give him any help at all. Virgin staff rude unhelpful sarcastic generally nasty. Look at your training  and recruiting. Your team leaders need to lead by example. Very disappointed.

In regards to the station itself I couldn’t fault. Today I caught a train from Birmingham new street to Birmingham international, on my way to work. I am a young girl who hardly catches trains, so I am anxious as it is. I buy a ticket online from Birmingham new street to international. As I am coming through the barriers I get stopped by 2 men ( work for virgin) I explain my phone has just died, ( which it did ) and I can’t get the barcode up on my phone. He told me to wait over the other side, and wait for someone , ( I’m in a rush) so I did. You can see at this point I’m worrying & very anxious nearly in tears. A lady come over to me and explained I would have to pay another £3.20. I explain I haven’t got anything on me. and I really need to get through to work. ( I’m nearly in tears Late as it is as I never catch trains and was all over the place shaking) I was really intimidated by the man on the door ( who looked Jamaican ) who told me to say please next time I want to get through the barriers. Would u speak to a 50 year old women like that ? They could see I was distressed and as a young female I needed a hand. What if it was there daughter / sister? Over a poxy 3.20. I think the issue could of been dealt much better, but all they cared about was a stupid £3.20 ticket. I get I didn’t have the ticket on me, however the attitude towards the man on the door to me was horrific. Next time I will not travel to this station. I’m a 21 year old female, was nervous as it is shaking and actually when I got through the barriers had a panic attack. It’s not like I travelled from London, I travelled 2 stops. I pay for transport all year around ( bus ) , but never again will I travel to this station again. And had put me off completely. Please think about peoples feelings too.! And how you handle situations..!
Lovely clean station, well laid out, nice staff.
£12.00 for 30mins parking, unbelievable.
I like this station, it’s really good but I don't understand how the toilets are closed before the train service ends...

My station! I always get off the train here, and go home here. Moor Street is an amazing station. So old and the architecture is brilliant. The small cafe has really kind staff inside. Lovely when its winter its so cosy!

Arrived here from London for a day trip. I was kind of expecting an ultra modern and large railway station, but this is actually a cute little station that still retains the Victorian era architectural elements. The designs of the interior signage remind a little of Harry Potter. The inside is pretty clean and there's the a few amenities, such as a newsagents and a cafe. Given that New Street station and the Bullring are just a short walk aways, that probably all thats needed anyway.
Old world.

Less ticket barriers unlike, New Street where it's ticket barrier city, simple platform layout and less coffee shops which charge ridiculous prices for a cup of coffee and the station doesn't choke you with noxious fumes. Friendly Staff on trains and on platforms.

Birmingham New Street should review the placement of their cycle-racks, a NEW station should have the cycle-racks inside. If you cant collect your bike for whatever reason, you know it will be locked inside and therefore SAFE. LEAVING CYCLES OUTSIDE IN THE ALLEY IS NOT SAFE. All the other major Birmingham train station's have cycle racks inside the station so why not New Street.
One of the best trains stations I have been to so far.  Very spacious and a lot of staff to ask for help.  A lot of things to do (eat or shop) to kill time at the station. A mall like experience.

Station building is nice with plenty of choice of shops and restaurants but the signage in the station is terrible. Only half the platforms are signposted and there are multiple barriers to get through before you reach the correct ones, many of which your ticket isn't valid for. Glad there were plenty of helpful staff or I would not have found my platform.

The security could do with stepping up a pace since i have been using the train's early in the mornings the ticket barriers are always open allowing free loaders getting a free ride and youngsters cycling inside, think the piano is a good idea someone is always on in

Thanks to the brilliant Special Assistance staff at Tamworth and Birmingham New Street! My son is a #wheelchair user and we recently had to be in Birmingham for 8am. No problem! We turned up at 06:55 at Tamworth, bought tickets using his disabled persons railcard and went up in the lift to platform 4 to catch the 07:01 to Birmingham New Street. There were 2 staff on the platform already even though we had not booked Special Assistance in advance. The train arrived a couple of minutes early and although it was crowded (standing room only) the wheelchair ramp was deployed and we were on the train ready for an on time departure. At Birmingham New Street there were 3 staff on the platform already (only one of them for us!) Again the ramp was deployed no problem and we were off the train. The Special Assistance helper asked if we were travelling further but even though we were not he accompanied us in the lift to the station concourse. Great work! We were in McDonald's for breakfast in plenty of time for our meeting at 8am.

Absolutely disgusting service from the woman behind the ticket desk at 5pm yesterday afternoon(1st August) Disgusting attitude and providing misinformation. Clearly being behind a partition has given her a false sense of power. Will also be making a formal complaint to her superiors.

The young blonde woman behind the 'excess fare' booth should be reprimanded. She was asking me about my age, and asking me for proof. I told her my D/O/B and then pulled a smirk face to her colleague, who was on his phone. She wasn't friendly at all. 

Overall its A lovley modern station (Similar to New St.) with escalators and big screens and a direct link to the city centre. The gates at the far back are being monitored now. Dont be fooled! You need to walk out the main exit for the city centre or youll be lost.

The blonde lady on the gates is really helpful and friendly.

I prefer Moor St though.

Great staff, great service and great value, you must keep this station open, as it is a vital link to the North from where I live, in Poole.

One of the best stations in the area!! The station is small, which makes it easy to navigate. I've been there 3 times and I had no problems at all! I think you should try this station!

A small local station served by an hourly stopping service in each direction in the off peak.  Trains here travel to Southampton Central from Platform 1 and Portsmouth & Southsea (and occasionally Portsmouth Harbour) from Platform 2, calling at all stations en-route.

The station is unstaffed - tickets can be purchased from the ticket vending machine at the station entrance on Platform 2, and a help point is located nearby if you require information or assistance.  Station facilities are limited to bike racks for 8x bicycles, a covered shelter on each platform, and live departure boards showing next train times, status and calling points.  A footbridge connects the two platforms.  Car parking is provided free of charge to railway customers.

The station makes travel to Southampton and Portsmouth very convenient once one memorises the timetable.  It is especially useful for example when there is a Saint's match on and the roads into and out of the city centre are rammed.  A weekend super off peak return fare is super cheap too with my railcard - at just £1.90 it is often cheaper than parking for more than 1 hour in town!  Onward connections at Southampton, Fareham and Portsmouth for more distant destinations (e.g. London, Brighton, Bristol) makes Bitterne a convenient start point for most rail journeys.

The station loses a star because the only way to access Platform 1 (towards Southampton) is via a footbridge which means you're stuffed if you are disabled and cannot use stairs.  Additionally the 1tph service pattern greatly hampers the station's overall usefulness and trains can sometimes be even more infrequent in the morning peak!  South West Trains plan to double the number of hourly services between Southampton and Portsmouth from December 2018 and I hope this will include more services stopping at Bitterne, which will hopefully increase passenger numbers.  Staffed facilities such as a ticket office or coffee stall would also not go amiss.

All in all it's a very convenient little station to use unless you have special accessibility requirements, could be better but could certainly be much, much worse (looking at you, Shippea Hill)!
Good
Station is fine, ticket machines are hopeless, require far too much information for a simple journey, and only seem to work when the wind is blowing in the right direction due to poor WiFi signal.

Firstly, they don't let you into the platforms until the train is actually there so you have huge queues at the platform doors which cross over the ticket barriers making it hard for people to get out of there. They really should have had the ticket barriers on the gates so that people can go onto the platforms whenever they want. Secondly, the ticket barriers didn't seem to be working for some people when I passed through them.

I have a fond interest in the Bourne End to Marlow, and the Bourne End to Maidenhead branch lines respectively. I could sit and spew information about it but, in reality I'm afraid my original positive respect and admeration for Borne end station, the terminal hub for connections to Maidenhead and Marlow has been tarnished simply by the ticket office manager.

On my way to London, I'd notice the train that would get to Maidenhead would have a knock on effect to my entire journey to Paddington down to time. Thinking through my day, after buying my tickets from the ticket machine, I turned to the ticket office and asked for a refund. The ticket office manager, seemed frustrated, and angered and explained that because the ticket machine was there, no one was using his office. I can connect the dots and assume that if the machine kills off his job as the ticket office manager, he'll either loose his job there, or have little to no income as a station manager, I also assume he lives there from the washing line and the barred windows of a small house that sits on the platform next to the station's ticket office.

Overall, unbiased by my poor experience with the manager, the station has an older feel too it, as it still carries wooden sleepers, and chairs from 1953, however the rest of the station, for as old as it is, feels clean, maintained and modern. But with the lack of staff and ticket office attendees, I now have a reluctance to use the office at all in any case primarily due to the low staff numbers and the manager being so frighteningly cross.

Space management could be better but on the whole is sufficient. Parking has recently been improved with markings indicating where spaces are, as well as entries and exits. Parking capacity could be improved by moving the station shelter towards the bridge and then taking a section off from the fence. 

This would allow cars to park vertically and thus could have the potential to offer more spaces for those perhaps looking for a park and ride solution. 

Station itself offers a no thrills approach. There is shelter provided with reasonable space should the weather hit typical Scottish measures. Metal seats are also provided both inside the shelter and along the stations platform. 

Train time are available and I am to understand that the accessibility / customer terminal is routinely checked to ensure that it is working well.

For the sake of clarity (as Google fails to recognise this) - there are two stations named "Brixton". One station (served only by South Eastern Railway) is in Atlantic Road/Station Road (two entrances); the other is in Brixton Road (served only be London Underground). There is no interchange between the two except by walking via the street and passing each station's own barrier line.
