Broadbottom railway station lies on the train line that heads towards Glossop in one direction, and towards Manchester in the opposite direction. 

What was a little bit confusing to me, was that there is a car park beside the railway station - but for some strange reason (unless it's me), it wasn't sign posted as the railway station car park. 

In fact, the signpost to the entrance to the car park refers to car parking for adjacent premises, not necessarily for railway station car parking itself.

Anyway, if it is the railway station car park, then it does have a quite a lot of spaces for car parking - perhaps in the region of 75 to 100 spaces.

Access to this particular railway station is gained via three ways. 

Firstly, you can walk into the railway station from this car park. Or you can walk down a set of steep steps from the road that is adjacent to the station, or lastly you can also take a walk from the adjacent road down a steep slope to the railway station.

There is a departure board that does show approaching train times - which is good.

There are no apparent signs of any bike racks in and around this particular railway station.

Buying tickets for any train departing from this particular railway station can be done via two means. There is a on-site ticket office, or if you prefer the less human approach, there is also a touch screen ticket machine just at the entrance to the railway station on the Glossop bound platform.

There is seating on both platforms, although strangely enough it is only the Manchester bound platform that has a covered waiting area.

If passengers want to be able to get on the Manchester bound platform, they have to cross over the railway line via the footbridge.

One overriding memory for me, at this particular railway station, is the abundance of closed circuit television cameras. I think I counted at least 5 of them - but there might be more.

I've been using Kentish Town West to get to Camden market and hadn't been to Camden Road station for a long while.

I am pleased to see that the station has been modernised, and now includes full step free access from the street to both platforms.

I think it is still necessary to use a boarding ramp to get on and off the trains.

There is also a full gateline now, making it less likely to get an incomplete journey. This includes a wide gate too.

The staircases to the platforms are still pretty long and steep, but have central handrails so passengers are split into up and down routes.

Departure boards are on each platform and in the ticket hall.

Because of the lifts, more staff are on site here than similar sized stations.

Camden market is less than 10 minutes walk from the entrance, so it's well located.

Cycle racks are available outside and it's possible to pick up and drop off people in the road beside the station.

Overall a station that meets the needs of most users.

The rail service here is useless, trains are so frequently late that any regular commute will come with a guarantee of lateness. Also you will find abusive staff that will accuse you of stealing when their equipment fails to work. They will take your money and not provide a ticket, when you carry a debit card they fine you. If you use the ticket machine then be very cautious as many of the tickets offered are not valid and the staff use this to express the aforementioned abuse. If you have to use this service buy your tickets from a staffed station like Stafford or Birmingham where the staff treat you with respect. And remember when they are trying to bully fines out of you, you only need to buy a ticket before boarding if you are boarding at a staffed station. Finally when using this station, mind your step in poor weather as they will dodge their responsibility to treat the platforms.

This quaint Little Railway Station sits on the railway line that heads eventually towards Liverpool in One direction and towards Wrexham in the other.

This railway station does have car parking spaces for up to about 4 or 5 cars but there are no official car parking spaces for disabled drivers.

Next door to the official car parking spaces there is a bike rack that can probably take up to 8 bicycles if necessary. What is unusual, but also good, and the reason I gave this station 4 stars, is that it actually has spaces where cyclists can lock their bikes away for security purposes which is good to see.

There is no security cameras overlooking the car park although there is some form of security CCTV on the platform.

As mentioned previously there is no official parking spaces for disabled drivers but if a disabled driver was able to find a spot to park they would be able to access the railway station because there is a ramp that leads up to the platforms.

This car park thankfully does have digital displays that indicates to passengers as to when trains are likely to arrive at the platforms. 

This railway station has no on-site staff whatsoever, and it also has no ticket machine (if people felt the need to buy a ticket from here), so consequently anyone who wishes to board a train in either direction will have to have purchased a ticket beforehand or they will have to get one once they board the train.

Both of the platforms at this railway station do you have shelters where passengers can sit down and wait for their train. Both of these shelters at this railway station are covered, in order to provide some form of protection against the weather if necessary.

A hidden gem of a station, with just a single loop from Romsey to Salisbury and back (via Romsey!) running through it. Trains depart hourly in each direction from 06:00 to 23:00ish. 

You can travel to Romsey or Eastleigh/Southampton Parkway in minutes and from those stations access the rest of the national rail network with ease. In the Salisbury direction the service calls at all the small Southampton stations west of the River Itchen, shortcutting a number of complicated bus routes and also connecting with eastbound rail services.

The building, constructed when the station was re-opened, is modern, clean and well maintained with friendly staff. Unfortunately the station building is only open in the morning but there are ticket machines outside.

There's plenty of free parking and the only real negative I can think of is the very limited amount of covered waiting space if the weather's bad and the station is unstaffed.
A modern railway station on a single track line from Eastleigh to Romsey. Steam trains pass through occasionally.
Suburban station reopened in 2003 to serve growing population. Utilitarian structure with ticket office open mornings, single platform, ticket machines, free parking, footbridge.

This station has obviously had lots of money spent on it in recent years.  The paint looks fresh some of the seats have been replaced.

However, despite all the money spent, if one has mobility difficulties, forget it. The only step-free-access platform is Platform 1. The other 3 platforms require ascending 30 steps and then descending 30. There are no staff other than 1 person from a private security company.  So no way of obtaining access with help.

As for the parking, it's almost impossible to make out the position of most of the bays.  There are, apparently, two disabled bays but if the feint markings are anything to go by, neither bay is suitable for a wheelchair user; admittedly a moot point given the lack of access to all platforms.

Staying on parking, the daily rate is just £5.00, free for blue badge holders.

The ticket machine offers only a few, no doubt higher priced, options for travel.  We used TheTrainLine App whilst sat in the waiting room and obtained the correct tickets. The tickets were available from the machine immediately.

This station would be so much better if the operators/owners had installed better access for disabled customers during the refurbishment. We are due to depart for London in 5 minutes and we are dreading the return already. I had a day trip to Colwyn Bay on Tuesday 29th 2018.  I was due to catch the 5.23 train back to Manchester Piccadilly. It was a hot day and I was not feeling particularly well by the time I was due to travel home.  I have various disabilities but needed a break.  There were two members of staff who were nice to me.  One was the quietly soft spoken professional young man who scanned my ticket for me as I have tendonitis in my right wrist and struggle to use it. He was patient and had a nice smile. Then there was the exceptionally kind lady who showed great empathy and kindness all the way through until I caught my train.  She was looking out for me the whole time (even from the other side of the platform!) She made regular checks that I was ok and chatted in a friendly manner when I thanked her for her support and drew her into conversation for a moment, as the train had been slightly delayed.  She lives in Rhyl.  I love Wales.  It's a beautiful place! XXX

Crossmyloof station, on both the Glasgow to East Kilbride line and Glasgow to Barrhead line, is a station built most likely during the late 19th century. The station is, from north to south, preceded by Glasgow Central, which is the main hub for travel within Scotland's largest city by population, as of the United Kingdom's government Census, which was taken in the year of 2011, AD The station is succeeded by Pollokshaws West, on the B769/Pollokshaws Road, and is very close to local landmarks such as the Pollok House and Country Park, and the Burrell Collection. Thornliebank, on the East Kilbride Branch, is on the East Renfrewshire/Glasgow boundary, and serves the town of Thornliebank, as well as the areas of Carnwadric and Auldhouse. Giffnock station serves the town of Giffnock. The station is on a road known as Station Road, which is just off the A77/Fenwick Road, which is used as Giffnock's main street. Clarkston station serves the town of Clarkston. In 1971, a large explosion occured at the shops next to the station, killing 22 people and injuring over 100. Busby station, slightly further down the line, serves the village of Busby, whilst the following station, Thorntonhall, is often skipped by the train as the town it serves tends to have very few passengers. The following 2 stations are both part of the new town of East Kilbride, and the stations serve their local communities as well as the town as a whole. On the Barrhead branch, the first station after Pollokshaws West is Kennishead, which serves the area of Kennishead, where there used to be 5 blocks of flats, but 2 of them were recently demolished. The next station is Priesthill and Darnley, which actually does a pretty awful job at serving the entire town of Darnley, given how far Southpark Village has expanded. Although, many people say Southpark Village is its own town. The next station is Nitshill, which serves the town of Nitshill, obviously. After this is Barrhead, which serves the town of Barrhead. There are more stations further down this line, but frankly I can't be bothered.

As a perimeter station on the Glasgow suburban zone, this station is well used, and is almost at capacity at peak times. Frequent services all day, manned ticket office, limited hours coffee kiosk, and large free car park. Unfortunately Croy needs massive upgrading, it’s not a village station, but a busy commuter mainline station. Car park is frequently full to over capacity, with cars parking in inappropriate places, as well as other drivers forced to start filling up the village streets. Travellers may have to allow 10-15 minutes to find a space. This station requires a multi storey, passenger numbers will continue to increase, inline with more homes being built adjacent. It requires a footbridge at the western end, easing access to the car parks. Waiting room is a match box size for the amount of passengers, and there should be overhead shelter down the length of BOTH platforms for protection from the frequent poor weather. Customer satisfaction and experience could be massively enhanced at this station.

This is a good station if you are connecting to a LNER train. Otherwise, there can be problems with the accuracy of the display boards. I was travelling recently and booked into Coach A (First Class) on a CrossCountry train. The information board showed coaches 1 to 9 (numbers and not letters) with First Class in Coaches 1 and 9. Station staff were unable to tell me if Coach A was at the front or the back of the train. I was advised to wait near the front. On arrival of the train, I was told that Coach A was at the back. So, I ran down the train, with heavy luggage, only to be told that Coach A was in the middle!! Eventually, I arrived at the correct coach, exhausted, only to be berated by train staff for keeping the train waiting!!! I am sure LNER staff will put the blame on CrossCountry Staff for the confusion and vice-versa. That's life these days.

Firstly keep in mind this is just a platform and not really a station, so don't expect much in the way of facilities.  That said, what is there is clean and feels safe so no complaints.
Gret little station. Yes do make sure you're in the right platform!!
I think we are very lucky that this little railway was saved by the intervention of many people one being Barbara Castle

A very bad experience at this station. Not worth even a quarter of a star.
There are only 29 demarcated parking bays, 1 disabled bay & a demarcated motor cycle area.
Despite arriving at the station in plenty of time, there was NO parking space open for me to park in! I then tried the actual station side, and parked in a space where I was not blocking any accesses, there were no "NO PARKING" signs, no paint markings on the ground, or signage stipulating that I was not entitled to leave my car there.
When I arrived back 2 hours later, my car had been forcibly moved, using a forklift, by an employee of one of the tenants there. 
As a result, my car was damaged. The forklift "fork" not only scraped the undercarriage, but went straight into the shock absorber, causing it to buckle, rendering it totally unsafe on the road. 
Pictures of my car were taken at the garage, a report written & the police notified.
So altogether a very bad, costly and time consuming experience!
Quaint but make sure you're on the right platform well before the train arrives!!!

Basic station with frequent trips to Lowestoft and Ipswich. Can be a tight squeeze for parking if picking up or setting down someone for the train. If coming from the North, be aware that you could get stuck on the wrong side of the barriers if you aren't there before the train is.

The platforms here feel dangerously narrow, especially platforms 3 and 4. I'd dread to imagine how busy it would be during the rush hour. The station has step free access via decently big lifts and there's a decent variety of train services serving here. The ticket office was closed at 11am on a Monday when I was there and the station only had two ticket machines inside the ticket hall. Other facilities like toilets and seating are available here.
Richards met Jagger here so this station is indeed to thank for the creation of the Rolling Stones
A good station use daily , always helpful friendly staff
Some people, lots of people I’m sure, have no idea how to lift a toilet seat. Every time I’ve used the station toilet the seats were covered in pish.

Overstaffed with useless employees, they have no clue, if you look for one of them to ask before u miss your train you never find and when u change platform u see them all chatting!! No customer service skulls. Same thing everywhere in any station where southeastern train operate
Although Darton has a deceptively large population of 14 thousand plus, the village itself is small. With two parks to walk alongside the river Dearne.
This is home. Lovely walks. Good for commuting. Friendly atmosphere.
Nice day out for tea & lunch and a good walk.
Was a great traditional station at one time, with proper waiting and utility rooms, but just simple bus type shelters now while waiting for the train
Car park always full. Rather windy on platforms at any time.
Gotta live somewhere

Always collect and drop-off people visiting me by train from London from this station instead of Windsor. Less busy, plenty of parking and no need to pay for parking if just staying a short time as car park right next to platform.

Such a rubbish station. A single shelter on each platform which seldom protects you from the weather, minimal seating and a ticket office which is only open in the mornings. There are no other facilities provided other than a payphone but at least both platfroms provide step free access.
A wayside halt with a couple benches to sit on to wait for the train.
Awful. They keep the gates down 5 minutes before a slow moving train pulls up
Lovely little station with great access to Manchester.
A historic and unusual railway station on the scenic Hope Valley Line. Steam trains pass through occasionally.

A good train station however it is very small. Only two platforms and the ticket office isnt regularly open. The station is pretty though and has an indoor waiting room on one platform. 3 trains to Manchester every hour on weekdays which is good.
Small busy station. Unmanned most of the time. Limited parking.
peng

Again, this stretch of railway has been flooded.....What damage has been caused has yet to be determined.....A high tide, on shore 'Force 10' winds, soaked some of those people waiting + watching.....Well, float in some reinforced concrete pontoons, sink them off shore to dissapate the huge waves....Build a 'granite lagoon', whilst creating electricity, with turbines in the structure, again dissapating the force of the sea in these frequent high tide storms of the winter months.....Concrete  wave control, curved walls that redirect the waves back out to sea, which you can see at other locations around the world........Extending the railway, further out to sea will cost £300 million, which means the 'huge waves' will be closer + might even derail a train, creating a dangerous scenario for emergency services trying to secure the safety of passengers on the wave washed train......" This lovely little stop on the Brunel designed coastal railway deserves a mention. 

A great deal of public money was spent relaying the track along this line which is one of the most scenic routes in England. 

This stop offers easy access to the town of Dawlish with its famous black swans and gardens.

At times of bad weather the train can be seen braving the spray from waves as it makes its way along the line here. 

Just up the track at the tunnel toward Teignmouth is a brilliantly executed Banksy like piece of wall art of a boy with a catapult.

Good connections to the Warren and the Sea Wall towards Dawlish, but facilities incredibly lacking. Infrequent service, few parking spaces and cross-platform transfers requiring you to leave the station, pass beneath the railway through a very narrow road tunnel, and then reenter the station.

For more frequent services, I'd recommend travelling to Dawlish - it's only an extra four minute journey.
Quiet place lovely walks and nice few pubs with nice food.beach clean and can easily get to places to visit on train or by car and nice walk into dawlish town.

Friendly and clean. Typical seaside venue. Ideal for kids especially when weather is good. A bit hilly for cycling with youngsters and there is a distinct lack of cycle pathways which is a real shame. Otherwise pretty average holiday town!
A basic station with fairly regular GWR services. Montreal station facilities.
Could no praise the staff enough we travelled with a wheelchair and the staff at Dawlish Warren, Exeter st David's, and Exeter central were amazing thank you
Great station with a lot of history
Deal railway station is near the centre of Deal and is located next to Sainsbury's car park.
Bill was very helpful and patient as I had a difficult journey ahead
Nice small quiet town next to the sea :)
...or no deal.
Handy for hopping onto Metrolink across bridge from station
Great experience  with Manchester arena
Great transport connections with both Metrolink and train services using station. Good location for commuters accessing the city and beyond
Bit cold but the lady on the platform was v. helpful
The staff on the entrance saw that I was going to buy a ticket online, they advised me to buy it with them. The ticket they sold me was 7.5 £ more than what I would have bought online.
Not a bad station ....big stairs mind no good for wheelchairs
what on earth have they done to the seats? Elderly person could not sit down as the seats are slanted downwards.  Dreadful. Why?

I was playing hide and seek with my friend and I was hiding in the wardrobe. As he walked into the room I slowly starting walking towards the back, it was a very deep wardrobe. I heard my friend leave the room so I walked back towards the front, where I saw a faint light through the gap between the doors. As I opened the doors to make my escape, I was taken aback as I realised I had somehow ended up on Platform 2 at Dorking (Deepdene). Can confirm the station is rather magical and definitely worth a visit either via train or enchanted furniture.

This station is currently receiving an update... new shelters, CCTV, new bike racks and new ticket machines. The steps to the platforms may prove tricky for the less mobile and inaccessible for disabled individuals. Also tricky if you're carrying a bike with racks & bags. It would be lovely if there was a lift or ramp.
95% of the time the ticket machine doesn't work so either plan enough time to buy your tickets from Dorking Main or expect there to be a guard on the train, but good luck with that.
Not a bad place

Nice small branch line station that connects llandudno junction to llandudno town.  

Very scenic little place with views over the Conwy estuary to the castle.
Simple beautiful!

This is a small railway station and the only stop on the short branch line that connects Llandudno Junction to Llandudno.  There are reasonably frequent services but it's a request stop so if you're on a train and want to get off here make sure you ask the guard in advance and if you're on the platform wanting to catch a train make sure you stand somewhere on the platform where the driver will spot you.

This is a fairly basic railway station, which allows passengers to take train journeys either towards Huddersfield, or towards Leeds in the opposite direction.

It's seen as basic because, there is no car parking facility, there is no bike rack, and there is no electronic signage to indicate when trains might be arriving. Also, there are no staff on site, and there is no way that any passenger can buy a ticket here.

What does it have? It has two platforms, and on each platform there is a passenger shelter (with some basic seating in it), and that's about it. Because there is no electronic signage, passengers have to rely upon a tannoy System indicating whether trains will be stopping (or whether passengers should stand well back from the platforms as fast trains rush on past the railway station platforms).
Great for recreational activities. Often visit. With some great walks.

This railway station sits on the line that heads towards Huddersfield in one direction and towards Sheffield in the other direction.

There is a nearby car park that can accommodate about 8 or 9 cars. 

Yes there is one space for a disabled driver.

And yes there is a drop-off area as well.

This railway station has only one platform, and it also only has one railway line passing through it.

There are a number of areas where people can sit down and wait for the train. Some of these seating areas are covered as well.

There are no on-site staff here and consequently there is a automatic ticketing machine on the platform.

This railway station also has a bicycle rack and can accommodate about 2 or 3 bicycles at best.

There are visible signs of security at this platform by way of closed-circuit television cameras.

I only decided to give this railway station three stars out of five because the station signage from my perspective wasn't great. In fact when I went into to the entrance (that I thought was the entrance), it confused me because I ended up going up some old dirt track which lead to nowhere.
Great thing I love it I got a dinosaur for free !!!!
Great Station! Been going for years. It was my local, but isn't any more. There needs to be more there that's all.
Fantastic station , very well kept
Denham is good very good station,, it has connection to Birmingham & London via chiltern railway. london padding with great western, and then central london and essex at the central line

A fantastic station , spoilt ,  complete with 1940s waiting rooms

 I afterwards learned they have a 1-way system in operation so I was in the wrong but don't their staff have voices? 

A simple, 'Sorry Sir, please go that way!' would have completely changed this situation. As it was, it was very unsatisfactory!

The station is located in a good location, near the King's College Hospital and the new bridge provided a new exit with lifts giving step free access. However, they closed the old entrance through the old footbridge meaning that the flow of passengers through here can be incredibly constricted. Very stupid if you ask me. Services are varied enough through here, served by Southeastern, Overground and Thameslink.

a station practically insignificant, scarce indications, staff constantly absent, but unfortunately a station in which one must necessarily pass to reach victoria, continuous stops waiting for trains that never pass the night in true nightmare, even 20 minutes of waiting with the doors open with a climate often glacial, inevitable if you then travel with the southeastern trains, the pathetic and ridiculous excuses to justify the daily delays, sometimes (I think out of shame) also avoid making announcements, so as to remain for a long time waiting but without any reason
trains are cool i guess
Shame 🙁 Staff is very very rude...itc.

Being the highest station in England, can get pretty windy & rainy, so wrap up well. But being on the Settle to Carlisle line, tourists are catered for better than normal Network rail stations; plenty of info., local buses run from here, station upkeep much better than non FoSCL stations.
Is there anywhere in the whole of these British isles as beautiful as this area. Difficult to get to by road but well worth the journey to this highest station in England, fabulous.
Just passed thro here last Saturday, behind 46233. Stunning views.
One of the Best station I've been too
Until the day when the residents get a proper service, better than one train a week in one direction, it will be a worthy quarry for Parliamentary train service enthusists

great clean station with lots of staff to help. toilets are clean and there's a few shops and cafes.    trains to most big cities in the region except manchester
Clean platforms. Some platforms have waiting rooms, but overall there is very little seating. Roofing is under renovation on one platform. They do have a cafe though.

It's a Good train station for Trainspotting Also There is lots of Places to go on the Trains like Matlock,Sheffield,London St pranas, Birmingham New Street,Cardiff cental,Doncaster,Newcastle,York.But Why are they Two Trains company's East Midlands and Crosscrounty Why can they be more?

14 year old daughter was travelling alone for the first time . Staff (think called Alia) let me through the barrier when I explained and also showed /explained to daughter all about the tickets  and had her using the barriers so she knew what to do .

Whilst the station is located in a good location on the other side of Ipswich, services here are much less than desirable. 

The station has no shelter whatsoever to shield from the sun or rain, trains stop here approximately every hour and are formed of one or two coaches, no announcements and the help point on the Ipswich platform was faulty.

I'm grateful for the station having recently added step free access via ramps down to the platforms and the ticket machine accepts both cash and card payments but everything is is pretty sub par.
I really like Derby road, situated in the lovely tranquil area of Ipswich. Love seeing the monsters at 23:59:59. Pure American power!
A beautiful little railway station where you can find supreme amarican locomotion at its best.  You might even find a Jono. Quite and peaceful, it sits in the deckilicouse area of the world.
Easy accessible. Located in mid of town
Accessable and easy. Good infomation about times when i was there
Use the station almost daily for my commute in and out of Plymouth. Station ok but trains not frequent at all. Convenient that its there, though.

Really helpful and an efficient service from those working at dewsbury train station. Resolved an issue I had very quickly and professionally. 

Thank you to the staff who helped get my bag back to me and sending it on the next train to the airport :) (had my passport in meaning we could get on our flight after all!)
very nice

Undergoing renovations currently in winter, not sure why they decided to do this but this has meant, waiting rooms on one side of the platform are closed. Sadly, no toilets at this station but there is a pub that has them, not much use if you're catching an early train. There is also a small confectionery shop and a manned ticked desk.
Thanks very much Bob who works here, for getting my coat back after I left it on the train to Paddington!

Convenient for Sandy Park. Basic, but does everything it needs to!
Basic single track station with minimal facilities

No security cameras around. Seats limited.
Worst station to leave you vehicle parked
Excellent station that is easy to navigate.
Nice enough station. Wheelchair accessible. No toilets or parking though. Departure boards.  Help button. All weather covered seating. Ticket machine.
Ok.

Dingle road railway station can be reached via West Terrace or over the railway bridge from Windsor road. There is no parking as dingle road had resident parking restrictions.   All trains go either into Penarth or Cardiff where you can change for main line or local destinations.
Seemed to be a very run down halt of a station with basic shelter, a ticket machine and trains every half hour or so. The station is on an inclination so take care.

I don't get trains here so I will just rate on appearances. 1 platform, departure board. Cover for rainy days.  No toilets. Ticket machine to pay at. No car parking that I can tell. Press button info/distress call machine.  It's a well hidden station and you would not know it is here  as you have to go down a ordinary street of houses to reach it. Quiet area that I can see. Ramp for wheel chairs.
Badly served. Many trains delayed. The Penarth railway station is not far away, which renders this station fairly useless since it is not even linked to the Cogan train station (i.e. Barry line).
much depress
Only the station side platform is wheelchair accessible. Beware!

This train station is well located for Dingwall town centre. The old station buildings survive and you can buy tickets for onward travel. The station has historic significance in that a plaque commemorates the Ross and Cromarty Red Cross who served 134, 864 cups of tea during the war years. Another plaque commemorates the Jellico Express which stopped here regularly. It was named after Admiral Sir John Jellicoe it was a Royal Navy train carrying personnel between London and Thurso during both wars. The memorial is dedicated to the men and women who travelled and worked on the train.

Lovely old fashioned station. Cafe is great during daytime. Good for lunch or just a quick drink. Good views of tracks for children interested in the trains. During the evening the pub serves nice meals at reasonable prices.

Clean cared for station which actually  caters for its passengers.Lovely cafe and also a nice  pub.Why can't  all stations have a few amount of the  basic facilities  like covered clean waiting areas and clean toilets plus non corperate good and drink facilities.This is almost like a station on a Heritage Line-That's how good it is.

Years since visited, but look out for the brass plaque on the platform near the station entrance (visible on 1st photo) that commemorated the number of cups of tea served to servicemen & women during the First Word War.

Pleasant country station with pleasant, fairly open aspect despite the surrounding greenery, but suffers from the problem common to unstaffed stations of not having fully enclosed and heated waiting shelters to keep passengers warm in cold weather. Trains every half hour in each direction (except Sundays), though services run through to Bishop Auckland rather than stopping at Darlington only once an hour. Long ramps down to platforms from the adjacent road bridge.
Beautiful quiet train station lovely place to wait for a train
Helpful staff when on duty.
Great spooky little station with some lovely atmospheric semi derelict buildings on the former platform. Those still in use are well maintained & when it’s staffed the staff are lovely.

Free parking available here, but only on a first come first served basis and if you are going to travel by train. There aren't many spaces, so either you intend to catch one of the very early services into Manchester Monday to Saturday or you're thinking of travelling on Sunday. Ticket office is open Mondays to Fridays only. Buy your tickets from the guard Saturday and Sunday. Take care getting on and off the train because there's a huge gap between the platform edge and the carriage.
Good station, no ticket machine and not always staffed.
Small station with good connections to Manchester.

This railway station sits on the line between Stockport in one direction, and Whaley bridge in the other direction.

There are quite a number of places to park your car car in and around the railway station. Parking seems to be free here.

There is definitely no signs of a bike rack here.

There is also no obvious signs of security in terms of any closed circuit television cameras in (or around) this railway station. 

When you want to buy a ticket for a train journey, you can either buy one from the automated electronic ticketing, or if you want to do, you can buy a ticket from the on-site staff.

This particular railway station does have a digital board indicating when trains are likely to arrive here.

There are two platforms at this railway station. One is accessed directly from the car park whilst the other is accessed via a footpath and a footbridge over the railway line.

This railway station does have seating of which some of it is sheltered if you  need to sit down when the weather is somewhat rather inclement.
Good station with good access

Was just a visitor passing by.
Diss station is an example of how other stations should be maintained.

Great CCTV and futuristic arrival/departure screens, and there are seperate LCD clocks  installed rather then checking the time on the information screens.
Nice and quiet
Nice little station, friendly and helpful staff

Diss train station has great staff, a traditional ticket office and platform, with decent waiting rooms, especially on platform 1, which is equipped with power sockets and comfortable seating including sofas.

Out of hours when the ticket office is closed an automatic ticket machine is available on each platform. A coffee shop is located on platform 1 along with a handy Royal Mail post box.

With trains to London in 90 minutes, very happy to have Diss as my local station.

Diminutive single platform halt with disused signal box and abandoned level crossing at one end. No staff onsite and trains generally only run once an hour in either direction, though there is an extra service towards Sheffield at the teatime every day except Sunday. However if you have to travel on the Sabbeth you could be in for a very long wait of over 2 hours. There is an adjoining car park, but in keeping with the size of the station this literally has the capacity for only a handful of vehicles.
Beautiful

Basic station with a small enclosed shelter and a departures board.

I had a connection as Doncaster with a cycle reservation. The platform staff where very helpful and went out of their way to help my with my bike and get me to the right platform. This is nice as often I feel 2nd class as a cyclist travelling on public transport, but not here! Thank you

Train to Leeds changed platform 2 times, it started at platform 6, then to platform 0 and lastly platform 7 in a span of 5 minutes. Going one end of the station to the other which made me miss my connection. 

Please don't do that again, I felt really sorry for this guy who was practically running to get to platform 0 from 6 and then they changed it back to 7.

I know it's a very busy station but please try to be considerate when moving trains to different platforms.
Melanie in the ticket office was very helpful and worked out the best deal for me and my partner...thank you Melanie

Truly awful experience, loud mouthed female bully of a platform manager shouted out incorrect/conflicting instructions, insisted on sending the train on its way before speaking to me, then said "Oh it was not me, you should have got on that train", when I protested, said "you're threatening me and said that I would be prevented from travelling..." eventually got a station manager to provide me with alternative travel documentation!!!.

The next train is to Doncaster on Platform 0. Please listen to this info. There is the Frenchgate Centre attached to it with Ecodisc lifts, but the lifts here are boring. Please mind the gap. Mind the gap.
A simple small station from which you can get a service to London Waterloo.

Great station very clean very organised central to Dorchester Town Centre like it very much staff are always very helpful bit of trouble tonight late night Revellers handle very quickly can't ask nothing more than that can you excellent
Railway station

Dump. Out of order toilets, naturally. Ticket machine only offers 10 destinations! - bizarre. Cramped, dreary waiting area, just 6 seats.  Quite a contrast to the plush, smiley retail centre on the other side of the car park. An object lesson in two extremes of respect for customers.

Built on a curve of track, this station and its waiting room are always busy but neglected. So much more could be made of this historic building and it is a pity it remains a pale shadow of its former glory. A mud track has been worn into the bank in front of the ticket office, where commuting footfall has established a shortcut which avoids the path.

I've never, that's NEVER, had my shoelaces tampered with and because they remained in one piece whilst I waited for my train, I find it difficult to fault the platform. Would have been five stars if I had been able to see an interesting keyring

Unmanned station on the Heart of Wessex Railway line between Bristol Temple meads and Weymouth (87 miles long), and known very much as the "Cinderella Line" - with 8 trains a day in each direction and a better service now on Sundays

Being unmanned means that there is not even a ticket machine - so buy your ticket on the train unless you have pre-purchased it (have it sent to you by post or on your phone or collect at any manned station - the machine telling you about next train might or might not be working - this station is run currently by GWR

If you want a regular service to Weymouth use Dorchester South (run by SWT - a 10 - 15 minute walk away and is signposted 

It is a very clean station now and this is done by a team of regular volunteers on a regular basis (see posters at the station)
Very clean unmanned station what is there to say trains stop trains go.
No ticket machine
Trolol

Make sure you take your best game to the ticket office where no opportunity to demonstrate superciliousness will be missed by the ticket office staff who are surely slumming it when they could be running the Royal Household. Barrier staff however are very decent.

Stroppy staff, couldn't get a coffee because the woman serving was talking to her friend. One of the people working there was getting really rude when helping a small group of elderly tourists because it wasn't clear what platform they had to be on. Train didn't leave on time. Late, rude and uncaffeinated.
It is so big
Nice little station, it's like the staff and the customer knew each other with how they converse
A modern railway station on the scenic Mole Valley Line. Steam trains pass through occasionally.

This is quite a nice station which has comfortable seating and a bike rack with a cover. It only has half of the services that the nearby Dorking Deepdene station and is also tucked away behind a car wash in an industrial estate.

As a transport service it's of little use -no car parking, and a limited catchment area. However, this used to be the town's main station and I remember the impressive buildings being demolished in the Seventies. The subway survives, surprisingly.
Lovely quiet little station well served by the excellent GWR diesel trains that are almost always on time.

Important departure point if you live in the Guildford end of Dorking Town. 

Not well signposted and hidden away behind some light Industrial units. If approaching on Station Road accessed by a narrow passageway.  

Covered seating on both Platforms. Platform lights were updated recently, so at least well lit. Some covered bicycle racks available. 

Infrequent services (often late), not manned and no Ticket Machine, but generally in good repair.
An attractive historic railway station on the scenic Oxted Line.

Seems to be a nice and small station with both intercity and local trains stopping here. Step free access is available here via lifts on the footbridge as well as seating, toilets and shelter for the rain. 

No ticket barriers are here but there are ticket machines and a ticket office with friendly staff.

Do take care when boarding trains here. The gap and step down is insane.

This is a attractive station with good amenities and offers useful services between Birmingham and London. It is often not staffed, however, even in peak times, meaning no ticket office or waiting rooms. There have recently been problems with the ticket machine too. So allow time for queues if you need to buy a ticket and be prepared to stand out in the cold.

Beautiful little station which is situated in the centre of the village. Also for a little bit of history. It was first named Knowle, then Knowle and Dorridge then Dorridge. Nice little cafe for refreshments and a old day waiting room. Also the local station for the people of Knowle and Bentley Heath (serving the area of KDBH)
The station ticket master was most helpful...thanks for your help with sorting out my ticket today. Best customer service!
Always good coffee and cake and biscuits for Molly our dog

Dove holes railway station, serves trains heading towards Buxton in one direction (or Stockport in the other direction).

This railway station has a small car park (on the Buxton bound platform side) which is also shared by nearby residents and also by trucks and vehicles from the nearby scrap merchant. Even so, there is still room for about 3 cars to park here although there is no designated area for disabled passengers.

The Buxton bound railway platform car park also has a bike rack that can accommodate about 4 or 5 bicycles.

There is no car park whatsoever on the Stockport bound railway platform side.

There are no digital displays to indicate oncoming trains. Instead, people must rely upon the timetables that are found on both platforms, although there is a help desk button if required on both platforms.

There are no signs whatsoever of any closed circuit television in the vicinity. Both platforms do seem to have a speaker although they weren't working when I was there.

Both platforms do have a covered seating area, and there is also a telephone to be found in.the covered seating area on the Buxton bound platform side.

Passengers wanting to board the train at dove holes would have to buy the ticket on board the train as there are no ticket machines available here.

Trains that do run through dove holes railway station, seem to be run by the northern Railway company.
A good big station. Space to sit inside away from the cold. Would be nice if was a bit more cosy. Coffee shop has limited opening hours. Southeastern staff at station which is great.
Nice station. Clean. Not too crowded either.

Nice enough station, staff were brilliant when I lost my wallet (plus ticket) - didn't get it back but they made a real effort. Has all the basic amenities - toilets, cafe and vending machines. Only waiting room with heating is on platform 1 - the others have to do with a basic shelter.
Been there in 1997. Good transport and convenient price fast and reliable timing.

Nice clean station, waiting room is warm, staff are really friendly and the waiting room is lovely ready for Christmas it's great to see abit of effort. The only thing I would change is the price of a cuppa
No ticket office closed few months ago. Ticket mechanic is rubish best to buy on the train.
An amazing place to be I loved every moment

A station in the middle of nowhere with beautiful views. No facilities of any kind except a shelter.

Downham Market is a lovely, clean and friendly town which offers more than you need. Good Pubs and lots of other excellent restuarants to choose from. Close to big shopping centres for days out AND on a direct line to London.What more do you want, other than good company, wich is your own responsibility.

Speakers don't work properly and the station is a bit dirty.

It's a station that has no wheel chair access. 
Been there for a long time and shows its age.
Wet windy days are no fun ,especially as recently there have been many delays and cancelled trains.
Convenient for train to Moor gate.

The new station is fantastic! It’s very modern and bright. There are now seats in the street level foyer next to the ticket office and the taxi rank is right next to the side entrance/exit. The V&A and city centre are only a few minutes walk away and the station is served by the numbers 42, 54, 77, 99 and 360 buses. The also new ScotRail waiting room is good too with plenty seats but could do with a few more plugs for charging. The platforms are light and airy but sheltered enough for waiting outside. The coffee shop is a welcome addition too! I have found it to be quite dirty later in the day but much cleaner in the mornings but I guess that’s what happens at busy stations.

Staff here are always polite and helpful. I’ve used the station on a daily basis in the past and have never had any problems. It’s not mainline so buffet is no open long hours. It serves the morning commute and into the afternoon but is shut in the evenings. The ticket office is staffed until last trains have passed through and there is a self serve machine on platform one. There is usually one or two car parking spaces available throughout the day and the main car park is accessed from Woodmill Road. There is a car park with about 40 spaces on the Queen Margaret side (this is a one way road) and you will find taxis on this side too. The station is served well by taxis and there are bus stops a short distance away on QM Drive which operate to and from the City Centre. If you don’t mind the Hill, the city centre is ten minutes walk and start by going through the underpass. Then turn either left or right to find your way up hill to the town.

The width of the single island platform, albeit a relic of former times when the station was somewhat busier, might be mistaken as a sign that it has pretensions of grandeur as this is a very basic unstaffed station with minimal facilities that are not much to boast about – there's a small bike rack and open waiting shelter but that's about it. Wheelchair users might struggle on the long ramp down to the platforms from the road bridge at the western end of the station which is the only access point and there's no car park, although there is usually space in the streets nearby. The bridge and trees to south of the station give it a dark and slightly oppressive atmosphere, particularly in summer. Sadly, though not unsurprisingly perhaps, it is little used.

I arrived from KX to Eaglescliffe on Thursday 18 January afternoon. A lot of snow had fallen. The train guard before given the arrival announcement, said to us he was surprised that the platform hadn’t been gritted as there had been considerable snow fall.

As I walked through the slippery snow and met my friend who was collecting me, we I looked and were shocked to see that the steep incline walk-way, Bridge, and decline walk way had not been cleared or at least gritted. The walk ways were lethal, almost making it impossible to leave the station.

I enquired of the men in the ticket office as to why it was’nt gritted, their reply was “it wasn’t their responsibility but the company thar has just gone bust”. Surely station health & safety wasn’t being adhered to that British Rail would have been liable if there had been a serious fall.

I’m concerned about my return journey from Eaglescliffe and would like to know whether the walkways have been treated and the platform, for safety,

If you can email me that would be reassuring.

R Bertie

A much-improved railway station over the last year or so. This station is currently undergoing renovation and a refit for new businesses, coming soon to the site. The car park has just recently been surfaced and operates a number plate recognition system. The car park meters no longer take cash, but do accept card payments and mobile app payments are in place. There are new ticket machines on the concourse, re-sited to near the ticket barriers. There is a WH Smith mini-shop, a Subway sandwich shop, Bella’s coffee shop with indoor and outdoor seating on the concourse, a barbers, a new ticket office and a NHS walk-in centre clinic, open until 8pm Monday to Sunday. The old AMT Coffee kiosk has sadly gone, but Bella’s makes fab coffee and sells rolls, sandwiches, light meals and snacks. A Costa coffee bar is outside the station, across the road, and is part of the new Beacon Shopping Centre. One word of warning though; the cash machines or ATMs are no longer free. Run by a company called Cashline, the two machines inside the station will charge you £1.99p per cash withdrawal. Oddly, there is a free-standing ATM in nearby Grove Road, which is another Cashline machine. Until very recently, this machine was free to use for withdrawals, but now it is charging 95p per cash withdrawal. So you can beat this provider at their own game, the nearest free cash machine for withdrawals has just recently appeared. As you exit the new entrance at the rear of the station, turn left and walk over to the dry cleaners on the corner. There you will find an ATM embedded in this shop’s window. It’s totally free for debit cards and Link cards. Enjoy!

My experience of using this pop up cafe hasn’t been great. 

Iced coffee is one of the most basic drinks to make. Any milk of your choosing and then the coffee poured on top after settling to ensure the coffee doesn’t taste bitter. Each day this week I’ve ordered the soya option. 

Each time the server makes the drink there’s a problem. This could be because he uses cows milk first or even pours the ingredients into the drink the wrong way around, and for any coffee fans we know how bitter the coffee can taste if pouring incorrectly. If I had a dairy intolerance I’d be taking this further!

I’m now drinking my iced coffee and yet again on the 5th time this week, it’s bitter. Thanks team. 

PS. Your manager made it correctly for you twice and also showed others members of your team. This is in no way a bad report about lower management and more a review about what barista’s have been put in place. At least hire those that have an interest in cafe’s or a want to work and do things right first time. 

Maybe the appropriate course of action would be to train those on your team.

I’ll be sticking with Costa!
Lit
It's ok but sadly let down by being a bit remote when trains are delayed or cancelled first thing in the morning. Staff are very understanding and helpful though
Is not a safe to get a train there
Well-refurbished station with park and ride facilities. Covered, though partially open waiting areas and footbridge with gentle stepped slope (not wheelchair-friendly).
Lovely place and staff. Trains are nice and warm! Also hardly any people so it is peaceful.
Nice Station but lacks toilet facilties.
Nice and convenient station. Excellent coffee bar with real coffee. And outside sits Charlotte Mary Yonge (1823–1901), English novelist
Fit for purpose

Lovely station. Easy to get to, never busy, clean and my train always arrived pretty much on time.
What more do you need!

This station is a gem, the staff are polite and helpful, the parking online is easy and cars are well protected. The boarding staff are polite, it's a wonderful station to return to after the hectic stations in France. Well done Ebbscross Dartford Kent.

Great place for a busy station it's quiet and calm. They've got a lot of plants and decoration and although a small station, it does the job well. Security is heavy but not intrusive and it just seems to be a place where you get the train, not full of hustle and bustle of other London stations
Very clean station, very light and airy building. For a station......so quiet! Maybe it was the time of day I visited??

Very unhelpful. Refund refused because it was “in the morning.”Then in the evening ticket office shut for half an hour for coffee break . Absolutely hopeless  jobs worth traditional British Rail attitude .

Beautiful stream to cross. Clean with a car park. Seating but not under cover. No toilets. Wheelchair accessible.  Departure boards. No ticket office. Google tried to take long way round. Follow parking signs for station

A quite station at the valley side of wales.  You get train to cardiff.  An hour journey will take you through the mind blowing sceneries of the valley side cardiff in wales.  United kingdom. Not much crowded.  You can take the ticket either from the also.  Will reach queen street in an hour.
The station has very few trains. There's no railway staff or any services near the station.
Excellent
Google maps took me wrong way and i dont know how to report  it. I hope the photos help. Clean. Car park. Ticket machine. All weather cover. Departure boards.  Wheelchair accessible.

The journey up the valley from Cardiff was lovely. Trees & hills.
Only the decline of Ebbw Vale itself was sad. Closed down shops to let. Dozens of them. It's the world we live in.
Arriva Trains really don't care much for this place. Never enough carriage, rarely cleaned and good luck with the ticket machine.
Did you know this was the 1st railway  line from Manchester to Liverpool built in 1830 what's still used
Run of the mill middle of nowhere station. Nice new booking office. Friendly staff.not a lot you can say really. Good service to Victoria and Liverpool
It's well-maintained and the services are usually on time. The downsides are that the service is usually only hourly and there's no access aside from steps.
yes the services for trams and buses are good you can get to where you want to go eccles would be nothing without them
A basic railway station on the Liverpool to Manchester Railway. It would be better if they extended the Metrolink to terminate/go beyond here.

A beautiful and peaceful place to go on a trek. You have amazing valley views throughout, you can walk in areas surrounded by sheep and cows admiring the nature's beauty. Would love to visit this place again.
Nice train station , and its  not a  far walk  from the nearby campsites too.

The oldest continually running passenger station in the world! And wouldn't you know it.

I bought 2 single tickets by self tickets machine in Edge Hill Station.
I paid for them,but the machine didn't give me the tickets.
I had to buy 2 tickets again in the office and I tried to take my money back with no luck.
I want my money!!!¡ I feel robbed by this company.

Very rude man in ticket office. 1st day in area, 1st time in station going to Manchester, 6.15 am, pitch black, no signs to say which platform is which, no electronic display signs to announce destination of trains, so I could work out which platform I needed for myself. Man on phone in ticket office,chatting. When asked which platform do I need he sweeps his arm in front of him 'round there' whilst still chatting. I go 'round there' and only find a padlocked Gate - perhaps he means go back to the road and there's another entrance on the other side of the road?? Worried I'd miss my train, I go back in 'where sorry?'. 'ROUND THERE!! (Throwing arms wildly around whilst still chatting). I go back outside in pitch black certain I'd miss my train. 
A lovely customer came past and gave me the directions I needed because the gate the guard was trying to get me to use was padlocked. Apparently, an alternative route was round the back of the office. 
Perhaps you could have signposts or electronic signs if you can't find helpful (or pleasant) staff?

Tried to get a train home to Wavertree Technology Station at 5.30 pm today, Thursday 15/11/18.

What a big mistake!!!  

The first thing I noticed was no electronic board showing arrival of trains at what platforms. In the case of Edge Hill at least 5 to choose from!!
Looking at the written display boards I could only see details of in bound trains.
After 3 people asked me the same question I was asking myself, IE - Am I on the right platform for my train?  I became really worried, and after waiting 30 mins decided to leave and got a taxi home.
Needs information screens
It is really like an airport.. Keep eye on the screens, and if you have any connected trains make sure they are not cancelled. Because it happens. 🤨
Edinburgh waverly is certainly the busy station. Signage is good and staff are happy and friendly. They helped me with navigating my way back home!
Great, easy ticketing and access to train. Nice and clean station with plenty of places to rest, eat, and drink. Staff were pleasant.
Busy rail station which has been substantially redeveloped.  Good food outlets and sign posting.
Very convenience station and large also. There has fast food restaurant and some other store,like Mark and Spenser , boots...
Trains come and go, if infrequently, from this currently sparkling edifice of the modern (and we shall see how long that lasts). Could do with more benches and a cafe, or at least a vending machine.

A great connection for Fife and surrounding areas but disappointingly lacking in amenities such as a vending machine or coffee shop. The station was almost deserted at 12:30 on a Thursday and appears to be frequented by trains regularly but not used. Still shiny and new and the toilets were super clean.

As a foreign tourist I am extremely lyrical about this brand new train station. Perfectly located and connected by tram, basically one footstep from the entrance. Staffed, so can easily collect ordered online train tickets. Friendly and helpful staff. Location most ideal for travels to the scenic highlands, so won't have to go to Edinburgh central first. Station a few steps from large grocery store and shopping mall. Last but not least tram perfectly connected to airport and super convenient to pay for the fare with cash money. You guys really planned this well. Way to go! Be proud! This couldn't be done in my home country.
Useful station in you work at Edinburgh Park and live in Fife

A dystopian glass and corrugated iron temple to the soulless ‘nouveau gauche’ style of railway station construction. Whilst South Gyle offers a pleasing collaboration of concrete and floral splendour, Edinburgh Gateway is a disappointment, its stylings mired in cliche of Portakabin-inspired dourness.
One to avoid for all but the most jaded and world-weary of rail travellers.
Fantastic transport links to everywhere ,very clean platform . Friendly staff on the platform to answer any questions .

Very handy if you work in Edinburgh Park and South Gyle. Also good for Hermiston Gait retail park and the Uni. There's the tram stop right next to the station, if you need to get to the Airport or somewhere along the route to York Place where the train only goes to Haymarket and Waverley.
Very cold station without a toilet and lots of delays and cancellations. Handy for work though

Not much here. A few seats on the Glasgow bound side, more space on the Edinburgh bound side.
Beside the tram stop, so linked up there.
Also beside Germiston Gait retail park, a place to go when the trains don't arrive. Like now, while I'm writing the review.
Key issue is that only half of the trains stop here.
Apart from free wifi, nothing much to do here. Fast trains dont stop here much. So have to wait in odd hours

Great connection to central London via victoria line, seven sisters station, just 4 stops. As well as Liverpool street. However trains running 15mins apart. And peak hours you need to Scrambled in train if you lucky enough to get a room to get in.
Lindo predio.

A quiet and standard station with four trains an hour to Guildford and London and step free access from the Guildford bound platforms. Also has a ticket office open at some times.
Still can't believe this place exists. Effing amazing

Great station with good service.
Great place.  Remote yet great pub nearby
Muy buen servicio, muy puntual, bonito lugar para caminatas.
Great staff and service ,the station as a taxi rank just outside the main entrance too,all local taxi drivers with a great knowledge of the area.

If you're changing for the Barnes branch on a train coming from reading, change here rather than Staines or anywhere else. Unbelievable that there are no one star ratings. It needs one. Probably the ugliest station I've seen - but most stations on this line are ugly. The two little bridges look as if they should have been condemned years ago. Shocking

Quite busy on a Friday night, which is to be expected. Great service and everyone was friendly. 

I would suggest coming here for a full meal. We split this and it was the perfect amount to keep the engine running.
Great original British pub. Great burgers : try the Nicholson's beef burger... terrific!
Great food! Nice staff. I recommend the Ploughman's sharer board.
Bloody good.  Halloumi fries were the best I've ever had

Seriously fantastic food with perfect ambience and decor. The wife and I had to wait a hot minute for seats but were able to quickly grab drinks to hold us over until they were available. Smart and newly refurbished with metal seating in glass area at front. Drinks machines but no café facilities onsite. About 500 metres walk up gentle slope to Elgin town centre. Turn left as you walk out from Platform 1.

Trains to London and Hayes are usually every 15 minutes with the trams to Croydon being every 10 minutes respectively.
Love this station and love using it would honestly move near if i could

Trains usually on time. Services to Cannon St, Charing Cross, London Bridge. Interchange with teams to Croydon and bus services to Woolwich and south east London and Croydon/Purley Way. This station is quite most of the time, sitting room , ticket hall available but sometimes ticket machine is down

It was discusting to see how a worker in platform 1, a female worker, had shouted at a customer who only wanted to ask if this is his train. Yet she shouts to him to wait and then sends away the train that he wanted to ask about. No welcoming, no smiling, no helping. Poor bloke looked scared and confused...
If I would know this ponytail short woman's name, I would complain. If people don't want to work with people, they should be finding something more suitable for them. 
I thought station workers are here to help when we customers get confused with all the trains and stations.

The station at the very least has decent facilities such as toilets, a car park, ticket office and step free access to all platforms via a ramped subway. The staff on the station platform appear friendly and very helpful when approached, hence why I feel they deserve some stars,  However these dedictated and professional staff are being let down by those in the ticket hall.  When renewing my ticket today I was met with a young woman who clearly didn’t want to be on duty at 6:30 in the morning.  No greeting, no cheerful demeanour, and frankly no manners.  Her only priority was to chat to her colleagues.

Please not Ely ticket office staff: providing good customer service is part of your role.  Be cheerful and pleasant, and above all give undivided customer attention.  If you need any guidance on how it should be done, visit the ticket hall in Norwich station.

Every single employee of Southern and any rail union members should be sacked immediately. The rail service is not fit for purpose.

Great station, you can get free books and you can give them back your book or donate them your book. Nice cafe on the platform to central London also there is a waiting room at the trains to London. On the other platform is basic couple of seats and a roof. Really nice plants at the around the station as well.

Excellent service consistently from Brendan and Grace and the other lovely chap that doesn’t smile much (Ian?). Community bookshelf is a fantastic idea I have taken and deposited books there and it’s a great place to see and speak to like minded readers! Thanks for making the station so homely. And when the trains are down, the staff always provide up to the minute information so that I can continue my journey.

The one star is for the short haired Nigerian looking woman. I was stuck coming out of the station as I lost my oyster on the train and I pressed the bell next to the gates it did not work so I called out. The woman said something from the front desk and carried on texting on her phone. Five minutes later I called out again. She became angry and shouted at me. Then not long later she stormed out through the door, paused and shouted at me 'WHAT DO YOU WANT'. I  explained that I lost my oyster on the way and can't get through. She paused again and shouted at me 'JUST GO'  and opened the gate for me. I thanked her for it and went through. I did not confront her on her breach of conduct as I all I wanted to do was get through the gate and I got that and I did not want to deal with her behaviour she displayed against me at the time. It was like I disturbed her from her favorite TV show. The woman is a nutter. I don't know how they employed such a worthless cow. To think I let this scumbag of a woman treat me like that. There is a man working there who is wonderful  calm and good with commuters. He came out and the opened the gate for me when I was coming in with heavy luggage. He just saw me and came out and opened the gate. Such a nice person. I hope he gets promoted. People who deliver service like this man should not have to work with miserable people like that woman. By the way, people constantly jump over and go under the barriers without paying in front of staff. They do nothing.

Excellent customer service from Brendan and Enfield Chase station.  I wanted to buy a railcard and advance tickets for a journey. I had looked up the journey online before visiting the station, but Brendan advised me that it was better to change at a different station as it would give me more time to transfer, although I would actually be getting the same train to my destination.  Brendan checked various routes for me, to ensure the best changeover time and to make sure there was no difference in price between the various different options; he also advised me about the various different times where railcards/oystercards were valid for journeys, depending on the operators (underground, overground, buses, trains, etc).  Thank you!

10pm and I was stuck behind the gate because my ticket no longer scans even after I replaced it. Rang the bell for over 10 minutes and no answer. Luckily another lady let me use her pass or I would still be there. The ticket office lights were on but no one bothered to answer. As a season ticket holder, I shouldn't be made to go through such embarrassment. Either you fix your paper tickets or keep someone on duty.

Travelled saturday morning  October 19th 9.04 was assisted so well by the lady in the ticket office ,advised us of prices and the best for our party. Travelling with my friend in a wheelchair the lady assisted us on the train with the ramp and rang ahead to Liverpool street to advise them we were coming. The lady was so lovely - Thank you
Great access to central London and easy access to westfield in stratford. Great for daily commute to work if you live around this area.

Fairly minimal local station. Not the best place to wait in winter or at night but it is well lit and clean. Ramp access directly from the road to platforms on both sides makes dashing for a train or exiting the station a smooth and painless experience.

Station is located in a good spot, not too far away from the town centre and has ramps up to the platforms giving full step free access in both directions. A ticket office and ticket machine, which accepts cash or card payments is located on the Birmingham platform. The station was in the middle of repainting when I was there.

great place to get a train

Bus stop, just a short walk from Eridge Station.

Station is run by a two bit company, trains run late and there is a need for a station uplift for sure! ok train station

Very hard to get to the platform if you have a pushchair, staff don’t help either unless you ask and only do it if they have nothing else to do and sometimes no one is there. Generally well thought out layout but fairly basic amenities and soulless atmosphere. Large size of free car park, in attracting a corresponding number of commuters and thus contributing to overcrowding on trains, has perhaps made the station a victim of its own success.

Trains to/from Tweedbank are often overcrowded, with many two car units utilised, much different from the services offered when the line was reopened. Large bike rack, but a small hut for shelter with metal bum rests for comfort, which are horrendous in winter!
Station was clean and tidy. There is a covered waiting shelter in case of rain. Very handy to have a station here.

A really nice, dated building with clean toilets and a fun play park right outside. Trains are fairly common, and the station is very peaceful. :)

A surprisingly charming station. A fine stone Victorian building with a ticket office, a bistro and a garden to sit in...even a book exchange. The stationmaster is courteous. The station has a news agents and a coffee shop. There is a cash points at the front of the station along with ticket machines.  👍👍 There is always taxi's out the front . Brilliant staff really helpful. Lovely station, always clean.

Always sunny when you arrive in Glorious Devon. This station is a retro time capsule of wood, iron and ceramic tiles, all gently fading as nature reclaims the architecture.

Great little station that's under appreciated (which I like, so not many people use it). Great way to start a day in Exeter ... Get off here and it's an easy walk to the quay for lunch, go up hill past the Roman wall to the Cathedral ... spend the day in the city and walk back via all the great little independent shops on Fore St and New Bridge St back (great coffee shops) to the station. A small station with minimal features. On the Paignton side there is a new information board detailing the trees around St Thomas which is nice. On the Exmouth side there are two bug hotels and a large amount of rock plants for insects. Ideally could do with more seats / benches.

I did give this 3 stars but my past few experiences have not been great. Every time it’s a school holiday, nice weather or some event FGW always fail. FGW are very luck to have such a beautiful stretch of railway along the coast and they ruin it with poor planning and frequent excuses. I missed my train connection on Bank Holiday Monday due to the incorrect times printed on my ticket for the replacement buses to make my Salisbury Train connection to Devon via Westbury!

 The bus stopped away from the station & I didn't know where to go nor what platform as I have NEVER been before, I went down to platform 2 & 3, nobody was there to ask, so I went over to platform 1 (I discovered) as it looked busier, I then saw the barriers with a lady standing there & politely asked where to get the train to Salisbury, she very miserably stared at me & pointed to the platform I was at, I asked what time it comes as I missed my connection, but she just totally ignored me, SO RUDE,  & by time my train arrived almost an hour later I heard so many people moaning about how rude & unhelpful she was, and she told one lady she shouldn't even be there, that's NOT the passengers fault as most people missed their train links, the man looked miserable too when asked to carry a case for an elderly lady up the bridge stairs!

There needs to be clear signs on where to go and what trains will be arriving where, as all I saw on the station screens & announcements on the tannoy were only about where the rail link buses will be departing from, how I ever got to Devon is a miracle as I was 5hrs late!

This Station had a substantial face lift in preparation for the 2014 Ryder Cup. Up till that point it was a rather forgotten station that had a lot of character. Originally called Crieff Junction prior to being renamed Gleneagles Station in 1912. In the refurbishment they removed the old footbridge access that had a different car park arrangement & road access from the A9. The old footbridge linked the tower on the left to the old station building up on the embankment overlooking the new car park access road. It duplicated the footbridge that still links the original platforms. The current car park resides on the old siding  area & the canopy on the left was for a now unused platform. The station was also the junction point for the Crieff branch line that closed in 1964.

A lovely example of a traditional station,  too many of which have been flattened 'modernised' characterless platforms. An excellent reminder of the golden age of railways, even without the junction on to Crieff and beyond.
Lot's of cctv, quite, big carpark with taxi rank and local bus services.

A comprehensive museum about the Jacobite steam train at the stop about half an hour from Fort William. On the steam train ride there is about 20 minutes here to get off the train and visit the museum on the outward bound part of the journey.

Goldaming is located in the Chaterhouse section of Goldaming town and is used by Southwest Trains. built in 1849, as an alternative to the disgraceful Milford, Goldaming is a nice station. Though it is an exceptional station, it is neglected, the station house is crumbling and in desperate need of repair, there is also cracked concrete in some places as well. The staff at Godalming worked hard in the past to maintain the station. and they won awards In 2004 for Best Miscellaneous Building in the Godalming in Bloom 2004 Competition, in 2005 they won Best Small Station in the South West Trains Station Pride Awards and received a Highly Commended in the National Rail Awards.
In July 2006 the station won the Special Award in the Godalming in Bloom 2006 competition, not only for their display of flowers, but also for the welcoming environment they have created. In August 2006 they won Best Small Station in the 2006 South West Trains Station Pride Awards. 

However the station has since been neglected and needs completely redecorating and the 1849 building needs maintaining. The new waiting room has these seats that no one is able to sit on due to the poor sloping design and there is no waste bin on platform one.

You can't help but feel a bit embarrassed if visitors get off the train and ask where they can get a cuppa or a bite to eat locally, as there really isn't anywhere now.
Clean and tidy. Dropped a star as nowhere to get a coffee or a bite to eat.

while its great to see that station reopened and the line running to Edinburgh and Galashiels, its a bit of a shame the old station building isn't being used. Perhaps soon?
It's a bigger shame that the trains aren't always on time :(
And why doesn't the local bus service link better with the train service, although that's a comment that applies to a lot of public transport. 
Again maybe in the future.

Awesome cocktails. Really awesome cocktails. Not cheap but excellent given the quality. The service was fantastic, impeccable. I'd always worried it might be stuffy, instead it was warm, knowledgeable and attentive. Did I mention the cocktails. Did I mention the service.

We dined in the Siren restaurant, it was amazing! Absolutely faultless cooking, fish was perfect, flavours were epic! Service was wonderful, the lovely Irish lady looking after us through dinner was fantastic! Well worth a visit!

I thoroughly enjoyed my stay here. The central location within walking distance of Westminster, Buckingham Palace, Hyde Park and Mayfair is a huge plus. In addition to the refined elegance, I appreciated the quirks like the little stuffed sheep that adorn the place.

Really attractive station approach.  Famous for being the station used in the BBC program Survivors in the 1970's, very atmospheric.  Malvern itself is a very interesting place with some really good architecture and local history.  It is a bit hilly even in the town but nothing too severe. It is one of those places that you can wander around and just take in the place.  There are some nice shops and plenty of places to eat.  It would also make a good springboard to visit the local area.  The Malvern Flower Show is worth waiting for.  There are some good caravan sites in the area but early booking is probably advisable.  The roads climbing above the town into the Malvern Hills are interesting too.  Worth a walk around the area of the railway station as there are some nice properties, mainly Edwardian and Victorian and of course the railway station itself which is quite attractive and has a good bookshop and cafe.

A nice looking station and very pleasant approach.  This was a film site for the BBC series Survivors made during 1975 - 1976

There are 2 manned ticket kiosks with helpful staff to purchase your tickets or ask for advice from, there are clear live departure boards & a good undercover area for when its raining with a cafe & lots of useful information, as well as a local bus that stops outside (1b) to take you to the town or the bus station for a connecting service plus a taxi rank.
