Handy for Church - Christ Church, Greenbank meets in the old Station House on the Chester Road (Manchester bound platform) side.
A simple, unmanned station with a small free car park by the Church, and small shelters and card only ticket machines on both platforms.  A one minute walk from the car park over the road bridge to the Chester bound platform.
Wheelchairs have ramp access to the Chester bound platform but there is no car park, only very limited street parking, on that side.  For the Manchester bound  platform you can avoid steps by accessing from Chester Road through the car park vehicle entrance (minding the potholes and puddles). At present there is a step up to train carriages, as Northern uses ancient rolling stock, but train staff should help if necessary.

However once again no toilets for the elderly, diabetics, people with incontinence, people out for a drink etc. etc. etc. Our fares go up, we don't always get a seat on the train, tickets offices closing, no staffing the station to direct people, especially tourists, and just bare bones operations.

So if you think you will need to go to the toilet on your journey then I am afraid you may be a bit stuck. Try not drinking or eating for about 6 hours before your journey to minimise the risk of needing to relieve yourself whilst using popular train stations.

Every time I get on or off a train in Haggerston, I strut. I imagine all my indie heroes arriving at this station with their guitar in hand and a songbook full of deep poetry.

No one notices, because those days are gone, and indie never lived up to its early potential. Why am I always arriving too late? Why? Ten years ago I'd have made the scene! It would now be my music clogging up the bargain bins in Poundland. Not fair. Not at all.

The northbound platform information display consistently 'freezes' with wrong information and no-one ever seems to notice (staff) until it is directly addressed to them. 

This morning I waited nearly 20 mins for a train to Highbury and Islington, and it literally went straight past with passengers aboard, but didn't stop  (around 7.50am) leaving dozens of passengers on the platform, wondering what was going on. No announcements, no accurate display information, no explanation. 

This is frustrating and unacceptable given how modern and new this station is when compared with much of the antiquated network. Clear and accurate information is a necessary part of the function of a modern station - and it needs to be present and operational. 

Aside from this gripe, I would say it is generally well maintained.

Free parking beside platform 1 (Glasgow bound) is taken early but Carpark over the road also available for £1 a day. Trains into Glasgow every 15mins or so. Wee coffee van parks beside platform 1 in mornings.
All the facilities you would expect at a small train station are available. Clean and tidy.
Gets me home
Awesome!
Perfict

Not very well kept and appealing train station and often causes major congestion for Hampden park. Its alright for if you need a train and you live in hampden park (or near).

This is a good little station for the residents of hampden park and the surrounding areas. This has not got a ticket barrier and has a little alley for people to get to Farady Close

This station is situated nicely in Hampden park (East Sussex) with services to Eastbourne, Ore, Ashford Int', Brighton and London Victoria. NOT ALL TRAINS STOP AT THIS STATION! This is quite an unusual feature for a london train station.

I work in Soho and like to take a bus up to Hampstead Heath for a nice walk.
Luckily I live along the Overground route in North West London  so it is great to use the Overground.  Hampstead Heath is a lovely open, clean and well kept station.  There are often staff up in the ticket hall helping people and giving travel advice.
I love the Overground line (except the engineering work on Sundays) and Hampstead Heath is a really nice station to pass through.

Small station with overhead stops (orange line) on our map system...

There are nearby bus stops that can lead to Archway, Holloway areas.

Stopped by this morning to enquire if I could park there whilst visiting Hampton Court Flower Festival as the main car park was closed.....’yes of course you can...and it’s free’ A very pleasant response and experience and saved me £16! Thank you 😀

Explore the beauty of history. Step off the train at this easily accessed station and explore Hampton Court Palace. Don't forget to tap out as you are leaving the platform. This would be done with your travel or Oyster card. Tap in as you are boarding the train to return to London or your original journey.

The toilets are a disgrace. It’s Hampton Court Flower Show next week and the smell of urine and the unflushable toilets need to be fixed not just for people visiting the show but for the health of daily passengers and pride of the station!

Great for access to the riverside restaurants, Bushy Park, and various other Pubs and shops. Although the station is on the smaller/quieter side, and appears to open on to a side road, its not at all far away from a High Street.
Rogue people asking for small change and cigarettes or wanting an argument if refused aplenty at this station, daytime and late evenings.

I got to the station today in the midst of the snow chaos. The guy working at the station was absolutely amazing. I did not catch his name unfortunately , my phone had died, I was stuck at the station and needed to get my my destination. Not a bad little station for what it is.

RAILWAY STATION.
My first review less than 3stars. I waited an hour for a train that was cancelled. Submitted my return tickets and car parking for refund. Got refunded half train fare and zero parking. Very poor customer service  . GWR still made a profit out of me and possibly hundreds of other passengers that had to make alternative travel plans and miss appointments etc.

Lovely station BUT there is no ramp or lift, so it's impossible with a pram if you travel alone :( Luckily people are lovely and gave us a hand on the numerous stairs which lead up from the station to town.

Good little train station that makes it very handy to get into central Manchester. Tickets can be bought on either the train or at the ticket booth at the top of the station. Staff are friendly and help you get the cheapest journey.

Lovely station. Very neatly kept with charming staff, in my experience. The historic wooden station buildings have recently been given a lick of paint and it looks great.

One of the worst experiences of my life was when I was lost while cycling the canal, (I was 18 with a friend), we had managed to find a town called Hapton with a proximate train station. We waited and three trains kept going right past us without explanation. They would stop then they would see us waiting and then continue to drive on. Leaving two guileless kids stranded. The train station was covered in graffiti, with remnants of drugs around, including needles and cannabis packets. The place looked dilapidated and dystopic.

This railway station sits on the railway line which in one direction goes towards Blackburn and beyond, and in the other direction heads towards Colne.

The railway station is a "request stop" only so if you want to board the train you will have to flag the train driver down.

There are no official car parking spaces here so if you want to catch a train you will have to leave your car on a nearby street instead.

To get to either other platforms you have to go down a ramp which is fairly steep in nature and therefore perhaps not best suited for wheelchair users.

There is nowhere to sit down, and there is no form of shelter in the event of the weather turning bad.

Also, there is no digital information board so it is a guessing game as to when your train will arrive.

There is a help point phone located on the platform.

There is no sign whatsoever of any closed circuit television in the vicinity.

This railway station does have a ticket machine on one of the platforms if you need to buy a ticket for your train ride, and it makes use of a touchscreen display as well.

There are no obvious signs of any bicycle racks here at all.
Plenty of restaurants and bars in and around the station. Good connections with underground. Fast trains to Birmingham, NW and Glasgow

Convenient station, considering it's connected to multiple underground lines and national rail. Some shops and restaurants are also available inside this station. However, it is always busy and needs an expansion to cope with increasing travellers

Great station for travelling to many destinations with a great array of shops and areas to prepare for your journey. A very nice little Train station. Very clean and tidy with no litter anywhere to be seen inside or outside the station. Nice indoor seating areas for waiting for the train. The building is very nice.

One of the best stations in the area. Seriously good. Look, it's no Kings Cross, but if you are in need of a train to Welwyn Garden City, it's hard to beat. The staircase from the ticket office down to the platform is a nice touch.

Raph earns this station 5 stars as he is the most happy and smiley ticket man - it's a pleasure to buy a ticket from him rather than the machine every morning. Never fails to put a smile on my face.

It's great station and staff it's very friendly always willing to help as they can.

Enjoyed passing through here

Haslemere is located in the town with the same name and is served by Southwest Trains, Haslemere is a great station, staff are helpful and trains are on team, there is a car parts store nearby and I like the station building, the station is pretty cool and among one of my favourites.

The owners of the train station car park are probably the real life version of dementors- cannot possible have souls

I was given a ticket for not being in a clearly marked bay but I am being penalised for Indigo (now Saba Parking) not having clearly remarked a bay after work and tarmac was laid. I’d understand if it were a clearly marked bay, but it is not a finished bay so I don’t quite understand how I was meant to know where the parking company would define the bay as finishing.

I went through their 'appeals process' and anyone with decency and morals would have seen they had failed to mark the bay properly. But obviously I forgot in my desire to believe in the best of people, that parking companies don't care about anyone so long as they make money. 

I very much doubt they even have an appeals process and just refuse knowing most people can barely afford the £60, let alone risking £100 if they lose an external appeal.

I explained to Saba that I can’t afford to risk the extra £40. I’ve explained how little money I have that even my train fare was paid for by the charity I was volunteering for that day. It’s a shame to be so morally bankrupt but I guess as long as they make money, they don't care at all.
Super-fast ticket office man, especially when there's a train due. Very grateful for that.
Great, it has good facilitys and staff are very helpful☺☺☺☺☺

A modern station with access to many locations.
Platform 1 is not usually in use.
Platform 2 is for services to Brighton, Eastbourne and Ashford.
Platform 3 is for Ore, and, rarely, SouthEastern services to London Charing Cross and London Cannon Street, some terminating early at Tonbridge.
Platform 4 is where all SouthEastern services are normally found.
An attractive new modernist station which serves its purpose very well with an integrated bus and coach depot
Not the stations fault but don't like those old dirty trains that come from Moorgate to go Welyn garden , when its less than 8 coaches it stops so far from the exit of the stairs.

Doesn't seem to be the best of train stations but it has basic facilities like a ticket office, toilets, even a disabled toilet. Shelters look old fashioned and the station seems good enough for trainspotting.

Rubbish train station, theres almost never any staff around to talk to regarding train times etc. Toilets are always locked way before they’re supposed to be closed. Just wish there would be staff around after 4pm.

Two platform station in the Hope Valley.  On the Manchester to Sheffield line with frequent services  to Sheffield, Manchester and other Hope Valley stations.  Has a small car park.  In the village there are several cafes, restaurants and pubs, a garage, supermarket, butcher, bakers etc. Great place for outdoor/walking gear with three outdoor shops. Good place to start a cycle ride or walking.

This is a great place to walk to or from, from  or to a number of locations. I particularly like getting here after a walk and going round some of the pubs for food and a good sit down but also for the brilliant florist Wild About Flowers, well worth popping in even if just for a poke around. There are a lot of dog friendly places and if you're out walking and some piece of kit breaks, there are two outdoor shops with plenty of stock :) also, the Greengrocers is brilliant! 
Edit. I completely forgot! There's the Youth Hostel and a few hotels here too! So if you want to do the camping and walking thing without the camping... Hathersage!

I’m a Hattersley native and I love it
Very local from where I live
There is car parking

The bloke in the ticket office is really friendly and is always trying to keep it clean .
I love this place
Quite pleasant whenever visited
shady asbo central

Perfectly functional train station. No ticket office so buy on the train or at your destinations ticket office. Trains are every hour or two throughout the day but service Leamington Spa and Birmingham. Used this station to get off for a walk along the canal back into Birmingham City Centre. Great service

Basic facilities and step free access is available here via lifts and a footbridge. Station feels quite run down and unpleasant in certain areas like the platform waiting rooms and toilets. The staff in the ticket office were nice and quite polite to say the least.

I'm giving this station a 5 star review because we passed through it on our way to the Pembrokeshire Coastal Path, where the gentleman behind the ticket counter who we asked for some information wished us a lovely journey; and he remembered us when we returned a week later - three out-of-town, sun-burnt backpackers, and kindly kept our bags for us so we could run into town for one last fish-and-chips! Charming station in the glorious Tyne Valley with level crossing and working signal box at its western end. Great
Peaceful - except for events - enough of 'em though to keep you entertained - nice folk - picturesque - brilliant wild life and birds - glad to be living here - 3 pubs can't be bad B-)

Nice station which has handy tram and bus links.  As far as I'm aware all Edinburgh - Glasgow services stop here so you don't need to go right to Waverly to catch a train to Glasgow. Best station to travel from if you enjoy late or cancelled trains. Even more fun when you get to cram into a tiny two-carriage train during rush hour, really livens up the senses to get you ready for the work day.
Very helpful staff. I collected a disabled lady from the train everyone was so helpful they made it very easy
Good station. Frequent service and good bus links.

Large car parking, helpful staff and a good espresso bar on the platform is open at peak times. The regular staff here are always very nice and I only hope that there are no plans to let a ticket machine affect their jobs.
A modern railway station on the scenic Hope Valley Line. Steam trains pass through occasionally.
Small railway station. Neat and tidy but especially in the evening not even a coffee can be obtained. Overall just a well functioning station that does what it is supposed to do.

Small local station that is very well organised. Staff are friendly and helpful.
The station has ample parking and the station covers direct routes to both London and the coast.

Basic train station at least it has seating though and I think it has a sheltered area 2 don't know why it's called Headingley station though it's right on the edge of Headingley and probably equal distance to Kirkstall so quite a distance from the centre of Headingley

A very small train station, Platform 1 does NOT have disability access but platform 2 has disability access. This means that if you're going to Leeds from Headingley there's no disability access. Trains on this route are a lot of times late say about 5 mins. Overall it's okay for a place like Headingley.

As had been said there is no disabled access for the Leeds bound platform, so if you want to go to Leeds from here or come here from Horsforth/Harrogate you have a large set of steps to navigate. I have done it with a pushchair, but wouldn't recommend it.

It's not really in Headingley either, but in Kirkstall. There's about a 10 mins walk to the stadium and a bit further to the shops. 

Rush hour trains can be ridiculously busy, especially if they only put on 2 carriages. Expect to stand when going to Leeds on a morning.
Really really really nice. # Great for watching trains
Too far from the centre of Headingley.

Headstone Lane is located in the Harrow Weald section of London, the station is only served by the Overground, Headstone Lane is a decent station, the platforms are clean, and the air is clear, and the neighbourhood is lovely.
I had a job to do at Headstone Lane station. It is nice little station.
Clean and tidy old fashioned station with lots of stairs
Reliable main line train service.
Totally unstaffed so no tickets or help.
Clean and tidy station.
I had fantastic service from the staff at Heald Green station. They were incredibly helpful to me, particularly I.A Tilzey without whom I would have real problems getting home. Many thanks
Very helpful staff
Helpful staff
Nice station

Small train station. All weather cover. Wheelchair accessible but a bit of a steep slope. Ticket machine. No toilets. No car park. Pay and ride Boris style bikes close by. Regular trains. Just situated by heath low level station which is less than 2 mins walk.

A great very convenient train station for people around the are. A train every ten minutes or so to the city centre with a return ticket costing only £2. Don't need to buy a ticket at the station as you can buy one at the other end.
All weather cover. Wheelchair accessible. Ticket machine. No toilets. No car park. Situated just 2 minutes walk from heath High level train station.

It's okay enough honestly. There's a decent number of trains stopping here throughout the day and step free access is available here on both platforms. Seating and shelter is provided however the ticket machines were broken when I was there.
Credit and many thanks to local volunteers who take care and beautify the station.
It's okay but it'll be better when the entrance from the southbound platform to Heaton Moor Road is reopened in the new year
I still love  the place  witch l first  lived in 12 mauldeth rd  Manchester  in 1980
Avoid Stephen in the ticket stand , no customer service skills ! Very rude man. Think maybe he needs to rethink his job role !

Lovely railway station, trains are frequent every 15 minutes tops. The platforms make great photos and you can get some good shots of trains. I recommend travelling from this station, and if you are a trainspotter, this is the ideal place for you.

It looked quite nice on arrival, hanging baskets and stuff. We had to collect tickets but the office was boarded up and closed for lunch. We waited until it opened and were told, "use the machine, that's what it's for", whilst he munched on his packed lunch, it really was as friendly and helpful as that.
I think a training course in customer service or just plain common courtesy might be in order. 
Went to the cafe to get some lunch before the train. It was about 1:45, apparently it shuts at 2:00?! so no coffee but we were offered a vegan sausage roll. We didn't bother.....

8 o'clock at night and ticket office still open but toilets locked.Enquired at desk and told, , "I'm going home shortly use the ones on the train" Quite prepared to take money but not provide services..... How surprising.
There's a lovely little cafe at the station with outdoor settling on the platform. A perfect place to sip on a cappuccino and show off my snazzy crocodile shoes.
Some good food and quirky bars.
Lovely branch line station full of charm.
A truly picturesque station👍
Quaint little station with a museum.

Small but perfectly formed train station. With two platforms - main routes are London and Portsmouth, no toilets, coffee van outside station during weekday mornings and very little within a short walking distance. I'm always surprised that national rail/south west trains haven't invested more into Hedge End station considering how busy it is.

Whilst it has its flaws, such as no disable access in crossing platforms, and staff only manning the place until 12 midday, it has improved. There's now shelter during the rain, two ticket machines, instead of one, and it has plenty of parking space, and is next to a bus station. 

There's also a pub a 1 minute walk away too.
Quite awefull as machines are generally broken and the ticket station is never manned. Good train links though. No disabled access to second platform either.
Please stand behind the yellow line innit
No toilet, no wheelchair access to platform 2 (stairs only). Ticket office usually not open.
Nice Little town.
Bit cold here, would be great if they added some heated rooms for when its cold.
Well kept, and in a nice town, shame the train service is useless.
Good parking easy access
Good parking...

An historic station (formerly Aycliffe Lane) on the route of the Stockton and Darlington Railway, which opened in 1825. The 1827 agentʼs office and tavern, although no longer in use, are the oldest surviving buildings at any operational station in the county. However, due to the age and relative infrequency of trains plus the somewhat rudimentary nature of the waiting shelters, one might be forgiven for thinking that things havenʼt changed that much for the past two centuries.

The last stop from Glasgow and Edinburgh and the main station in Helensburgh just around the corner from the clide cost and the town centre station staff are very helpful and professional and a lovely place to visit or to have a holiday

Apart from trains being most of the time late or cancelled , the station is well maintained  clean and tidy,  seats are available around and pretty much sheltered from rain or snow, disabled toilets are also available on site.
Staff members are helpful.

Today I had a real senior moment and left my tablet on a bench on the platform. I realised as soon as the train had left the station. The ticket collector, Gary, very kindly rang the station who confirmed that it had been found by a member of staff, sorry I don't have the name. Thank you so much.  Arrangements were made for me to collect it later in the day from the ticket office. Thanks to all platform, ticket office and train staff for your help and kindness I really appreciate it.
Dianne Robinson.

Really nice well maintained station in a good location by the seaside. There is a cafe open every day, bike storage, a warm waiting room and toilet facilities as well as full disabled access.

It's just a shame about the dire train company who operate it, despite a decent schedule you are far from guaranteed a train from Helensburgh Central at the best of times as it will either be cancelled, delayed, revised, or start from Hydland instead.

To sum up, yes this station has everything you might need in a station apart from TRAINS. CHECK BEFORE YOU TRAVEL, and then even when you do check, check again.
Very rude and aggressive staff on platform. Failure to give appropriate and respectful safety information.

Very nice train station. Was waiting for the Oban train. Very comfortable train . Guard was helpful and found me a comfortable area for my shopper and large holiday trolley. I had coffee and a sandwich from the trolley. Scenery magnificent on way up. Got help off the train at Oban. A very nice experience travelling to Oban by train. Well earned 5 orange stars. When i go to Oban again will definately travel that way again.
This station could do with a bit of TLC to spruce it up and make it the little gemstone it should, and deserves, to be.
Well tended halt.
Not many trains but nice little station

Great place to get close to steam engines,
Takes you back to when it was a busy station, 
Love the history and at certain times a great cafe,
Highly recommended to railway enthusiasts,
A great place to view steam while taking on water
Quiet historic railway station, often serving heritage charter trains.
A lovely historic railway station just before the junction with the Little North Western and the Settle to Carlisle Line. Steam trains pass through regularly.
Very scenic and well maintained railway station on the Settle and Carlisle line.
River end of town looks tired with the main hotel empty. But harbour, museum, beach and views worth it. Plus La Mirage serves more food than you could ever eat.
Delightfully clean train station. Very helpful staff too.

Very poor service on Sunday 9th June 19.
Having all passengers go to PLATE form 2 and as the trail arrived they changed platform to 4 there was a few elderly people trying to get from plateform 2 to 4

Good little Station. Very helpful woman at ticket counter, three of those covered double-decker bike rack thingies, a kiosk downstairs and a Puccinos selling pastries and coffee on the London platform. All they need is a sandwich bar on the premises or nearby.
Refused to issue a pre dated to me because they didn't know if there would be any problems on the day of travel
Nothing outstanding there
Lovely place for a summer stroll.
Beautiful English town on the Thames. Had a lovely day there.

Called at Henley Station this morning at around 8.30am when somebody was just finishing working on the ticket collection machine. I cheerfully asked if the machine was working and you sarcastically replied that it looked like it. There’s no need for that you miserable sod.
Quaint little train station. Has one ticket machine available 24/7 outside booking office. Booking office only open Mon-Fri 06:00-13:00 and Sat 07:00-13:00.
Huge car park for the size of the station. Generally kept clean and staff are helpful. However staff aren't present for more than a few hours each day.

This quaint railway station lies on the railway line that heads towards Leeds in the one direction (and towards Goole in the other).

A lot of the railway traffic that passes through this railway station is freight based, which includes delivering coal to the nearby power station. Yes, there are passenger Services through Hensall, but they don't pass along this stretch of track that often at all.

If you need to catch a train at Hensall, it would be advisable not to come by car as there is no where at all to park your car, so the best you can do is if somebody were to drop you off nearby and then walk to the nearby platforms.

This station does have a platform covered shelter on both sides of the track.

There are no obvious means of actually identifying whether a train is coming in the direction you want to go (or not), and that includes the lack of any digital display regarding train manoeuvres.

Also, this railway station does not have any bike rack, so it would not be advisable to travel to Hensall railway station with your bike as there will be no where to leave it securely.

It should also be noted that this railway station does not have any method of passengers being able to purchase railway tickets, which therefore means if you want to take a ride on any of the trains here, you will have to purchase the ticket either in advance, or alternatively you will have to obtain a ticket once you board the train.
Nice station but only 3 trains a day

A nice station with plenty of good rail links to major destinations. The toilets are clean and modern. The station also contains a cafe and other essentials including a waiting room. It was a bit dirty on the platforms however, could've been cleaned to the standards that the toilets were done to!

Dreary Station in need of modernisation.   Trying to get in and out of it is depressing with two pathetic doors.

Service to and from Birmingham could be described as a poor at best.

Staff are great but they need to complain about their poor working conditions. I use trains alot in most southern counties and Hereford is the worst I have been to, very run down, dirty, unkempt, outdated. When will it get a revamp?
Its a pity to see a station in such a state. Old, dirty and in need of a good scrub along with a lick of paint. Other than that staff were polite and the train on time. Thanks...

A station run by Transport for Wales and is served by trains from Transport for Wales, Great Western Railway and West Midland Railways

It has 3 platforms and a small indoor waiting room and a ticket office and a barrier and it is staffed.

Platform 1 & 2 accessible by a bridge and lifts and they have kept the old bridge

Toilet (singular) for ladies at least is on platform 3

Usual ticket facilities of a self service machine

Buses do serve the station (there is one on the left as you go out) but did not notice the one on the RIGHT as you go out, and no indication of another bus stop and is was only by chance than I saw the bus come in that I noticed the other bus stop - otherwise good to have bus stops actually near the station entrance
I don't love Herne Bay. I LOVE CERTAIN PARTS AND PLACES HERE.Like the serene walk with my dog Dolly to reculver. Even the walk reculver to Margate. Good for tourists.

Outside area including the bus stop was very poor - litter everywhere and the only bin in the area toppled spewing rubbish all over the street.

The train we were taking was canceled and little help was received. 

The bus stop outside has little ability to cope with more that one bus at once - there were 3 at one point.
Great station, easy to get around and staff always has a smile on their face

Brilliant service today. Ticket office staff member very helpful, thank goodness it's open on a Sunday you really wouldn't be able to do a photo card early Monday morning. This has definitely reduced my concerns travelling to London all week, even bought my car parking ticket.
My favourite station all the land!!! I always look forward to the grand promenade and the wonderful cafe, me and mum come often for lunch
Appalling service by woman at ticket counter on 12 September, 4pm. Earned yourself one star too many.
By far my favourite station in London
Woman at the ticket counter at 4pm on 12.09.19, you earned yourself one star for your appalling customer service - congratulations!
Been here a few times, could use a clean up. Great to connect to other train lines from Bromley. Will use again
I had to change trains at Herne hill today. Not only was the waiting room unlocked, it was clean, comfortable and well maintained. The cafe on platforms 1 and 2 is a good addition too. Well done.

Bare bones station that honestly feels like it's been built on a strict budget, even for the time period. No step free access or any decent facilities whatsoever, a few ticket machines and only staffing seen are in the mornings.

Seating and shelter are inadequate at best and don't fully protect from the rain and wind which is fun. What a rubbish station.

While understandably not in any way grand, it feels like this station was knocked together as a result of a local 6th form DT project, for a couple of quid.

2 stars because it has a roof.

Hersham is located in the town with the same name and is used by Southwest Trains. Hersham is a terrible station. Not only does it not have staff, the station is gritty and smells, the station only has two benches on each platform. I recommend using Walton-on-Thames instead.
Bad service

its a Shame  - there are 2 plateforms with maybe 2 benches each, no toilets, no one to help you if you need assistance. My advise to you would be to travel from/to walton on thames and walk to hersham

The station is very quiet. Opened in 1888.
Trains are operated by Greater Anglia.
I travelled to Liverpool Street station. Trains run slow.

station is easily accessible and has good overhead coverage.  But, couple more ticket machines would be helpful for when there is an electronic failure on the existing two. Also public WC  would be handy.Greater Anglia train service on the other hand has a very poor  unpredictable service in either terminus

Was quite a nice looking station with a partially staffed ticket office and nothing to hinder step free access to the platforms and trains. Oyster is accepted here and the station is located close to the town. Nice.
I was doing a rail replacement . All stations to Enfield. Quite an experience  as I had never been to any of the stations that I had to call at.
Luvly little station! Cheep cheep.
Good building. It has a shop, Ticket Machines and Office, A nearby parking, platform 2 and 3 have step-free access, has toilets but let down by the amount of delays and cancellations.

One of the worst train services I've ever used in my life. I've been here a few times and every time the trains are cancelled or delayed. If you are trying to get to Stevenage you will be better of getting the bus and if you're going to London then get the train from Hertford East.
Nice driver 🤗
It's one of the more unusual station buildings, let down by regularly-delayed trains.

Hey it's an un-manned station not much there.
They've added ticket machine, and the electronic notice boards were being worked on when I was there.
Lovely train station

Unmanned Station without ticket machines. Be aware you will need to purchase your ticket online as you can now be fined for attempting to buy it on the train. Very few services stop here so don’t expect to turn up at the station and easily get a train. Research it first online. Station is a bit run down so be prepared for awaiting transport in adverse weather!

Hessle looks like a good station from trains.
Hessle's main landmark is Humber Bridge, which was the World's longest single span suspension bridge. Another geographical feature is linked to the bridge. The Yorkshire Wolds Way terminates on the bridge The Lincolnshire Wolds Way probably terminates on the bridge too, forming The Wolds Way, new version.
Unstaffed.bleak, particularly at night.
It’s home and one of the most beautiful places to live
A small station with almost no facilities, you have to purchase your tickets on the train. Trains stop here going to Bidston and Wrexham. It does have a small car park and a pay phone though.
This has been incorrectly signposted as a station. Have reported to Google Maps.
There is no railway station at Brocas Farm, Southern or otherwise. The nearest station is at Hever!

Poor facilities and not much shelter in cold or bad weather, despite the fact this is supposed to be a modern transport interchange!! Access to both platforms is via long ramps with stairs only on the northern (westbound) side. There was direct entry to the Tyne and Wear Metro system without having to go up then down again, at least from the southern (eastbound) platform, but the way is now barred by a metal shutter despite this link being a very sensible idea and of obvious benefit to passengers. The frequency of trains is also abysmal, with only one an hour in each direction for most of the time. In short, this is not a shining example of transport fit for the 21st century and there is much scope for improvement.
could do with better service

People who work on the station do not care about rail service and do not know -probably do not want to know notning, no information point, very poor service. Station does not have proper signals what is where, very confusing. There is one little shop where is nothing - just few cans in the fridge, few chocolate bars and few crisps bags. Bad bad bad!!!
Trains are on time and very clean station staff very helpful and friendly
This is a charming little train station, and it's like going back to the better days in the past.

Went to ask about returning unused tickets from the strike day and found the guy behind the ticket desk pretty lacking in tact, when I told him I hadn't seen any signs on the day he pointed out some small posters in windows. I knew where the ticket machine is and there was nothing before or on it about the reduced service. I don't typically scout the perimeter of a station for posters before I buy my tickets. He said it wasn't his fault I couldn't see which I found a bit rude. Also falsely claimed that there were announcements every couple of minutes on the strike day. It took 15 minutes before there was a peep. Maybe just take the advice to help your customers next time.
A traditional historic railway station on the scenic Tyne Valley Line. Steam trains including those hauled by 60103 Flying Scotsman pass through from time to time.
I just visited to view the signal box, but found the station equally charming.

Pretty much the same as Tackley in terms of services except it's right next to the Oxford Canal, which is nice. Service pattern of every two hours is still provided here which is a complete joke. Step free access is only available for the Oxford bound platform.
Very easy to find nice and clean and staff lovely helpful good with the kids
Easy access. No fuss. Facilities good.
Easy to access.
Quick and easy accessible
Simple and easy.
A fairly nice station, with an exciting but slightly dirty underground tunnel connecting the two platforms. Please do note that trains make a very short stop here.

Local train station for Higham village and surrounding areas including Cliffe and Cliffe Woods.

A mobile coffee shop is avaliable form 6am to 10am weekdays.
it good
This is a really good London overground station in zone 4, especially Since the addition of the automated ticket Gates lines to tap your oyster have gone down a lot!

London Overground have really improved this station; their recent renovation has made the station look much smarter and more modern. The staff are also very helpful! Today, I carelessly dropped my gloves on the platform, and when I returned later in the day, the staff gave them back to me. I was so relieved and I want to say thank you to that kind gentleman. Overall, I am proud to say that Highams Park is my local station!
Huge improvement since London Overground took over. Clean trains, clean station, all refurbished. Staff at all times. Accessible in both directions now work completed. Shows what can be done!
A reasonably good station but what does annoy me is how the doors are locked at a relatively early time of about 7pm. This means I have to walk much longer!

No step free access for months now with no indication of when the pointless works will be finished, if ever. I've never seen a worker working, only smoking or leaning/standing perfectly still. They should feel nothing but unbridled shame for the grief they are causing for people with bicycles, prams, people with low mobility and wheel chair users. Three star station because this is rather isolated. The area is heavy on industry.
There are homes and shops, they're about ten minutes away. 
Buses are available but, it's off the beaten track a bit so check a timetable.

Small, unmanned, unkempt station. Next to no cover if it rains, and if you are there late a large chunk of the trains will only open one door to stop people getting on. I'd rather walk up to Cosham than use this station,  and in fact have, several times.

Hilsea is located in the Hilsea area of Portsmouth, the station is served by Southern and Southwest Trains, with additional services provided by Great Western Railways. Hilsea is among one of my favourite stations, it's clean, most trains stop here, announcements are clear, the station is up to date and the neighbourhood is quiet.

This station, although small, and lacking in facilities, is probably the best station in Hilsea. The area is mainly industrial, with urban conurbations spring up on the periphery of the industrial areas. The station platforms are also quite dangerous, as the width of the platforms are less than the recommended SWT safety width. Can barely walk 2 abreast on the platforms, so on a busy day extra care should be exercised.
Loads of fun and interesting people

It's just one of those barely staffed small stations on the outskirts of London with a half hourly service in each direction, a pair of tickets machines and a lack of step free access, only being accessible via a footbridge. At least the station has a unique enough platform layout.
They really do need to make it step-free so it is more accessible,  its 2018!
Clean station well Signposted
Ok
A nice station, but unfourtently the ticket seller working behind the desk is an extremely rude indivdiual. He has zero courtesy and does not posses even the most basic of manners.

Decent little station but watch out for the short ticket office hours.

Small station. Nothing wrong with that.
Friends of Hindley station have done a spectacular job.

Lovely station in a deep cutting that's very well looked after. This is done by locals I understand and not the rail company. It's been great recently as the weather has been been good but I imagine it's awful in winter. Not enough cover if it rains. No lifts too so if you can't manage the steps your stuffed. There's no one to help.
Lovely surroundings and great train schedules. Pity there's no lift or escalator otherwise it would be a 5 star rating.

I needed somewhere nearby to catch a train. I tried the lake, the golf course and the local Tesco, but nothing doing. Wish I'd known about hindley station sooner. I was able to catch my train and get off at another station, then during the return journey I managed to get off at hindley again. It works BOTH WAYS!! Brilliant.
where are all the trains

At Holyhead Railway station. It never changes. it's been the same old Train services from Holyhead to London Euston and Cardiff Central and Cardiff Central. And there has only been 2 platforms as well. So I would like to make a few Suggestions. 

1. I Think Holyhead Railway station Should Expand in the future with some more platforms. 

2. I Think There Should be a Brand New Direct Train services from Holyhead to Clacton on Sea, London Liverpool Street, Aberdeen, Brighton, Blackpool North, Hastings, Portsmouth, Scarborough, Great Yarmouth, Enfield Town, Penzance and Plymouth with some Brand New projects. 

3. I Think Holyhead Railway station Should have Left Luggage in the future. 

4. I Think There Should be a Brand New Channel Tunnel or Bridge from Holyhead to Dun Laoghaire in the future. That's with 2 Brand New Direct Train services from London Euston to Galway and Londonderry via Holyhead. And if it goes to Londonderry. That's stopping at Dun Laoghaire, Dublin Connolly, Balbriggan, Drogheda Macbride, Dundalk, Newry, Portadown and Belfast Central until it ends in Londonderry. 

5. I Think Holyhead Railway station Should have some Brand New Shops, Pubs, Bars and Restaurants etc in the future. 

Now the reason why I am Suggesting all this is because the Traffic on the A55, A10, A406, M1, M2, M3, M4, M5, M6, M62, M11, M25, M23, A1, A2, A23, A12 etc. The Traffic is nothing but a waist of Time. And it's not going to get any better. So we need to Encourage people to get out of Cars and unto Public Transport. And Hopefully one day that Holyhead Railway station will change in the future.

This particular railway station sits on the railway line that heads towards Colne in one direction and heads towards Blackburn and beyond in the other direction.

There are no official car parking spots available here so if you want to catch a train and leave your car here you will have to leave it in a nearby street instead.

The train station only has seating area on one of the two platforms, and there is definitely no where to shelter if the weather was to become inclement.

There are no digital information displays whatsoever at the station although there is a tannoy System to give you some idea that trains are heading one way or another.

There is a pedestrian bridge over the railway track so that you can walk from one side of the platform to the other platform if you need to do.

There are no obvious signs of bicycle racks here and also there are no signs of closed circuit television neither.

There is also no ticket machine or any staff at the station, so if you want to board a train you will have to buy a ticket beforehand or get one on a train from the conductor.

Station platforms are clean, very very convenient to go to Lincoln (its cheaper and faster by train). Only thing that they may improve, is some services. Especially on Saturdays, where services are every hour and twenty minutes. Some express services wouldn't hurt too. Because the service to Newark Northgate skips this station meaning if you'd want to get to Newark North gate (High Speed Railway Station) you'd have to go to Lincoln or change at Newark castle which is a 15 minute walk. The help points are good, replies within 30 seconds. Also, shelters just in case it rains. There are some bike racks, that normally get used. The last time I went they were all taken. The station recently had a small refurbishment, a new sturdy platform casing and a new station sign which is visible. It is located on Station Road. And yes, there is PARKING there, which is rather free. Though - only for station use, people have been fined for not using this properly. So, next time you come to Lincoln from the south west/ south; come to this railway station. (Just remember to check the timetable)!

Upon exiting the station  you will frequently see groups of insalubrious individuals gathered outside either aggressively begging or blatantly indulging in shall we say somewhat more nefarious activities.  This intolerable situation recently culminated with a British Transport Police Officer being stabbed by one of these “over represented” criminal elements. Customer service needs huge improvements and of course its great to build system to travel not just for walking people, Wheelchairs need to have access also, Kensington (Olympia) is a combined rail and tube station between Kensington and West Kensington on the boundary of west and central London. It is managed and served by London Overground and served by Southern and London Underground. It is in Travelcard Zone 2. On the Underground it is the terminus of a short District line branch, built as part of the Middle Circle, from Earl's Court; on the main-line railway it is on the West London Line from Clapham Junction to Willesden Junction, by which many trains bypass Central London. The station's name is drawn from its location in Kensington and the adjacent Olympia exhibition centre.

The shore area has changed greatly since the 1970's, due to the Kent river channel moving further away towards the Arnside shore. This has allowed invasive spartina grass to establish itself, enabling  mud to be held back during high tides. The sea bed has risen about 8 feet as a result.

The treetop walk was a little scary for me as I am afraid of heights but I still did it and saw a birds eye view of everything. It was a magical experience and I will be back next time I’m in town.

An attractive, well cared for station close to Kew Royal Botanical Gardens.

The station has two platforms and is served by the District line and London Overground. Each platform has its own gates and staff.

Most people arrive on the Richmond bound side, which is on the opposite platform from the RBG. To cross over you must exit on that side, then use the subway on the immediate left (22 steps down then up), or use the footbridge over the tracks on the right.

The Botanical Gardens are a five minute level walk from the station.

Although both platforms are step free, any customers with poor mobility or using a wheelchair arriving on a train going to Richmond, should stay on the train. Go to Richmond and then return on another train to Kew Gardens so you can exit easily.

If you need assistance speak to staff before starting your journey.

Ticket machines, toilets and a newsagents are all available on the Central London bound side, nearest the RBG.

Staff are available both sides and were approachable and helpful.

There's also plenty of restaurants, cafes and shops conveniently available in the streets right outside the station.
Probably the greenest, most beautiful and safe area in South West London. Botanical gardens are a must see for any visitor.

Lovely park with many activities for all family members, it was such an amazing day we enjoyed everything in this place, especially the smell of nature all around.  I liked the idea of many places for dining and coffee

Life time Londoner yet my first time coming here today.

The place is amazing! Virtually faultless ( one fault which I’ll get to later).

It covers a vast landscape and has some serious style! Concrete and plants 💕 lots of spiky boys, different terrains and landscapes, a pagoda ( which sways in the wind at the top!! Very unpleasant hah ), water based environments, hot and cold environment plants.

It’s a super relaxing vibe and it’s so large that you can escape from people if you want. Lots of interesting corners and I would say it’s fun for the whole family.

My only grip is that there is not enough sign posts and even tho I’ve lead hikes over vast terrain, trying to read the map they issue is not easy!

So yes, go and make a whole day of it! Make a pack lunch and take it slowly :)

A separate line can be accessed under the road bridge with trains to Wigan, Manchester and beyond. These normally run every hour.
Platforms can be reached using the steps to one end of the platform or via a ramp to the other end. The ticket office is at street level with a toilet next to it. Glass shelters with seats are available on both platforms.

This railway station at Langho is the stop off point for trains heading either towards Blackburn or towards the Clitheroe direction. 

I have given this rotation only a three star rating for a couple of reasons such as there is no disabled access entrance to this platform and station at all and there is also nowhere that passengers can park their cars if they wanted to commute in either Direction.

Both of the platforms do you have areas where people can sit down and wait for their trains and some of these seating areas are covered shelters.

This railway station does have digital information displays to indicate to passengers when the next trains are likely to arrive.

There is definitely no sign whatsoever of a bike rack on either of the platforms.

So far as I could see there is no closed circuit CCTV cameras for security purposes.

What I did like at this station was that there was quite a number of colourful flower boxes on both platforms. OK, I would agree that flower boxes are not going to help anybody on their railway journey but at least it does give a place a nice feel about it.

An attractive historic railway station on the scenic Esk Valley Line. Steam locomotives pass through from time to time.

Normally Leamington Spa station is fine and staff helpful. There is a considerable amount of parking and a good service to London, Birmingham and much of the country. However, today I went to buy a ticket at 1805 for travel tomorrow to minimise delays early tomorrow morning. The ticket office was closed as staff were “on a break” until 1830. The office opened at 1833 and I eventually obtained my ticket at 1846. For me it was an inconvenience but for others arriving during the closed period it was a major problem since travel without a ticket would incur penalties. Hence for trains departing over the period of office closure, and for a period of some 15 minutes after, those wishing to travel have been put at risk of extra cost and inconvenience. This is unacceptable and it is to be hoped will be put right soon.

The painted concrete and industrial art deco design don't seem to work quite as well here as they do at the stations between here and West Kirby, in part due to the overpowering modern flats immediately adjacent to the westbound platform. However, the level crossing at the western end of the station adds some character and in addition to the relatively large free car park across the road, you shouldn't have to wait too long for a train.

Leeds Station is the bees gnonads. I have lived in Leeds all my adult life and I am loyal to my home town. OK. If you need to use the toilet, I suggest you use the platform loo, before you leave because Leeds is terrible for public toilets. Last trains away from Leeds are usually before midnight, which is way too early. But information is good, staff are friendly.
Leeds station is well signposted and therefore easy to navigate. There are plenty of options for food to eat whilst you wait. Northern's ticket office staff were kind and helpful when I visited.

I don't tend to go in that much, but it's a very well set out station, with lots of conveniences such as shops etc. Staff are quite friendly, not ran into any hostile staff. Writing this as a rail enthusiast, I'd recommend visiting if you want to do some train spotting, as there is a variety of different trains on offer. Refurbishment works on the main concourse at the time of writing make the large open space quite cramped.

Good access to trains travelling around the country, good shops when waiting for a train, staff always brilliant. However, there always seems to be some sort of building work going on. I understand maintenance has to take place but very annoying when trying to get around a usually VERY busy station.

Our group of adults with learning disabilities and two wheelchair users set out from Leeds train station this morning to Halifax station as they were going to Eureka for the day.  They booked their tickets through Traveller Assist and when they landed at Halifax station they were told that the accessible lift was out of service and therefore they couldn't leave the station.  This left our support workers with some very upset people and one person with autism who went into meltdown because the plans had changed.  The lady at Halifax from Northern Rail explained that she had called Leeds Traveller assist first thing this morning at 5.20am to tell them that the lift was out of order.  Why were we not told when we booked our tickets???
Never enough staff, ticket machines always broken and the queue always out the door.

Small station with two platforms that cuts across between the west and east; one platform heading east, the other west. There are staircase access plus ramp access for wheelchair users. Littleborough railway station is located on the line which heads towards Manchester in one direction, and Leeds and beyond in the other.

Platform 2 does have two ways to get to the platform either by steps or either by a ramp that is located close to the car park nearby.

There is visible evidence at this station of security cameras which is comforting to know.

Platform one has one covered waiting area whilst platform 2 has two covered waiting areas. In one of the waiting areas on platform 2 there is a easy to use ticket machine.

There is visible evidence of a bicycle rack on platform 2 that could perhaps take up to 6 bicycles at a push.

This railway station also does have digital information boards to indicate when the next trains are due to arrive.

There is a car park for this railway station although it tends to get somewhat rather packed at times. It does have a couple of disabled parking bays if the need arises. This car park does not have any visible security camera presence.

An interesting blend of old and new, which might perhaps afford passengers waiting opposite the restored original station platform an opportunity to reflect upon just how much things have improved on the railways in the last 100 years or so (no matter how much we like to complain about the state of our train services in this country). As attractive as the period brickwork night be in the light of day, it is sadly not at itʼs best when lit by subdued artificial lighting (even if the colours change in a rather attractive way) and one might be forgiven for thinking that it some dark corner or long-forgotten access tunnel something sinister is afoot. Perhaps even a Bond villain could be hatching their latest diabolical plot, who knows? Joking aside, however, should you be in Liverpool with an hour to spare itʼs worth having a look at if even you have only a passing interest in railways or historic architecture. It is certainly one of the cityʼs lesser-known but hidden gems – which for the sake of authenticity is best reached from Water Street via the much brighter pedestrian tunnel (only open at peak hours on weekdays).

Lochluichart Railway Station is a request stop on the Kyle Railway Line. The flatform had been salted by someone the day I visited and there were good noticeboards telling me when to expect the next train etc. There is a little wooden shelter to keep you dry on a wet day. The station is located on Loch hall Road (A760) which is off the A737 road to Irvine. It is a small station between Howood and Dalry on the Ardrossen / Largs line. There are regular trains to Glasgow and its a good 30 min commute to Glasgow Central and under an hour to Troon. There is a ticket machine at the station which only accepts cards, if you don't have a bank card just buy a ticket with cash on the train from the friendly staff. A bike rack which is semi protected from the weather is there for your convenience. Leave your bike there overnight it's safe. There is a sheltered area for bad weather and a car park that is big enough for 20 cars. If you can't get parked close to the station, park on the side of the road leading to the car park. Do not obstruct the roadway. Buses service the station for Johnstone, Kilbernie, Dalry and Bridge of Weir. The closest bus to Glasgow is about a 10 min walk from the station at the A737 roundabout. Thats good to know when trains are cancelled because of flooding, snow etc. The RSPB bird sanctuary is less than a minute walk from the station and boast lots of birds and critters. Loch Semple and Barr Loch meet in the rainy season when there is flooding. Please check the Lochwinnoch local  website for any weather disruptions as you won't be able to access the station from the Lochwinnoch Village side on Loch hall Road those days. The station is a 3minute drive / 15minute walk from Lochwinnoch Village and no taxi company services the station although the nearby town of Johnstone has a few reputable taxi companies, search for them online. There is a lovely restaurant about 2minutes from the station and visible from the platform. Furthermore the trains are neat and tidy with on board perks such as rest rooms, free wifi, genuine bicycle racks, table seating, disabled persons seating and charging ports.The service has never let me down in terms of quality and runs till late at night. Check your train booking apps for correct prices and times. Currently it's under £6.00 a return to Glasgow from here. I have been stranded at Glasgow Central Station before on an amber weather warning. In that instance I took a train to Johnstone Station ( if possible the service will run as far as that). From there you can get a taxi to Lochwinnoch and other locations no problem. Please like my review if it has helped you.
Nice wee station with everything you need
This is a small Scotland station in a very charming town.

A nice small, station.

The (new) signage took me on a VERY long trip going past just about every shop they have - which I suppose was the idea. I don't come to train stations to do my shopping in boutique shops. I come to catch a train and transfer to another. Please make the interchange easier. But, I must say the platform staff were very helpful. Not the information booth staff though. They were arrogant and walked off whilst  I was talking still to them. How rude.

Love the new look London Bridge station escalator going to the platforms nice big and airy.

Ticket office staff can only sell certain types of ticket, but there is no signage to make people aware of this. I stood in line for 20 minutes, only be to be told they couldn’t sell the ticket I wanted because it was offered by a different train company.

Clean well built, not sure how good it is if you are not a frequent user as you appear to have to go down to lower level to see where your connection is. Platforms are a bit narrow in places if you suffer from acrophobia

Gorgeous park with very useful facilities, a lot of space for children, picnic gatherings and sports. There are toilets available, which make this park very accessible and desirable. But the best part of this park is the fact they have tennis courts, gym with cafe and a heated swimming pool.
A small and quiet halt of a station with no step free access, minimal facilities, no ticket barriers and even limited shelter. Location is quiet and decent enough but that's about it.

It’s a 4 from me. And if you know me, you know that I don’t give out stars lightly. I use this bad boy most days during the week and it’s always a pleasant experience. From walking through the doorway, beeping my card, to waiting on the platform, it’s a very professional, welcoming and warm station. I will be a regular for many years to come. Keep on rocking TFL, I’ve bought the T-shirt !

Trains are seldom on time, maybe once a week for the morning trains but never on a Monday. Now getting very congested and often a struggle to get on the train during peak hours. Staff fairly helpful and they've lessened the constant prerecorded messages.
Nice little station nestling amongst housing and businesses in bustling London Fields. It is usually staffed these days. Trains from Liverpool Street to Enfield Town.
Nothing special about the station but nothing wrong with it either. Does its job just fine.

Pleasant little train station on the edge of Brighton, it's very looked after and has some interesting history boards that you can read. Trains are often delayed however this is due to southern rail not the station itself.

Long Buckby railway station is a small railway station next to the village of Long Buckby, Northamptonshire, England. It is the nearest railway station for the town of Daventry, 4 miles (6.4 km) away.
Discover Long Buckby Rail Station. Getting to and from, buying and collecting tickets, staffing, facilities, accessibility & mobility access

Small station with 2 platforms. trains quite regular as it serves London Euston one end and Birmingham New Street the other end. Ideal for getting to Birmingham International, Rugby, Coventry and Milton Keynes. Both platforms are accessed via steps so no disability access. No toilets either which is an issue if trains are delayed. There is a coffee/snack van in the car park which does well. Huge car park which I use regularly if travelling for work - £4.80 flat rate per day. Smaller car park at front of station is permit holders only.  Ticket machine is often out of order and ticket desk is not always manned and regularly closed.

Of course it's a railway station offering transport, there is quite a big car park and bus service running through regularly but the ticket machine seems to be out of order a lot of times. There is also a snack van nearby I haven't yet tried.
Limited facilities. Now has a snack bar in car park in the morning. Plenty of parking and only £4 a day.
Coffee superb
Well cared for station obviously tended to by staff passionate about its appearance.
Very native place of Trent valley
Really handy for Sawley, not Long Eaton, but the services provided by East Midlands Trains and Cross Country are great.

Very quiet station, it's one of the ones that gets missed out on some of the services between Carlisle/Lancaster & Leeds. No electronic screens but there is a railway phone that you can use to speak to the signalman to find out where your train is.
Because I live so close to the Halt, it had been invaluable.

If you happen to be on a train which stops here then, save the old signal box across the other side of level crossing at the eastern end of the station, it has to be said it will most likely be something of a non-event. The lack of facilities and diminutive wooden platforms mounted on stilts suggest that money has not been lavished on bringing this station into the 20th, never mind the 21st century, though at least there is a covered waiting area. A grim place to catch a train in winter or at night and not a car park in sight.

Very poor. Waited until I had lived in the area at least 2 months to see if anything improved after feedback & it hasn’t. Machines often don’t work, either don’t take notes or don’t take change (or both) often no one behind the desk, and most notably - advertise as a station with a toilet & disabled access - and have neither available. It has been out of order since May.
It's not to bad now the lighting has improved on the platform apart from that just a normal  station

Offers everything you need at a train station, semi covered platforms, machines to buy tickets by card and cash and a service attendant to answer questions, has train information in easy to see spots and large enough signs for anyone to read from any range.

Some of the platforms could do with a clean and some trains are often a minute or two late but that isn't the stations fault.  Overall a decent station with decent service
Just your standard train station....could do with modifying but then so could most stations
It gets crowdy sometimes but its good overall
Although the roads leading here say restricted access it is possible to get through however only by foot or bike, no cars.  There are no staff or ticket machines.

Surrey’s least used train station (although with new developments maybe for not much longer). There is only about 5 trains a day stopping here. It’s really difficult to get in and out of as the most obvious way is through the studios which don’t allow you to walk through. The new housing development shuts off another way so you have to walk on a small muddy trail through the woods. The station isn’t staffed and instead you have to buy a “permit to travel” which is a piece of paper you have to renew at the station you get off at, and buy your ticket there. This costs either 2x 10p 2x 20p or 2x 50p. This station is about as minimal as it gets...

As far as train stations go its pretty minimal, with no staff, limited access and no ticket machine, however, if your looking for a fun adventure location or even just a nice day out with a picnic, its a really fun place to go.

Very small station, more of a cubicle really, two platforms and a bridge over the tracks to get to the other side, which is great for taking photos of passing trains. At night the smell of urine and the closed office make it feel quite rural, despite it being it being in the heart of Longfield, however staff were very helpful and really got our trip to London off to a good start, so an extra start for service (if not surrounding).

5 stars because it's one of the fastest ways to leave Longniddry

This railway station is located on the line that heads towards Manchester in one direction, and Stoke-on-Trent in the other.

There is a small amount of car parking spaces located near platform 2 which could perhaps take maybe 3 cars at best. 

I won't be in any particular great rush to park my car there simply because there is no obvious CCTV overlooking the car park, and access to this small car park is not very good at all, quite simply because the car park is situated right next door to an industrial site that includes a car dealership and garage repair service, therefore access to parking your car near platform 2 isn't that great really at all.

Considering parking spaces for cars on platform one, there really isn't any official car parking space on that side of the platform so if you wanted to take a train towards Stoke-on-Trent it would be far easier if somebody dropped you off on that side rather than you leave your car anywhere near that part of the station, and that is why I have given this place a rating of only three stars.

Looking at the better parts of this station, there is a digital display board on both sides of the station, and both platforms do have covered waiting areas, and there is also a bike rack located on platform one which can perhaps hold two or three bikes at best (at any one time).

There is absolutely no means that I could see where you could buy a ticket if you wanted to, so you would have to either purchase it in advance, or buy it on board the train.

This railway station is a reasonably busy railway station in terms of trains passing through it, but there aren't as many trains if you want to actually get on (and board the train).
Better than Stoke station because it's less busy. Shame there's only 2 trains that go here.

Got some really beautiful architectural buildings and green spaces. Especially the mature victorian planting of Longton Park aka Queen's Park. The best park in Stoke-on-Trent!
 Just a shame the majority of it is run down. The majority of shops in the town centre are charity shops or empty. 
The indoor market (a grand turreted entrance on The Strand with a mosaic and a lion's head above it), is good for fresh fruits and vegetables at reasonable prices. Lots of meat stalls too. Unfortunately, the wee independent shops that connect the indoor market to The Strand seem to be all closing down. As too are the shops in the pedestrianised shopping mall, which should be knocked down & rebuilt from scratch. More of a ghost town than a town centre. 
There are however, a post office, train station, big supermarkets Lidl and Tesco, Pet's at Home, Curry's, Next, Argos TKMax, Matalan, B&M, Wilko, Sports Direct, Potteries chimneys, cemeteries and lots of solicitor's firms etc so it's not completely dead. Lots of room for improvement.
Apparently the council are aiming to make it fit for tourists in the coming years. Can't see it myself. But they are presently revamping the Town Hall. And The Ghlost House café is a good edition too. Both are lovely buildings. So who knows...

Pointless. Why doesn't Thameslink go all the way to the airport? Why do they only accept cash for the bus? Why does the bus even exist? Our outward journey was stressful because Thameslink had a melt down and all the trains were cancelled.

Now on the return I'm sat in an expensive Uber because it's 1 in the morning, the bus left and there isn't one for another hour. That's £50 for a taxi, and our return fair from the airport to London wasted. Our 2 return flights to Croatia didn't cost much more than that.

Really not fond of this station at all. Whilst it has facilities that are more than plentiful such as step free access with lifts, shops, ticket office and toilets, the services provided here is absolutely terrible. Cancellations and late running Thameslink trains are commonplace.

As with all request stops please remember the following -:
1) If you are on the train and wish to alight/get off then always tell the conductor or guard (communicates with the driver)

Lye train station is so convenient for Birmingham or Worcester which means no traffic jams or paying expensive car parking charges. People moan about the train service but if you’re delayed here it’s only for a few minutes

Incredibly basic station here with minimal facilities, seating and shelter on either platform. Step free access is available on both platforms but the ticket machine only accepts card payments. The station has a car park and is served by about two trains an hour.
Basic station, fairly regular trains through to Birmingham, Stratford and Stourbridge.
Not all trains stop here
Relaxed atmosphere, scenic harbour and coastal views with a Costa cafe open to the public in the ferry terminal building and lots of boats to see and a regular train service on the doorstep too.

Very few facilities as a station but it's main purpose however is to connect with the ferry linking to the Isle of Wight so it's hard to be that angry with the station overall. Trains serve here every half an hour Monday to Sunday.

Da qui partono i traghetti per l'isola di Wight, costosissimi (noi abbiamo pagato 70 pounds per 2 persone con auto utilitaria). Il viaggio in traghetto è durato una ventina di minuti. Al banco per l'acquisto dei tickets l'impiegata era antipatica e carente d'informazioni, tant'è che ci ha riferito di dover aspettare più di 2 ore per l'imbarco, avendo poi noi scoperto che non era vero, quindi abbiamo perso il primo traghetto disponibile (e alla fine siamo partiti un'ora dopo e non 2). In ogni caso, se siete alla ricerca di scogliere emozionanti e paesaggi panoramici, ve la sconsiglio: è solo un'isola piena di attrazioni commerciali, adatta a chi non sa come buttare i suoi soldi.

Great station and town. Went to a barbers called Jack Rabbits who were far better than the London shops I'd been to. Awesome. 😃

A great rail station to visit if you are into railways! One of the most unique ones in the UK. As another reviewer has said, the public can access the station now, you do not need to be on business at the base anymore to get on/off here. There is a public footpath that goes between the boundary of the commando base and the railway line. The footpath to the station is accessible from Exton Station from the north and Lympstone Village Station from the south.

The distance between this station and Exton Station must be one of the shortest in the UK which makes for a unique journey if you want to do that.

For the commandos themselves there is a guarded gate at the bottom of the base which provides access to the public footpath and therefore the station.

A somewhat unique rail station that adjoins the Exe Estuary Trail path and gives access to the Marine military base across the path. The station is gated, but contrary to popular belief you may use it to entrain or alight from the Evocet Line trains. Note, this is a request stop halt for the train. A must-do for any serious station gricer.
Decent station, for a reqeust station.
Beautiful Riverside village on the Exe Estuary Trail with a peaceful atmosphere and lovely pubs and cafe.
Friendly people. Nice village.
Standard branch line station but well-looked after with a very pretty flower-bed. There is a shelter for waiting and help-point if you need information.

Basic station with a covered seated area and not very much else. Main problem is that there are not many trains. One per hour each way. Need to time your arrivals at the station with the train and do your waiting in a local cafe or pub.
Pretty basic and dull.

Lytham railway station is on the South Fylde Line. Trains stop here en route way to Blackpool South and Preston stations. It has one platform in use. There is no ticket office or ticket machine but tickets can be purchased on board the train. There is a small shelter with seats on the platform. A defibrillator is located at the station entrance.
A wonderful little town...

Many thanks for assistance provided on my trip to and from Southampton recently. I was escorted to and from  the very door of my trains on both journeys with pleasant efficiency.

Unpleasant experience today at Macclesfield station. My husband and I were commuting from Piccadilly. On arrival my husband realised he’d left his ticket on the train helping a lady with her luggage. On presenting my ticket the conductor said that tgr ticket was not valid as I’d used a Virgin train ticket to commute on a Northern Rail train.  OK so we made a mistake and duly paid for two further tickets. The nice lady at the ticket kiosk said it would cheaper to buy two return tickets even though we wouldn’t get to use the return part. So what happened next is what I really find most disgusting. I offer my return tickets to two passengers who are going to Piccadilly only to be told that they are not transferable and can only be used by the purchaser. The conductor Gareth says I should check the terms and conditions of travel. So are they saying I can’t buy a ticket for someone else? They have my money, I have two tickets I can’t use and they say I can’t pass this on to someone else. Is this correct?
Excellent service as a disabled person I couldn’t fault them from start to finish they were more than helpful & would go as far to say to any disabled  person use this service.
Very friendly ticket office and a great view from the platform while you wait

Please make sure you travel in the correct part of the train as trains split here
