Good clean and safe. The staff here are quick, friendly and helpful. Well done!
Decent station opens out onto a nice park and pretty council building.
Small but quaint station
Not enough parking to accomodate and no alternatives close by. A significant issue that makes the commute a nightmare. Avoid if possible.
The man at the ticket office was very friendly help me refund wrong tickets without being rude and was very friendly.

On the whole the service is acceptable. There is a limited high speed service available although this is at certain times. The ticket office is only manned for half of the time and early morning can be a tight squeeze for everyone to get a ticket from the machine, before the train arrives. There is limited seating and protection from the weather. The station is looking rather tired too.

It's a very basic stations which serves it's purpose. There is ample shelter away from wet weather (however the pigeons also use this as their home so it can be messy) and the recent introduction of a grab and go coffee shop is great. The station is home to a ticket office however this is intermitinently open. There is also one self service ticket machine to collect tickets from.
An attractive historic railway station on the scenic Medway Valley Line.
Bland
Great place to see the Hogwarts Express, ferry station for skye, plenty of places to eat,

West Coast Railways is an authentic steam engine that is a wonderful ride! Most folks will remember the "Harry Potter Train" and the entire trip is -- well -- steam filled in tunnels and sometimes some ash will find your hair. Plenty of warning before going over the beautiful bridge.
Beautiful town,'beautiful little train station.  I'll definitely be back.
Love this little place. Travelled here by train, but sadly the weather wasn't too good so couldn't see it in its full glory. Not many places where open in February as it was pre-season.
Absolutely stunning place love it

Nice little town station great for going from Scarborough to York it’s always not busy even at rush hour not many people get off nice benches indoor and out on the platform there is a nice restaurant/cafe great location next to a clinic and Asda even better there is a lot of parking a great little train station
A nice clean station plenty of places to sit
It's the centre of the universe
Lovely country station. Friendly staff and low cost parking. Great choice for local commuters!

As a visitor to the area I arranged to pick someone up from this station,  only 1 short stay space the rest  charged at a daily rate, also has about 10 empty taxi only spaces.  Would have given zero stars  if I could.  My first and last time in Malton, not at all welcoming.

I have always found the ticket office staff particularly helpful when arranging travel. Online tickets are easily purchased, but nothing beats a face-to-face chat with efficient, helpful staff. Thank you. Karen Thomas
Second best station in Malvern :)
Would be good if there was ever anyone on duty.

My husband and I landed into Terminal 2 today and walked to the station for our train.  I asked a Team Leader (I think his name  was Mike Falini, for some help).  He was absolutely brilliant with us, he took our large cases and stayed with us til the train arrived, then put the cases on the train for us.  Excellent service from this man, sorry if I have his name wrong.

Can anyone please tell me if there are luggage trollies at the station to transfer my bags to departures??? Thank you in anticipation.
Brenda x x
The staff are awesome can't beat northern hospitality

Flight was early so we had a train ticket which meant a wait of 2 hours. Due to unseasonal weather it was extremely cold and we were told a ticket for an earlier train would be an additional charge of £19 despite being an off-peak time. We will be driving next time as this is now a more financially viable option.
Good place but charges for trollies to go to the bus/train station using skyline. Completely dead place in midnight!

If i could give zero stars i would. You cant exit or enter the station when busy due to the pathetic number of turnstiles. The ones you have are so slow!!!!! God help anyone on this station in an emergency as you have no chance of getting to safety!!! Sort it out

This place is so dirty!! Shame I can’t upload photos. In the gents toilets there was a big dirty green spit and and an empty “cocaine” bag. It seemed like the gents hadn’t been cleaned in over a week at least.
The station is dated and all seating is outside so whilst waiting nearly an hour to connect to my next train I was freezing.
There is no 1st class lounge either so absolutely no point upgrading if this is one of your reasons.
Into the station on the train there is a bottle knock so don’t be surprised if you’re late either whether in or out
Gormless staff unable to organise anything. I can see why this station is the worst in the UK.

I was waiting for a train to Chester on platform 4 when a massive gush of wind blew one of my bags onto the middle of the track, I panicked since a few items worth a lot of money were in there and i went straight to a member of staff about my bags, and they tried to get it with a litter grabber, which unfortunately wasn't long enough to grab my bag in the middle of the track. despite not being able to get it, the staff were all super helpful and nice to me, despite it being my own fault for not keeping a hold of my bag. But when i was writing down my details for getting my bag back when an engineer was on shift to retrieve it, an engineer came around the corner, and was asked to get my bag for me, which he did! I would like to thank the staff again at Manchester Oxford Road Station, for being extremely helpful and kind! It really made my day and I appreciate all you guys do!

What a farce!! I appreciate that trains get delayed but when station staff tell three disabled passengers to change platforms (up and down two flights of stairs) and the train leaves from a different platform, not just once but three times, you can understand why we chose not to believe them again!! What about the Disability Rights Act!! 
We finally got onto a train 3 hours later!!!
I would have scored this no stars but wouldn’t have been able to enter a review!

Didn't announce cancellation of my train, then told me the wrong information so that I missed my next train.
This has to be the worst station in Manchester 
Always late should be the moto

I was walking an old lady who was blind to a train on platform 5.  It was a cross country train.  I helped her up the step onto the train.  With her half way in the train door automatically closed on her knocking her to the ground where she now lay.  A staff member ambled over.  I asked the staff member for help.  The lady eho was blind said she was fine but i thought she was in shock having just been knocked off a train by the train door and was not fine.  I had my own train to catch on a different platform.  I asked the staff member for help and she refused to help.  If i had been knocked from a train and fallen to the ground and not able to see then i would seek reassurance.  I am deeply disappointed by the staff member and the lack of help from another staff member at the barrier.  The station itself is nice but the service today was despicable
Visiting on business. Not a bad station but I prefer Birmingham New St. The people are friendlier there when trying to navigate surroundings.

Gate staff more interested in discussing weekend plans and blocking access to help or let passengers on trains. toilets that smell like someone has been gutting rotting fish. A near constant change of platforms like a dismal game of musical chairs. Avoid at all cost.

A lovely gentleman working helped us find our platform, walked us there and even came back found us on the train  and showed us the route on his phone with time we would be arriving.  Superb service. Thurs. 29th, Aug.

The new roof is nice - at least since they fixed its dangerous leaking - but the area where you wait for your train is ugly, dark , dingy, stinks of diesel, and very confusing with poor signage and no easy to find live information on platform. Means it's easy for many people to get the wrong train, as we saw today.

Not too much to do here, but the connections to city trams are very good. This means it is easy to get into the city. I will be forever grateful for staff that let me stay on a train coming here despite the fact I had bought the wrong ticket.

My son who has special needs left his laptop on the concourse and only realised when the train was about to leave so we had to get off the train as he was very upset and the staff in the information centre were very good and very helpful could not do more for us and really put his mind at ease and found his laptop I want to thank them for making his day

Beautiful old building and friendly staff at Manchester Victoria Station. You can reach anywhere in England from here, Lancashire, Yorkshire, Midlands, London, etc and beyond. 

There’s a Costa Coffee and a pub, a few stalls with food vendors and a beautiful memorial of the Manchester Attack in May 2017 (see photo). 

The street circulation around the station has recently changed, so some drivers will have a difficult time to pick up and drop off at be station. Make sure you coordinate with your friends or family if they are coming to get you. 

If you have extra time at the station
take a walk in the surrounding area or shopping district.
It's an easy station to transfer trains on (although lifts are currently out of action) but for a mainline station the facilities are quite lacking
Really a halt rather than a station but well maintained
A small basic railway station with a shed for shelter when waiting for a train.

Seems like a nice looking station with newly installed lifts to provide step free access to the platform towards Ipswich. Has toilets, a ticket office, cafe and a large car park however trains towards Harwich aren't very frequent, usually once per hour.
One of my favourite walks starts and finishes at this great station.Watch-out for the cold north east winds in winter !

Very poor experience with this station today. All the trains from Ipswich to Colchester were cancelled due to some problem with the overhead wiring- which is understandable. My main problem was that they said they had replacement buses to Colchester or Ipswich, however, I have been waiting for 45 minutes, and still a bus has not come. When I asked the staff at the station, they were not cooperative and were unhelpful- borderline rude to be honest! If I ever come here again I expect a big improvement.
There's a lovely warm waiting area here with very comfortable seating and air conditioning. The station is well serviced with disabled access and a refreshment bar.
Not bad, but during rush hour in morning and evening the approach to the car park and the roundabout outside the station become a nightmare!
Never open, makes getting to work more stressful
Great

Perhaps the most boring station on the entire Merseyrail network, the lack of staff meant, in the past, you could avoid buying a ticket then claim to have come from Manor Road on arrival at your destination (only really worth it if going to West Kirby otherwise the risks outweighed the potential savings) I have no idea if you can still get away with this money saving tip though
Small station at Hoylake with one staff member. Neat and clean but with not much essential facilities.
Awful. Access only by footbridge. No use whatsoever for disabled passengers or those with prams or buggies.
Ok

Parking is great, what let's it down is the upkeep of the bridge, stairs and ramps. They are run down with indents all over you have no choice but to get wet going through puddles. However, you take your life in your hands if it's icy. I've fallen over 2x in the past and going down the steps is like a piece out of running man or gladiators.

Nice little station hidden away at the end of a long driveway. Good open air platform seating and an excellent tea/coffee and snack bar situated next to the huge car park. This station does not have a ticket machine or toilet facilities.

Well-serviced and well-maintained station. Waiting rooms, toilets and ticket office close pretty early in the day but there are now more ticket machines. NCP car parking which is a bit of a pain.

It's a very good station for a mixed load of trains

A bit mucky when I went. There's a shop on the station which never seems to be open, but it's not an inherently bad place, just nothing to write home about.

Impeccable service ! Arrived a few minutes before the next train to London.
Bought 2 roundtrip tickets and asked how to pay for parking my car on the lot.
Lady in the boot replied: I will fix that for you. She went as far as stick the parkingvoucher on my windshield so we could board the train in time.
The regular staff member is very helpful and friendly.
Was lucky enough to witness a double arched rainbow and the glare of the sun through the rain.
What now feels like a long time ago this station had Aldous & Campbell classics.  Now long forgotten and the modern lifts are complete rubbish.
Decent station.

On Monday the 21st i came home to Margate from London arriving at approx 1540 hrs, not being well lately I took my time getting round to platform 1, where I realised I had left a parcel back on the train, I contacted a member of the platform staff, explained my problem, he without hesitation told me to sit and wait while he went and found my parcel, Hé did this quickly politely and without any fuss, many many thanks to you people at Margate train station,.
Helpful staff at station

Helpful platform staff, ticket office staff sometimes less so, only one ticket window and sometimes a queue there and at the one ticket machine. Risky to arrive with no time 
to spare if you're buying or collecting tickets.

Although it is a nice little station, it is awful for Disabled Access, (London bound) and they don’t provide discounted parking for disabled blue badge holders, even though the only way to get on to the platform in a wheelchair is through the car park, which is quite a way around the back of the station. It is really disappointing. A lack of accessibility across most train stations, seems to be standard :(

Leicester been Market Harborough Station Platform 1 and 2 for London and Nottingham By Derby and Sheffield trip ticket prices great service we have station at Market Harborough both everyone that great new stations platforms

Step free access is only possible for trains to Leicester and facilities like toilets are only located on the Leicester bound platform too. Both platforms have seating and a waiting room, but the London bound platform is really short. Trains stop far from the entrance towards Leicester.

Very good, simple railway station. 2 platforms/ 2 x covered seating areas. LOVELY PLANTERS! WHICH ARE MAINTAINED BEAUTIFULLY. Abusive man lives behind/ next to the station, has 2 black, aggressive dogs running free and who DO NOT come to his calling. Very distressing and frightening.

- Well maintained and cared for by the station group
Also has 2 help points if you ever need to contact the train company
Nice station and well maintained
The only station in market rasen not much comes through

Mr. Thomas was Very unhelpful staff. Very disappointed.
Decent enough train station, have never seen it busy here

a lovely little station the size of a bus stop. quite surprised how small it was when i got there. its a bit far from the river if your going on the Thames walk from marlow bridge. but very memorable as it must be one of the smallest station's in Britain.

This train station is used mainly for passengers heading over towards Manchester or towards the Huddersfield direction. 

There are three platforms and each platform has a covered seating area for people to wait for their trains. 

There is car parking space nearby but there is only about 5 spaces for cars and maybe one or two disabled car spots as well. There is no where for passengers to leave their push bikes. 

The train station is also used by people who intend to walk or hike around the area, or who are visiting the nearby canal which is only a matter of feet away from the train station.
It is a station. the trains to Middlesbrough and Darlington are too slow but they are half hourly

Every day something is wrong. They close the station every other day, the oyster card machine doesn't work and the ticket office is staffed by people who either don't care or have an issue with the public, with sarcastic and condescending remarks, and leaving the office to take a break leaving it with no staff, and customers waiting to top up their travel tickets. That's before you have even tried to get on a train. The trains are over packed and the Maryland staff do not try to help people bord. For those unwilling to fight to bord the train, realistically you are not going to get anywhere before 8:50.
Apart from station staff, the morning service is unreliable and a step back for this modern age, hope they act together, we paying customers, im not one to complain but i have to

One member of staff helped me out today. There are no lifts and I needed the underground, a tall mixed race guy who worked there came over and helped me take my baby boy in his buggy down the escalator, he knew there was about 10 steps after, so he walked with me, helped me carry the buggy down the stairs and made sure I got the platform ok. It's people like this, that make the world a better place. He didn't have to help me at all, but he did.

Lovely old fashioned English station - famous for The Beatles' Hard Day's Night film - you'd never think this was a central London terminus...took a pleasant journey up into the Chiltern Hills & out to Aylesbury from here...helpful train driver pointed me in the right direction for my train...& there's an M&S Food...
Nice and tidy station. Friendly staff, lots of shops. Did you know you can buy your tickets up to 5 times cheaper if you buy on-line?

Stinks of diesel fumes, which means it has high concentration of air pollution particles and is not the healthiest of stations. I'm surprised the line hasn't been electrified yet and that Chiltern Railways are not making any visible effort to reduce emissions and local air pollution. Of course, travelling by train is overall better than travelling by car, but certainly there is a lot to be desired here. 
Otherwise, the station has very fast and convenient links and is pretty.

Great station except for one thing:  they do not announce the platform the train is leaving from until very shortly before it is due to depart...  Then everyone has to run to the platform and there is a terrible scrum.  If you are in the least bit disabled, or have heavy luggage, this is very unpleasant.  Why can't they announce the platform well in advance?  On European trains, the platform is even printed on the ticket, so you can go there calmly and in good time.
Love this shop, go there everyday, lovely staff

Free limited parking, a short walk from the bus stops on Crosby Street.
Limited facilities at this unmanned station, although you can buy or collect tickets from the machine.
A recently rebuilt railway station. Class 37 hauled passenger trains pass through daily and there's a number of steam specials passing through each year.
I Think Matlock is A Really nice place Because Of the Cable carts and Arcades but The Train station is Not Big Nuff because  Sometimes it's  Really busy to Derby.

Horrendous parking. No one there to advise if it's full due to visitors at the Heights of Abraham attraction nearby. Cars were coming in but were stuck inside due to lack of management. You could see parking personnel checking cars were displaying tickets but were not bothered to help sort out the traffic jam due to cars entering the parking space even though it was full. 

The authorities interested in making as much money from parking tickets but not interested in welfare of visitors.

There is a car park about 15 min walk away, recommend that to anyone going to Abraham heights instead of Matlock Bath rail station car park
Beautiful landscape. Great time out with family.

There is also loads of crap on the tracks such as purple-pink pillows, cans of Irn-Bru and other trash. Station needs a big cleanup and bringing back the second platform would be useful! The station is busy 2 or 3 times throughout the day but there has been times where I was the only one waiting at the platform, so I don't really mind that there is no ticket office. Getting a lot better service and improvements thanks to the TransWilts partnership. Basis frequency of one train each way every hour to either Swindon or Westbury. Great little station which serves the much needing town of Melksham in Wiltshire.

Small covered but open waiting shelter and bike rack, though amything with wheels must be carried down the stairs. As a local who lives near this station, I find this station is unreliable and more of a nuisance. Trains are very infrequent at this station (trains to victoria come like once every 25-30 minutes), and the road gate/bridge is annoying as hell. The gate closes the road for like 10 minutes; causing unneeded traffic, and all of this traffic is caused just by a train needing to cross the road which takes seconds. Furthermore, while trains are infrequent stopping at this station, trains from elsewhere frequently run pass this station; causing the road gates to close even more frequently. I've been using this road many times when getting to the other side of the road with this station's ineffective and inconsiderate gates, and it takes more than 20 minutes just trying to get to the other side of the road's gates; this is because those gates start building a big traffic, all thanks to how frequent the gates close, and because the gates stay closed for like 10 minutes. 50% of the time the road is closed because of how long those nuisance gates stay closed for. No wonder half the road is empty while the other side/lane of the road always has traffic...

Morfa Mawddach Train station is an unmanned request stop on the Cambrian train line, with trains inland to Birmingham international via Machynlleth, Aberystwyth on the west coast and north to Pwllheli. You have to wave the driver to request the train to collect you on the platform, and alert the conductor upon alighting for the train to stop. You can buy your tickets on the train. Morfa has a free car park and a public toilets open during the holidays, with an easy access loo. There are no littler bins in the area due to rubbish attracting wildlife like foxes. Visitors are encouraged to help keep the area clean by taking litter away when they leave.

To get off the train here you need to ask the conductor on the train. To get on the train, you need to make your intent clear by putting your arm out. You will usually know when the driver acknowledges your request bye sounding the horn

This station is a request stop and in order for the train to stop is to tell the conducter of the train and if you are on the platform you must make your intent clear. This station used to be a junction and the trail is the remnants of that railway line

This is a train station suitable and built for able-bodied persons. If you are disabled or wheelchaired bound avoid this train station like the plague. There is no lift system here or anything that can assist the disabled to cross over to the other platform. This station is also manned on a part-time basis. There is no ticket machine on either sides of both platforms. There is a ticket conductor on the trains who will be able to assist you with ticket issues. I noticed that there are CCTV installed cameras and emergency/assist machine to enable comunication between yourself and train staff elsewhere. I found this station to be primative in design and lacking the most basic of facilities to aid the modern day traveller.

To be fair to the train company -the station is nowhere near the village, which has a good bus service to Reading. Surprised this station survived Beeching.

The Newcourt Railway Station is situated between Liberty Way and Jack Sadler Way alongside the central community area.  (Please note that the current map position shown here is incorrect, too far North along Liberty Way.)
The address as displayed on the new platform is Newcourt Station Road (Devon Metro), Exeter  EX2 7FR.
As of 31st May 2015, the expected opening date is Thursday 4th June 2015; however, planned industrial action for 4th and 5th June may delay this.
This station is an ideal 'get off' point for the new Newcourt Community Centre, Blakeslee Drive, with its excellent accommodation and facilities.
Please see station development progress on FriendsOfNewcourtStation - FONS website / Facebook pages.

This station is just so bad. There's too few trains to Cambridge and back, the trains are always late, and the trains are always packed to the brim when/if it does arrive. This is my only route to work and so it hugely affects me when the train is delayed by 20 minutes again.. It's also impossible to read the sign after any rain to see when the next train is due to arrive. It's ridiculous, and as I write this, I'm currently standing on the train, wedged in like sardines, and delayed as usual.
All right, but... Famous town like this deserves more character here...

Basic, though quite pleasant station with small fee car park for rail users on one side and a golf course on the other. Partially open waiting shelters on both platforms with a single ticket machine on the eastbound side.  Before boarding a train passengers must obtain either a ticket or “Promise to Pay” voucher, the latter being required if you want to pay later in cash as the machine only accept cards. Whilst there are ramps up to both platforms, wheelchair users will find that if they wish to travel in the direction of Bishop Auckland and need to buy a ticket first, itʼs a rather long trek from one platform to the other via the road bridge a few hundred metres away. Fortunately, for those who can use it a footbridge is provided to avoid this inconvenience. No staff on site or toilet facilities (so inconvenience all round on that front).
Handy little station travelling all the way to Saltburn if required. Nice flat walk over to Shildon approx 2 miles and the Railway Museum

Nice and local however no disable access for the Manchester direction... if it wasn’t for the help of the person selling the tickets I’d be knackered trying to get my baby up the steps... next station is quite far for me

Despite being operated by Southern, trains are hourly and usually on time (providing that they are running at all.
Platform dates from the 1960’s and is short, only able to serve three carriages of a train. There are convenient shelters on the platforms to keep would-be passengers dry and out the wind. 
The Star Inn is less that two furlongs up the road, which serves excellent food.

This station is barely more than two platforms, with a shelter and a help point on each one. 

Services are regular during weekdays. At the time of my visit at the beginning of April 2018, there were no weekend services, although there were regular tannoy announcements informing the public of a new timetable from 21st May 2018. I would imagine this will include weekend service for the summer season, but check before you travel.

There are no toilets at the station, but there are some located a few minutes walk to the south, on the way to the beach.

The beach is private in places, and about a ten minute walk from the station, if that. There are no facilities other than the toilets, so take what you need if you are visiting for a day at the beach. And whatever you do, check the time of the last train.

There is a nearby camp site with a small shop, but it is private, according to signage.

The station is on the main south coast line between Eastbourne and Hastings.

There is a nearby pub, The Star Inn, if you turn left upon leaving the station ( north ), and turn right at the T junction, towards the east. It offers a good menu and has a very nice garden, suitable for children. There is a baby changing room there.  The pub has many photos and reviews on Google Maps- I've always found it to be pleasant and welcoming.
Very few trains call here.

The electronic sign posts are frequently broken and or not working. Platform 1 is for trains to Leeds. Platform 2 is for Wakefield and outward bound trains from Leeds.  Recommend using electronic ticket machine if catching the 7:33 to leeds to ensure you have a ticket when you arrive in leeds as the ticket point inside leeds station can be very very busy at times.

the 7:33 train is often packed, leaving standing room only and little to no chance of purchasing a ticket once on the train.

North Berwick is the rail terminus for trains from Edinburgh. This quaint little station has some covered seating and also a car park. The ScotRail trains using this station are well maintained and clean. ScotRail operates an hourly service on most days of the week.

Such a beautiful town / resort. The weather was sunny, hardly a cloud in the sky. Lots of colour in the tree's, shrubs and flowers. A walk / scramble up the maw, then a stroll down to the beach through the marsh, trees, gardens and parkland. A real hidden gem.

The ticket office has limited hours but you can buy a ticket from the machines at other times. If running late for a Gatwick bound train, be careful not to get trapped behind the level crossing barrier

A small station but has good connections to Edinburgh which is a short 20 minute journey from here. A little walk down to the harbour from here and a relatively steep 20% incline on the way back but it's totally worth it for the iconic views of the Forth Bridge.

It is not a mainline it's just a little station with northern trains. There are usally a lot of pacers there. Tip: you can tell if a line is a mainline because there is a little thing for a pantograph on the top. If it doesn't have one it means it is not a mainline.

North Road Station is a very suburban station with nothing more than a platform with train services to Bishop Auckland and Saltburn via Darlington Bank Top. Around the station is now a great new retail park. Where you can do plenty of food shopping at Iceland, aldi, morrisons, Greggs and Pound Stretcher. Plus many more retailers. 
The station is also home to Head Of Steam. The museum that celebrates Darlington's railways heritage. And they also have many special events such as model railway exhibitions, lego exhibitions and various vintage vehicle events. 
Also on the land is the home of the A1 trust. The guys who build brand new steam engines.  So popular in and see them and give them a donation so they can keep up there amazing work.

This is very basic Zone 3 station without step free access. The staff are friendly when manned. Fast trains do not stop here and there are not too many seating places probably very few use this station. If you want step free access with coffee shop and eateries please use the nearby Richmond station in Zone 4.
PS: On clear days, from the station you can see upto three flights flying one behind other to land in Heathrow!

Many comments here are polite. This is the easily one of the shabbiest station I've seen in this country. Especially accessibility. Strange as I don't think the problem is that difficult to solve though it is left to what it is today.

This is a good place to go to if you have any feet or foot problems, it's not always instant as some foot ailments take time to clear up and heal ,there is sometimes a small amount of pain ❗but the gain to be fully recovered is worth it, they have kept me mobile for the past 8 years or so, and worth every penny. Very helpful and friendly service -that makes a big difference. 👍👣✔.

why cant i walk on the tracks !!!!

Agree with the comments regarding unhelpful staff. In my experience, the staff who are supposed to monitor the ticket barriers are more of hindrance than a help. Two of them were blocking a gate each while gossiping amongst themselves. With their backs to the growing line of customers who couldn’t get through the automated barriers, they were paying no attention whatsoever. When they finally realized how many people needed their assistance they seemed deliberately slow, awkward and rude, because we had disturbed the little chit-chat.

This says to me - very poor management. Monitoring ticket barriers may be a boring job, but if the staff aren’t paying attention it’s just totally pointless. We could have all just jumped over and they probably wouldn’t have even noticed as they were so engrossed in their gossiping! They need to be on-the-ball. For both security AND customer service reasons.

I have to agree with the other reviews mentioning the unhelpful staff. The station was unbearably busy because the old jobsworth on the ticket barriers wasn’t allowing anyone on the platform until 5 minutes before their train arrived. This then caused a chaotic bottleneck when everyone flooded through at once. Really unintelligent staff.

Station is improved, but car parking is frankly a joke. Have spent up to 80 minutes driving around / waiting for a space. Unless you travel very early AM or after lunch, find another option because mid AM parking is nigh on impossible. 

Note the 'temporary' multi level car park could easily be expanded to add a further level on top given that it's akin to heavy duty meccano. Quite why no one has bothered to do this yet and alleviate some of the obvious shortfall in parking spaces is beyond me.

As you approach Nunhead Station there is very little to recommend it, let's be honest, it looks grotty from the outside. Yet a surprise awaits. 
As you ascend the stairs and glance to your right you are treated to an unexpectedly superb view of the Canary Wharf skyline - which seems to leap out at you.

Furthermore, this station, tucked away in a small corner of Nunhead, has excellent links to the city.

It's a little rugged and unkempt  with no public toilets (hence 3 stars) but it's a vital and well used station for the local area.

Oh yes, the small tuck shop on the platform is very handy and reasonably priced - serving hot drinks, pastries etc.

Handy!
convenient in and out of london.

The London Underground is a public rapid transit system in the United Kingdom that serves a large part of Greater London and the home counties of Essex, Hertfordshire and Buckinghamshire. It has many former stations, while others were planned but never formally opened for public use. Some stations were closed down due to low levels of passengers usage rendering them uneconomical; some became redundant after lines were re-routed or replacements were constructed; and others are no longer served by the Underground but remain open to National Rail main line services. Many stations were planned as parts of new lines or extensions to existing ones but were later abandoned.

This is a great little, almost country style mainline junction station with the Newquay branch line and St.Blazey depot lines diverging here. Such a great station where the staff are BRILLIANT! Special shout out for Barry and Keeley in particular who are amazing.  Well kept, clean and always well maintained. Parking fantastic. Full of character.  Well done everyone at Par Train station you’re a credit to the Railway network! :)

The main point at Par is its connection to the Newquay service.

Unfortunately as most travellers are arriving westbound from the Paddington direction, they need to cross over the footbridge to get to the Newquay platform.

The footbridge has 25 steps either side and no lifts.

Worth bearing in mind if you have heavy suitcases. If you have trouble taking stairs or use a wheelchair, make enquiries before departure to find out what alternatives there are.

St. Austell, the next stop, has lifts, but if you change there and come back to Par, you'll miss the connection.

Returning back towards London is much simpler and only entails crossing the platform to connect.

The London side has a waiting room and covered area. The Penzance side has seating, some canopy over the platform, the ticket office, toilets, way out, free car parking (for about 60 cars) and taxis.
Lovely busy station and connections to Newquay London and penzance

This railway station sits on the railway line that runs towards Southport in one direction and towards Manchester in the other direction.

Firstly, I must say I would love to have given this railway station a 5-star rating because it really deserves it - but I couldn't, simply because there is absolutely no way at all to park your car which is rather annoying I must admit.

The overall feel of the place and look at the place is nice and is pleasing on the eye so it is a welcoming site for anyone wanting to visit and border train here at parbold.

This railway station does have a bike rack which can accommodate about 4 or 5 bicycles.

Right beside the bike rack is a payment terminal where you can buy your tickets for your onward travel at this railway station. If you prefer a more human touch there is a ticket office located in what was probably at the old stationmasters building.

This station is covered by an ample amount of security in terms of closed circuit television cameras.

On my visit here I could not see any digital information displays to help passengers understand when the next train might be arriving. Instead this station has onboard platform loudspeakers to announce the arrival of the next train due at parbold.

Both platforms at parbold do have covered seating areas in the unlikely event that the weather isn't quite so good when you're waiting for your train.

Even though there is no parking areas for anyone at this railway station at least it does have good disabled access via ramps leading up to both platforms.

I must finish this off by saying that this railway station has a nice feel about it and it is nicely presented in terms of the way it looks and I especially liked the hanging baskets of flowers and the flowers that were also located behind the parbold railway station sign. OK, to some it might seem irrelevant as to whether a station looks nice or not, because the bottom line is you're using the train station to get on board a train aren't you, but at the very least it leaves a pleasant memory of your time when you visited or passed through parbold railway station.

I got the train from Hamilton and met my Girlfriend. She told me about Ruby Roo had just opened. We went there and looked at the menu on the window. The guy seen us looking and come out and invited us both in. As we walked in, the place looked very nice indeed. We were asked if we wanted a table just in the door or go upstairs. We went upstairs and there were only a few tables there. All the tables were set out just nice. We were given a menu to chose out meal. I didn't need one as I knew what I wanted. We got our drinks as per usual. Service here was real good. Quick and fast. We didn't wait long for our meal to come. My Girlfriend got a Burger meal and I got a chicken tikka meal, very well presented. My Goodness me. Was that chicken tikka good. Noooo. It was wonderful. It was tasty. Onions. Were tasty. Yes. Rice was good. Oh yes. Gravy sauce. Magic and tasty. The Chicken. Well ohh yess beeeeautiful. Hot and tasty too. It was delicious. If you ever want a chicken tikka Ruby Roo is the place to go. The costume was good and friendly. Well looked after. We even had a wee chat with the manager too. 10 out of 10 Ruby Roo.  Fantastic. I will be going there again next time I go through to Partick. Quite pleasant in nice weather, which is just as well as there is only one service in each direction in the morning and the same in the evening so you could be waiting a very long time for a train – especially on Sunday when there are no services at all. However, in the cold or rain you wouldn't want to hang around on the southbound platform as the waiting shelter provides very little protection from the elements and even this small luxury is denied passengers travelling in the opposite direction. All one can really say is that anyone here with a season ticket – if indeed there are any – is getting a very bad deal indeed!!

This railway station sits on the line between Wigan in the one direction and ormskirk and Southport in the other direction.

I might have given this station a 4-star rating except for for the basic fact that there is no car parking facilities here whatsoever. And there is no area for people to be dropped off here either.

The station has no on-site staff but at least it does have a help point where you can get in contact with somebody if you need to do.

The station also does have digital departure boards on both platforms which is good.

What is also good here is the amount of closed-circuit television cameras for security purposes.

The station does have areas where people can sit down, in the open air, or they can stand underneath a covered waiting area, although there are no seats in these shelters.

Also, there is no facility for bike users to store their bikes, because there is no bike rack.

You can can buy your tickets here, from a digital payment terminal, but if you cannot use this facility, you will have to either buy a ticket beforehand, or buy one on the train on your journey.

There are plenty of of "keep pemberton railway station tidy" signs, and it does seem reasonably tidy here.

What a lovely little station. If you are travelling by train to Lydstep for example then this is your stop. If your able to there is a cliff top walk or if you’d rather, get a taxi for a 5 minute ride to the Caravan Park
The village is spotless tidy and clean. It's the  best keep village in Wales. With a friendly face. A beautiful well maintained village.
Excellent, station. A really helpful man in the ticket office, nothing to much trouble, giving choice of the best fares. Well done 👍
Just a quiet and small station in the town. Lucky enough to have a half hourly service, seating, shelter and step free access so I can't moan too much.

Clean, sheltered seating.  Bike rack. Trains every 15 mins to Cardiff central.  No toilets. Part time manned ticket booth. Limited parking that is free. Departure boards.  Wheelchair accessible.  Very close to town. Taxi place and newsagent etc yards away. If you are going to penarth do so by train as there is a severe shortage of parking.

The station staff are always helpful when buying tickets not just to Cardiff but all UK destinations and always try to get the cheapest price tickets. Just a pity it seems to be only staffed in the mornings.

Just a small shelter and a ticket machine. Toilets are available and lifts enable easy access to platforms. Tickets can be purchased at the staffed ticket office. Buses arrive at the stop outside the station serving routes to many of the favourite destinations in Cumbria.

An hour or so later, we were very pleasantly surprised when he offered us hot drinks and brought us some local snacks from the staff room. Lovely service and a beautiful station!

Pilning station is operated by Great Western Railway and is what is known as a Parliamentary station, with currently 2 trains on a Saturday going eastbound.  The reason for this is that the footbridge was taken down in  2016 as a result of the engineering and electrification works that are taking place in that area

The trains are operated by Great Western railway  

There is a campaign to get the footbridge back and also a better service (see campaign that is referred to on the other reviews)

This is a must to relieve pressure on the Severn Beach Line and also with the industrial units that are near by and I am sure regular services will serve the wider community

There fore there are limited and very basic services at the station with only a help point and a shelter

GWR will not get true numbers if tickets are not collected (when I used it I bought mine in advance and it was never checked!!)  Group proactive in looking into numbers at the station each week

It currently only has one platform and is a fair walk from the "village"

Beautiful village in the far north west of Scotland, situated in Lochalsh, Wester Ross. It is a place that I just love to visit. It has a small population numbering about 340 at the last cencus. There is a hotel, pub and a few B&B's in the village plus a general store. When the tide is out you can walk across a walkway to a small island where there is seating so you can enjoy a picnic if you like. Because it gets warm water from the Gulf Stream there are Palm trees planted along the shore making it really beautiful as you walk by. You can rent a bike to explore the scenic countryside or take a trip on boat to spot some seals. A really wonderful place to spend a few relaxing days.

Unattended four track rail station with generally one morning service and no serviceable platform 2 to return to. Express and freight regularly pass through on this busy Rugby - Stafford line. Remains of footbridge visible, but site of the old signal box now covered in grass.

The train station is located at the end of Shawlands and serves Shawlands, Newlands and Pollokshaws East with entrances on Kilmarnock Road (across from Tesco Metro and Papa Johns) and Coulstonholm Road (next to Newlands Job Centre).
Access is not wheelchair friendly at either entrance, one of the reasons why it didn't get 5 stars. The entrance at Kilmarnock Rd has long steps and can easily be accessed with a pram or bike without too much effort though and easier on arthritic joints. This entrance is clean and well lit giving access to the main road and the best train exit for access to the main shops and restaurants in Shawlands without getting lost if you are unfamiliar to the area. 
The Coulstonholm Rd entrance has lots of regular steps, pigeons and water ingress, it is not as well lit and I imagine it's difficult to maintain for Scotrail. This is the entrance I mainly use though for convenience.
Trains into central station are 3 an hour during the day off peak and reducing to 2 an hour evenings off peak and 1 an hour on Sundays. Peak times offer an extra service to and from the city.
The line serves Glasgow to Newton and is on the Cathcart circle with journey times into the city approximately 12minutes on the Newton line and 16 minutes for the Cathcart circle.
It is a very cost effective service, with a return to the city at £2.30 off peak and kids go free with the adult. Much cheaper than the bus if you don't have a monthly pass or you have kids in tow. For comparison, 1 adult and child, the bus is approximately £5.90 for the same journey.
The trains are quiet and clean and the actual station is well maintained and lit. 
You cannot pay cash at the ticket machine, but you can pay cash to the ticket inspector once on the train. Otherwise, there is a machine to purchase tickets with a bank card and it has a contactless facility. 
If you have purchased online national tickets for longer journeys around the country you are able to collect them anytime from this station. 
No toilets or snack facilities. 
There are two undercover areas, cctv, direct intercom to a member of rail staff to answer queries, signage is clear and understandable and it is well lit on the platforms. 
If the station had wheelchair access, more trains and Coulstonholm Rd entrance was bought up to a bright standard, I would definitely have no hesitation in giving 5 stars. Might suggest to them to rebuild that entrance with a lift for a wheelchair friendly solution. 
I would still highly recommend the train station.
Great station owned by Kim K's New kid

As far as the entrance goes, this must surely rank as one of the most picturesque and quaintest stations in the entire country, immediately adjacent to a wonderful bowling green and the quintessentially English village of Port Sunlight. The southbound platform, as the name suggests, is a real suntrap on a summer's day, but less inviting in winter as the shelter is narrow and completely open on one side. Access via stairs only to platforms.
Great architectural heritage and credit to Victorian industrialist and philanthropist. LORD Leverhulm.... Soaps etc....
Wonderful walk through the rose gardens, Warwickshire Memorial & past museum. Lovely Hillsborough memorial garden & walk through the dell & around Port Sunlight village.
Great village to visit
PLEASE DON'T CHANGE THIS RAILWAY STATION! Friendly staff. Quite waiting room.  located in the centre of the town. A highway on getting out and in of the town safely.
Easy enough to navigate with friendly members of staff and frequent trains to locations such as Swansea and Cardiff Central.
It's a nice station with a waiting room,information Bord and office,staff to help you and departure Bord

If you require information on journey times / connections just ask.

At the time of this review, a major section of the train station has been rebuilt (This includes the overpass connection from car park and in town towards the center two platforms). In my honest opinion, once the plaza in town has completed construction including the bus station, I believe the futuristic/modern style will reflect the building architecture around it. 

I've seen some plans of a newer building beginning construction on the foundation level nearby and it too, is a modern-style which will contain at least a cafe. Although a lot of people that have left negative reviews, I feel they may not be considering the bigger picture of what the area will look like when it's complete. I on the other hand will appreciate the fresh new look mixed with old Port Talbot stone building architecture, when I know others only appreciate older building architecture. A good balance between the two can work if the style is consistent and furthermore I believe the steelworks-style does work for the town.

However one key part which I would agree with others here is that the customer service from members of staff at the Port Talbot Parkway help desk are rude to customers. Which I've noticed isn't something new when it comes to station staff in this region. I'm sure they aren't really doing it on purpose, although being polite to them doesn't seem to make too much of a difference as it's possible there are other factors at play within their management.

Overall, it's not looking great at this time and It's quite sad to see staff unhappy while reflecting on the community around them. However, it's not something that stops me from getting where I need to go, it doesn't really change my mood, or ruin my day. However if you do happen to be visiting for the first time, it might be a real let-down for you, so I suggest not having high expectations for the station. It functions as intended, but overall it's nothing impressive.

Hope this review helps. 
( And there's me reviewing a train station xD )

Judging by some of the photos uploaded and the previous reviews written it seems some people have confused this railway station with the narrow gauge railway stations on the Ffestiniog and Highland Railways.  This is the "proper" station and lies on the Cambrian Coast line which runs between Birmingham and Shrewsbury in the east and Pwllheli in the West.  The station is just outside Porthmadog town centre and whilst it's a bit basic (one eastbound and one westbound platform) the old station building has been converted into a pub called the Station Inn so if you find yourself having to wait for a train there's somewhere on site to seek shelter.
A stunningly beautiful North Wales town in a stunningly beautiful part of Wales.

The railway station at Prees (on the border between Shropshire and Wales), has a railway level crossing nearby. 

There are two platforms at Prees railway station, one is for northbound trains heading towards Nantwich, whilst the other platform is for southbound trains heading towards Shrewsbury and beyond.

It appears to me, that Prees railway station is a quaint little place that is kept clean and tidy, and also has covered shelters where passengers can wait for the trains heading towards Nantwich or Shrewsbury. 

Someone has taken the effort to display a number of flower boxes around the platforms which adds a nice touch to the feel of the place. 

There does not appear to be anywhere for people to leave their bicycles, and it should also be noted that there is no official car parking spaces. Even so, there is a gravelled area near the northbound platform where passengers can be dropped off or picked up from.

However, there is a light at the end of the tunnel, albeit maybe 2 years away but to coincide with the Shakespeare Theatre the station is getting a makeover, which is long overdue!

Don't go in your car to the station or you may fall foul of the bus gate trap in Fishergate. This is a quaint little railway station, that sits on the railway line, that either heads towards Liverpool in one direction, or Wigan in the other.

The trains that run through this station are all run by the northern Rail train company. Freight trains do pass through this railway station at various times.

There are two platforms, one serving passengers bound for Liverpool and the other serving passengers heading towards Wigan and beyond.

There is a rail station car park beside the railway station which can accommodate between 6 and 8 cars although there are no particular spots for disabled people. The surface of the railway station car park is gravel based (and not tarmac). There is no visible signs of any security cameras here.

There are no bike racks at this station, and there is no ticket machine on either platform, and the railway station is unmanned.

Both platforms do have a covered area where passengers can sit and wait for their train ride.

This railway station also has a foot bridge allowing passengers to cross from one side of the station to the other.

At one end of the railway station, the old signal box can be seen (which is still in use today). A clear view of the old signal box can be seen from the railway station car park.

This is probably one of the most unfriendly wheelchair user train stations I have come across thus far. There is no facility whatsoever to assist the wheelchair user. There is no lift system in place to assist the disabled person to come into the station and furthermore cross over from platform 2 to platform 1. This station is highly not recommended for the disabled or wheelchair user, there will be no-one here to help you. This station, from what I can see is not manned, and whilst I was there waiting for the Reading train to arrive, a member of staff ( I shall presume) unlocked the door to an office area on platform two and locked themselves in there. There are CCV cameras fitted in the station platforms, with a very old bridge crossing over to platform one. There are no adequate shelter rooms for bad weather available and this station does not have the appearance "its safe" especially at night. That said, this station does not have any WI-Fi service and it is located next door to Aldi.

Rochester is a relocated and newly built station in the Medway area. With a modern and spacious building, the station is very welcoming. Disabled access to the platforms above is provided by means of lifts, and stairs give direct access to the 3 platforms, 2 of which are in use. Platform 1 is generally for Thameslink to London, Gillingham and Rainham, and the fashionable SouthEastern High Speed services to St Pancras International. Platform 2 is mostly used for the Kent Coast, including Dover Priory via Canterbury East, Ramsgate via Margate and services to Whitstable via Faversham. High Speed Loop services also provide fast access to Ashford, via many Kent Coast stations.
Make sure to check before you travel online, or on the SouthEastern app available on Google Play and the App Store. Enjoy your day!

Lovely village but BEWARE the speed trap. I joined the A59 Liverppol road from Church road turnig right for Much hoole. There are no speed indication signs so proceeded at 40mph. It is a wide A class road with very few houses so not exactly built up. Proceeded round a LH curve  keeping a safe distance from the car in front. 200yards up the straight sat a mobile camera van. I got a ticket for doing 40 in a 30 zone. I reiterate that from that from Church road there are no speed signs. However there is street lighting and so the 30 applies in the absence of any speed indicators. Rufford is a railway station that sits on the railway line between Preston in the one direction and Ormskirk in the other.

It is situated right beside a level crossing.

Close by to the railway station is a car park that can handle about 10 to 15 cars.

This railway station does have a bike rack on one of the platforms.

Both of the platforms to have sheltered areas where people can sit and wait for their train to arrive.

There is no obvious signs of any digital information board so to a greater or lesser extent it is a bit of a guessing game as to when your train will turn up, unless of course you look at the information on the  notice board, and that will give you a rough idea as to when trains are likely to stop at the platforms.

There are no obvious signs of any closed circuit television either at the station or in and around the station car park.

Where do I begin with Runcorn east. 

1. The transport to the station (buses, walking and cycling) are all horrendous. The buses are never on time, and at times do not turn up at all. Complaints to companies often go unanswered or you may be lucky to receive a pasted response. 
There is practically no safety for any bicycles left as the station is located in a rough area and is hardly manned (about 6 hours a day by 1 bloke who is playing on his phone all day.)
Walking is a last resort as the station is located far from civilisation but is often the only option when no buses turn up.

2. The car park has FINALLY been revamped, although there is quite a bit of wasted space and minimising the neglected "wood" on either side of the car park would have been a good option. Remember though that there is NO CCTV

3. The gent who mans the station is only there for peak times and is closed most of the day resulting in any queries being unanswered.

4. This station is essentially unnecessary as Runcorn Central is superior in most ways...except that Virgin mans it so your pass is not eligible... unless you pay an extra £50 to have the pleasure of taking a route through Crewe.

5. Get ready to multiple sets of stairs or slopes as the station is located in a mini-canyon. Oh and the "shelter" is rusted and rotting away. It is unbelievably cold and a waste of space. 

TLDR: It is a pit that is better left to rot. If you have the chance of using an alternative station, I would advise Frodsham or Widnes (not great but at least you don't have to climb multiple sets of stairs)

Rye House is a station on the outskirts of Hoddesdon.  Trains from Stratford and London Liverpool Street stop here on the way to Hertford East.  The station sits between residential and industrial units and is poorly served by major roads.  There is no on-site parking or drop off facilities.   Beside the Southbound platform there is a part time ticket office and machine,  step free access is available to this platform but not Northbound (towards Hertford East).  There are no lifts or escalators.  There are primitive customer facilities available on site.  There are no shops or cafe and limited shelter from the elements.    Despite regular use by commuters there has been pitiful investment in the station limited to resurfacing of the platforms and removal of a derelict shelter.

Sadly the imposing station building is no longer used for the purpose for which it was built, though at least it remains largely intact.  The width of the two platforms still extant hint at the popularity of the town as a recreational destination in days of yore and as it is now the station is still a pleasant enough place to wait for a train on a warm summer day. Services are fairly frequent, though from the quality of the ride the passenger might be forgiven for thinking the trains should really be in a museum. However, many places of equal if not bigger size lost their link to the rail network many years ago so it is best to be thankful for small mercies and appreciate the colourful, if modest floral display when blooms are in abundance.

If you like Victorian, this place is for you (and me). The town is well presented and pretty with a good selection of shops, as well as the famous cliff tram lift down to the pier and seafront, where excellent fish and chips can be enjoyed. The valley gardens and woods provide lovely walks for all, dogs especially, with a tea room which is dog friendly. Saltburn also has the farmers market every 2nd Saturday in the month providing good local produce, it's well worth a visit.

Nice old Victorian train station set in a lovely seaside town.

Although originally a small settlement and the haunt of smugglers, the Stockton & Darlington Railway Company reached Saltburn in 1861. Subsequently Saltburn was formally planned as a new town in the late 19th Century by the Saltburn Improvement Company.

A fleeting reminder of the now long gone magnificence of the railways, at least the station buildings remain here, and not demolished for two tarmac strips of dross. I would seriously advice against using this station to travel to Saundersfoot town. This station is absolutely not suitable to travel to/from Saundersfoot town with children or any luggage; the walk to Saundersfoot is about a mile down a steep hill, with no pavement or lighting. Needless to say, nobody should ever attempt to reach this station by walking after dark. No taxis wait at the station, so pre-order one if you think this might be necessary. This is a request stop so make sure you signal clearly to the driver that you want to board the train, otherwise you'll have a 2 hour wait for the next train, and trust me you don't want that! On the whole, there is nothing wrong with the station, you just need to be prepared for what you will find. 
 If you do get stuck you could try and have a look at the old abandoned tramway tunnel, which runs underneath the station.

If there was a supermarket of stations then this would, if not part of the basic no-frills range, be a heavily discounted item. Pedestrian access to both platforms is via ramps from the road that runs underneath the railway at the north end of the station, which are a fairly long haul for wheelchair users and those on shank's pony alike. There's no ticket office and only one ticket machine on the southbound platform adjacent to the car park, which is a bit of a pain if you're going in the opposite direction. Despite the trees on either side of the station, the ambiance can be fairly desolate even on a warm summer day and it's certainly not somewhere you want to linger in the depths of winter.

Hey I just wanted to thank the manager Bentley and he's staff at Shoreditch overhead, yesterday 20th Sept 2018. I picked up my granddaughter who lives at Shoreditch and was heading to my house on the isle of dogs. I had lots of bags as my granddaughter was staying over night. On the over head I managed to leave my hand bag on the train!! I got all the way to canary wharf station until I realised I didn't have it. As you can imagine the shock and complete horror. It literally had my life in this bag. My wallet with £150.00 cash. My bank cards. My keys to my house, my medication that I am on for breast cancer. My electric key and gas card. My phone!! I ran to the guard at canary wharf. He was really good to, he allowed back on the train to Shoreditch with my 2 year old granddaughter, who at this time was getting upset. I got to Shoreditch and Bentley was by the ticket gates. I ran to him hoping my bag was there. It wasnt. However Bentley just took over the situation, he was calm, sympathetic and so so reassuring. I couldn't think straight and the panick with making my head draw blanks. I could hardly string a sentence together. Bently suggested I take my granddaughter back to my daughter. Come back to him where he would sit with me and make all the relevant calls I needed to make....cancelling cards, getting into with key smith etc. I ask bently if he could keep calling my mobile phone, in hope someone would answer it. He tried whilst I was there but no luck!! I left the station to quickly take my granddaughter back home. As I was walking along in pure shock I heard someone Calling my name...it was bently running down the street after me...We have found your bag, we've got it!!!! He was like a super hero in that moment and I couldn't help but fling my arms round him and give him a big hug. Some amazing human being on the train had handed my bag into lost and found at New cross station. What are the chances of that?? Also not one thing had been touched my phone cash keys etc where all still there. Not only did this amazing person hand it in untouched they also left no name...a humble kind beautiful human being did that for me. Also I was blessed with Bentley,  he went above and beyond to help me. He was so willing to do what ever it took to get the situation sorted. He even got one of the station guards to accompany me to new cross to collect my bag. Another beautiful human that went above and beyond. I really hope someone high up sees this comment, I hope they gives special thanks to bently and he's staff at the station on 20/09/2018. 
I haven't been feeling very blessed of late, I've been very low at my personal situation and the world. However yesterday restored so much faith hope and love in my heart. It was truly a special day. My granddaughter and I then poddled off to the farm as I had promised her...Thank you Bently and your amazing staff. I'll never forget yesterday. Your my hero.

This railway station sits on the line that heads towards Huddersfield in one direction and towards Barnsley in the other direction.

There is only one platform available here because there is only a single railway line passing through here.

There are two entrances / exits, of which one is suitable for disabled people because it has a ramp access to the platform where as the other entrance / exit is made up of a series of steep steps to the platform.

On one side of the track (on the opposite side to where the platform is), there is a small car park that can provide parking for maybe 3 or 4 cars (but it does also provide one or two spaces for disabled drivers to park their cars here). This same small car park is the location of the bike rack that can probably hold up to a maximum of about 8 bicycles.

This station has no on-site staff and from what I could see there was no departure board here that I could see and perhaps the only way you're going to know whether your train is going to arrive on time is via a tannoy System. 

The railway station platform has two areas where people can sit down and wait for the train (of which one area is sheltered - if the weather means you need to keep out of the rain). This very same covered waiting area also houses an automatic electronic ticket machine which has a touchscreen on it. Consequently, passengers must buy their ticket using this machine, otherwise passengers would be required to buy a ticket once they have boarded the train. 

In terms of security, there is some reference to CCTV cameras being in and around the platform, although I couldn't see them at all, and there were no obvious signs of any security cameras anywhere near the car park.

It should also be noted that trains only pass through (and stop at this platform) at the most with a frequency of about one train per hour.

It is a bit of an unusual railway station because it has two platforms that are not directly opposite one another. This means, if you wanted to go from one platform to the other platform, you would have to walk out of one side of the railway station by (1) walking down a slope , (2) walk under a bridge and (3) then walk back up the other slope on the other side before eventually reaching the other platform.

There is only one area where people can park their cars (which is on the Manchester bound platform side). The car park can hold about 20 cars which includes three or four disabled parking spots. The car parking for passengers seems to be free.

There is an area where passengers can leave their bicycles in the covered bicycle rack which can probably hold about 5 or 6 bicycles. 

There is no obvious signs of security cameras here. 

Platform 2 (the Manchester bound platform), does have a covered seating area where people can wait to catch their train, although there is no ability to buy a ticket from this platform.  

There are no staff on site, although there is a digital information sign to indicate when the next trains are due to pass through the station.

Also, there is a bus station located in the car park near to platform 2.

Platform one which is for trains heading towards Huddersfield is different from platform 2 in one respect in that it has a ticket machine on the platform which is housed inside the passenger shelter area.

Trains that visit Slaithwaite either (1) stop here, in which case they are northern Trains, or (2) are they are fast trains (that don't stop here), operated by TransPennine Express.
Stop on Ale Trail!

Set against a backdrop of industrial decay, in bad weather this really is a barren, windswept and decidedly grim place, indeed one could almost be forgiven for thinking it had been plucked from the pages of a futuristic dystopian novel – well at least if the trains weren't so old perhaps. Although there are shelters on both platforms, passengers travelling east may find the protection offered by the wafer thin, open fronted structure leaves a lot to be desired in driving rain or snow. Even in fine weather it's not somewhere you want to linger for any great length of time and gets two rather than one star only because someone has gone to the trouble creating a small floral display. Sadly, one feels this effort is rather wasted as it really needs something akin to the Hanging Gardens of Babylon in order to brighten things up in a meaningful way.

A jewel in the crown of ferroequinology in the historic city of Edinburgh. A masterpiece of brutalist era British Rail architecture, South Gyle offers the weary traveller a plethora of comforts; a cornucopia of well-tended flowerbeds adds a pleasing aesthetic to the functional concrete platform areas. 
A car park is provided for the multi-modal traveller and help points are available to alleviate all but the largest passenger concerns. Customer information screens are offered and these are readily updated with train times, calling patterns and information during disruption.
Towards Fife the view is one of verdant flora and fauna; towards Edinburgh, a stark reminder of the variance in social classes offered by the conurbation. 
The station is near the prestigious Gyle Shopping Centre, and the buzzing suburb of Corstophine is but a short stroll away.
No rail-based holiday to Scotland is complete without a fleeting visit to South Gyle.
Good facilities for a small station. Reasonable size car park. Could do with better signage to find your way there.

I was travelling yesterday 23/12/17. Cross country called a strike and I was travelling to Cleethorpes. There was no way I could travel on any other day as I was only flying in that morning. Unsure of what I should do I asked at the ticket desk and the young man asked for my ticket, put the information in the computer and gave me a print out of all the changes I had to make to get to my final destination.  Instead of the one change I now had five. The ticket told me the time I was arriving in each station and the time I was due to leave which was very helpful as I then knew how long I had to get to the next platform.  the changes were between 4 and 15 minutes.  I arrived at my destination unfrazzled after a very straight forward trip. But I wouldn't have if it had not been for the boys in Southampton Parkway so I just want to say a very big thank you and a very happy Christmas to them.  X
