No wheelchair access, however, and the shelter on the southbound platform is rather on the small side to say the least. Car park on opposite side of road with limited capacity. Friendly and helpful staff.
I required public transportation and I received it. If you need to go to Chester, Ellesmere Port or even Liverpool you can do it all here. This hat trick of final destinations is at your disposal.
A great little station about half way along the Liverpool to Chester line.  Facilities are limited, but greatly positioned for those in the area wanting to get to Chester.
Ok station. No cafe nearby so cannot get a snack for journey. Nice waiting area however
its the best station ever you get stopping meridians and hst's
Service is not frequent, mainly popular during the morning peak, evening peaks with the odd service during the day.
Because the train don’t stop
An attractive railway station with a signal box and level crossing.
Staff are always helpful. When the weather turns icy the staff always make sure that the stairs and platforms are well gritted and free from dangerous ice patches.
The scots bronx
A bit run-down
It's just a platform, so nothing to say really.

Rundown station, no departure board but announcements are made and there is sheltered seating. 

Very scenic and you can watch the planes take off from the nearby Blackpool International Airport while waiting for your train. 

Frequent bus connections at the top of the station although there is no disabled access to the platform. 

Hopefully Northern or the local community will spruce up the station and bring life back to it.
You can keep it
A divine prayer place. Calm, huge and wonderful.
When the trains run its great. But beware if there is ice or heat or any other weather issues.
A basic railway station, the Northern terminus of the scenic Abbey Line.

The step up from the platform to the train has got to be the worst I've ever seen on the UK railway network. It's about as unfair to those with impaired mobility as you can get. Bad enough of how baron and poor the construction of the station is and the pitiful frequency of the service provided. At least you get shelter, a ticket machine and a car park. Yay I guess?
The City of St Albans is probably one of the most boring cities I've ever visited in the UK but this station is one of the relaxing and most peaceful stations I've seen
Haven't been here in years. Ticket machine would not take my card so had to queue. Card worked absolutely fine! Smith's gone, station a muddle, toilets closed on 2/3. Best avoided if you can!
Machine sells you tickets which you're not permitted to use. Staff then say you have to cross to the main ticket office, via the road rather than through the station, in order to get a refund

By far one of the worst laid out train stations in the UK.

- Too many different bus stops
- Walkways over the tracks are far too small for the capacity the station takes
- Small number of drop-off space for cars
- High parking charges, if you are lucky to get a space
- Expect to damage your car in the Victoria Rod multi-storey carpark as the ramps have poorly designed walls at their entrances
- Regular ticket machine issues in station
- Forget about buying tickets at the desks on a Monday morning
- High bicycle theft (Highest in country 2017).
- No walkway entrances on other main roads around the station (eg Hatfield Road)
- Most reserved parking bays ate taken/ rented to local businesses with over a year waiting list.

Only good thing is that there is usually a good supply of taxi’s outside, but during rush hour you could be spending more time getting out of the diabolical station feeder roads because of it’s terrible design.

If I could give the station a negative score I would.

The lady at ticket counter this afternoon was rude and helpless. She didn't help me at all and she didn't even give an answer about a simple question, she couldn't be bothered at all. The 2 males staff at the gate lovely they helped me and very really nice. Thank you guys
Not fit for purpose.

A small, 1 platform station on the Severn Beach line, St Andrews Road is in an industrial part of Bristol. The station looks quite nice, albeit doesn't get too many services. It is also the Least Used Station in Bristol with 6522 passenger entries and exits in the 2016/17 period, around 17.9 per day. Has to be one of my favourite stations that I have been to
Handy train station

Well kept station with ticket office and ticket machine. The station is looked after by a local community group and is a pleasant place to wait for a train on the south Fylde line. Its a nice gateway to St Anne's high street and promenade.
Nice place to visit

Quiet little station right in the heart of St Annes. Ticket office which is rarely open, although sheltered seating, bike racks and ticket machines are available.  There are no toilets at the station.

Neatly presented and the old platform is still intact leaving a little mark of history.

Attractive well used station with planters and small garden maintained by local volunteers.  Short walk to the town centre and slightly longer one to the beach.  If you're not able to walk there is a taxi rank on the road side.  Numerous eateries to suit all tastes.  It's my hometown and I love it. Come and visit.

I see a lot of people on here whining about a tram interchange for the town centre of st. Anne's,  The problem of those people is that they are utterly and detestably lazy, the train station of st. Anne's is literally IN THE TOWN CENTRE, so they can walk! I used this rail way intensively when I used to do a lot of traveling, and the position of this Railway has not changed since it was first placed there.
Use this station daily, staff are usually friendly and the place is clean and tidy.
Good staff all organised well

Cleaners so insanely rude, got to the train station in the morning to be told the waiting rooms open at 6 by him, very rudely. Fine, okay, everyone has their bad mornings so we ignored it. At 6;20, after he's mopped a floor on the other platform, ask him why they're not open and he goes ' will be there in a minute'. Left for half an hour in the cold morning waiting for a train, not even an apology, so rude. The waiting rooms never did open.
Recent additions make this a well equipped rail station. The original walkways need restoration though.
It's clean, friendly staff and a coffee kiosk.

Lovely little low key station. St. Bees is an extraordinarily charming area. Has a very peaceful and calming vibe. The walk from the Station to the beach is glorious. The station is basic but excellent for the remote area. The scenery is great. The location is good. The fair prices are ok. Recommend visiting this area.
Peaceful clean and friendly. Beautiful cove and surrounding hills.
Lovely little coastal village
Too many bees

Would be a decent station if it had 3 things
1:- A Ticket or Permit to Travel Machine
2:- Actual Train Services
3:- A Decent that doesn't stink
Small old station the way old branch lines stations were.

Complete banger of a station! After coming over from Ferry Road across the street, where I was very disappointed, Victoria Road blew me away! It was like being on a seventh heaven; everything, everything was in it's right place! Good lord above: it was a fiver to a gambler, a golden ticket to joy and happiness.

Useful travel alternative to the local bus service.

Single platform, single track station on the Par to Newquay branch line.

The station can be reached in two ways from St Columb village.

By foot from the village centre, it is sign posted along an alley, which then runs parallel to the tracks and crosses the tracks on a wooden walkway to the platform.

From the other side of the village a road leads to the car park and a gate on to the platform.

The free car park has 14 spaces including one for the disabled. There's a pick up/drop off point and two bicycle racks.

On the platform is a covered seating area, but no glass in the windows. There's a help point and an information board.

Tickets are bought from the guard on the train.

The train service runs in both directions, to either Newquay or Par. It is reliable (mine was 4mins late), but infrequent.

It's important to note, if returning to St Columb Road by train you must speak to the guard to get the train to stop.

The staff are friendly enough here when the ticket office is open however the station as a whole leaves alot to be desired. Step free access is only available on platforms 1 and 4, toilets weren't open neither was the waiting room and the stopping pattern of trains is quite low.

Very helpful staff! Always ready to help you even if your train is about to approach the station they will leap into the office to quickly print out your ticket so you can make it to your train! How sad that they are not there often! I found them very useful when I just started traveling by trains as I never did before! They were very supportive and friendly!
Very helpful staff and platforms gritted in the cold weather
Waiting room never opens, staff are friendly.
Never any staff around and waiting room doors always locked. It's a horrible station

Good facilities, incuding a cafe with tea / coffee / snacks. Beautifully branded cups. No ticket barriers.
I also was lucky to spot train to Edinburgh here!
Very well maintained train station and park & ride location. Provides easy access to St. Ives and other locations. Helpful staff are deployed around the station and it is kept in good condition.
Nice large park and ride, car park machines not working, and unhelpful staff on the station/platform

Long queues for the car park machine (ACOPA app location 2161) meant although we arrived with 20 minutes to spare - we still missed the train and had to wait another 30 mins. Car park signs state availability- but we figured that was probably just the disabled spaces.
Hi how do I get a phone number to ring as we have left our little boys Hoody on the train on Thursday 15th August??? Thanks
Staff kind and helpful especially the ticket agent who with his help I took the right train.

A pleasant town centre railway station. The staff in the booking hall are knowledgeable about the local transport system and are friendly. There concourse serves as a waiting room for one platform which has toilets, on the other platform there is another heated waiting room with live arrival/departure times displayed on a screen.

Fairly clean for a train station, staff are always friendly and great connections. 

Only issue is the lift was not working when I visited, I only had luggage so not bad for me, but would have been a problem for an accessible user.
Love the staff at Shaw street the can't ask for better people x

Town centre station recently refurbished to a bad standard. Not well looked after. Toilets inside supposed to be for rail users only but they are free and no other public toilets about. Undercover seating is available on both platforms and vending machines on platform one.

Comments: On the 30/07/2019 I sent a complaint and asked for a reply by post, as of yet I have not received any reply or acknowledgement of my complaint. Below is a copy of my original complaint. 
On 11th of July I purchased online two adult advanced travel tickets to travel from Doncaster to St Helen's with one change both ways at Manchester Piccadilly. The dates of travel were the 26th of July outbound and return 28th of July. When booking tickets with both Trans Pennine and Northern Rail had various options such as direction of seats and aisle or table seats, no option at all for any disabled so rang to enquire about a small (about same length width as a wheel chair) disabled scooter we were informed this could be used
On Sunday the 28th of July we arrived to catch the 15.56 train to Manchester Piccadilly and preceded to the ticket office to ask for assistance with the ramp. I informed the guard which train We were catching and was abruptly informed the train was late due to a medical emergency, he then said what is the ramp for looking at my partner and asking does that fold up. This would not be asked if she had been using a wheeIchair. Pushing a wheelchair and cases is not an easy option. It was explained how we had arrived two days previously and the conversations with Northern rail on the phone regarding the scooter and I asked how do you suggest we get to Manchester when denied access as this was not our fault. The guard then made a phone call and whilst on the phone talking loudly stated "I don't know why she carn't get off" and " they have broken company policy using a scooter". The guard explained that wheelchairs could be used as they can be fixed but on the outbound journey I do not recall seeing any fixings for wheelchairs where we were placed. My partner who has MS, Chronic Anxiety and suffers from Panic Attacks became distressed and started to cry from his lack of respect and understanding. The guard offered us a taxi to get us to Manchester courtesy of Northern Rail. We had to wait 40 minutes for the taxi to arrive, due to my partner being distressed we also stood the whole time in the rain without coats. I asked about our connecting train in Manchester as time was passing The guard said the fare was covered so if we missed it they would take us the whole way to Doncaster. Unfortunately we could not make the connection in time and had to travel in the taxi. My partner drives but has a fear of motorways so that was why the option of train was chosen, we then had to endure the journey in severely bad weather for almost two hours. 
Due to my partners illness any stress can have a physical repercussions and although I planned our journey to avoid as much stress as possible I feel this was in vain due to the attitude of the guard and how we were dealt with. 
I am aware that things are being put in place for changes in 2020 regarding electric scooters but all staff need to be aware of your own policies now. The guard at St Helen's also said staff are afraid to say anything due to the discrimination act. I do feel we were discriminated against and my partner spoken down to which is unacceptable. 
I request a reply to this matter and have also contacted to rail ombudsman I feel I have been patient and waited long enough for someone to respond to me
Friendly local pub with good beer and sports on tv. The bar staff are amazing.
No problems with the station or access itself, only with the unfriendly, ignorant know all manning the ticket office. He needs lessons in manners and customer service, or change jobs.
Great station, very friendly and helpful staff.
Rude service.

An amazing seaside town! Lots of shops to buy souvenirs, food and drink - a fantastic beach when the tide is out and you can rent a boat, paddle board or canoe too. Best if you can leave the car at home or do park and ride as there isn't much parking space.
Loved it such a lovely day out. We did park and ride from st erth to st ives train stations which was lovely.
Beautiful place- always come here for my holidays
The best seaside resort in the UK bar none. Fabulous light, Fabulous beaches, Fabulous shops,bars and restaurants. Cornwall at its best.

Lovely place with lots of shops and cafes. Very well kept, clean and tidy and the beaches we're awesome. 
 Very accessible as we went by train for 8 pond as a family of four, bargain.
🏖️👍🌞
It was a terrible place and it was really scaby

A small station halt.  Small shelter but no other facilities.  Steep incline to the platform.  Convient for the football ground which is a two minute walk away. Trains to both Exeter's main stations St David's and Central.
The most basic train station, although it does at least have shelter, and is useful in  saving you 40 minutes walk to St David’s for about £1.
Functional little station with minimal facilities and not that many trains stop here. Handy for the Exmouth line
Most of the trains don't stop here and you cannot buy or collect tickets either.
Saubere aber vor allem sichere Bahnstation mit direkter Verbindung zur Liverpool Station!

Honestly not that good of a station with no live travel update display screens on either platform, no step free access and limited seating and facilities. Train timings can be awkward but the station has a ticket office and is relatively close to Lewisham. Can be good for watching the trains go by but that's about it.
Brilliant automobiles

Good luck with your team today but you have a lot to play on the team today and I am very different with my new games games because it isn't the game I have played on the game but it is weaker and extremely helpful in games like the most powerful games I've played on my phone game on my computer I play computer games and I am very very happy to have it defeated by my phone play on the game and the games I have to do is very helpful.

For those of us that live closer to st Johns than Lewisham and New Cross this station is just great for the commute. It doesn't feel like this station exists near London as it's nice and quiet although the walk bridge to the station offers great views of the city. Even the walk to the station is great as it's set in quite a bit of greenery and small streets. Ever since I started living here I have found my commute to be a little bit more enjoyable just because of this.
It is a very small station. Trains are not quite frequent and no toilet facilities on site.

Step back in time and enjoy a branch line railway journey from St Keyne Wishing Well Halt. The location is idyllic, in a heavily wooded valley far away from the hustle and bustle of everyday life. Trains pass through on their way to Liskeard (20 min) or Looe (16 min) but the passenger has to wave to the driver to stop. A beautiful journey in both directions, but the pick is to travel along the estuary to Looe. Truly magic and very cheap fares.

Very Long name

Not much to explore!
Grateful we get to use this station 2 days in a row for transit. The help machine works fine, and when contacted, were responsive to queries.

Location location location!!!
Good station, no staff in evenings; think they hide.
Location is by Warrior Square (hence the name) not a nicest of areas to visit. Gardens and seafront is lovely, local inhabitants are not.

A well used station on the main line to Hastings. There is seating undercover on the platform and a tea room for your daily coffee. Station officials are on site most of the day even on bank holidays. However they are not on site during the evenings which is a pity at times. I was a little disappointed with the cleaning on my visit, as on the day I was there, there where 10 used vape metal canisters under the waiting area seats that young children where asking questions about. I thought that was disgusting. There is a small communal garden next to platform 2 which is well maintained and looks nice
Nestled between two tunnels, this is an odd station. Can be accessed either side of the tracks.
Good service and nice staff, well maintained station with a nice tiny green garden next to platform no.2.

Plenty of ticket machines at the top of the station but very much lacking in accessibility. There's easy to read information boards and a small coffee shop, but there's a real lack of seating on the platforms, or any coverage from the elements further down the platforms.

The station has no lifts and is only partially staffed throughout the day making it poor in terms of accessibility. Trains towards London off peak leave almost perfectly clock faced making it very easy indeed to remember when trains serve here.

Saint Margarets is located in the St. Margarets section of Twickenham, the station is served by Southwest Trains, Saint Margarets is a fair station and a pretty nice one too, the neighbourhood is quiet and clean and train service is great.
Great place.
Agreed with previous poster.. The staff at the station is useless.. Totally gave me wrong directions.. He had 1 job.. 1 only and can't get it right!!!!!!
Nice and clean. Em's the coffee shop at the station is brilliant. The staff are extremely friendly and they make you feel at home whenever you go there. Very reasonable. A must to visit.
Loving this weather 😆😆😆
Excellent station. Probably built about 50s so come here to see a 50s station. Trains all arrive late as per south eastern time tables.
They should rename this station Royston Vasey. The staff and the passengers all look like characters from The League of Gentlemen (see inbred). That's only the start of its problems.

Nice place near a park, a cricket club to the south, yet another huge park called festival gardens. Right after we have the muddy Merry river somehow a prolonged for the sailor but a feast for the photographer. In about 7 minutes we are easily getting out from Liverpool Central Station

Quaint old station building with stepped ramps down to platforms, so wheelchair access possible but not easy. Bike rack but no car park, though there may be the odd space in the road leading to the station entrance. Staffed ticket office as elsewhere on the Merseyrail network. Generally quite quiet though at peak times it can be relatively busy. Set in a wide cutting that's fairly sheltered and very pleasant in summer.

Normally a very quiet ststion although there is only one ticket window and no ticket machine so there can be a queue out or the door just after 8am on a week day so extra time should be given for the commute.
Helpful staff, handy for locals to get into the city centre.

Generally a quiet station on the Northern Line on the section between Hunts Cross and Liverpool Central. The station is staffed so tickets can be obtained during the times that the station is open. A toilet is available opposite the ticket office.
Congratulations on the wonderful raised flower beds at the station. They look really beautiful.  Hope you will plant bulbs in them for Spring in a couple of months
Excellent customer service and facilities. Disability access and communication. Staff are available for any questions and are quite cheerful.
Excellent service! I was late for a prearranged pick up time however Paul waited for me. Very jolly chap and a pleasure to share both journeys with today!
Great service. Friendly driver, was already waiting when I arrived at the station.
Usless service. Trains always late or cancelled. Staff are like zombies bloody useless. Sort it out National rail or sell up.

Great station, restored with consideration and  taste. Plenty of high quality shopping options here, some people come here for the day. Outside in the local area and Coal Drops Yard, there are plenty of great bars, restaurants and shops. An amazing destination.

This is a very impressive train and tube station. It has been very well designed and has a huge amount of shops inside to visit. 
There are also clean toilets which are free. 
There are a number of coffee shops and bakery stores to buy drinks and food. 
It is large and you would think you will get lost but there are plenty of clear signs to direct you. They are all in English though.

A vibrant station with plenty to keep you occupied while waiting for a train. The lower concourse provides an array of high end shops. The station links to the underground network as well as all the other Transport for London links. But don't forget there is always the famous British Black Taxis to get you to any part of London you desire.

A wonderfully rejuvenated railway station. I've many happy memories from childhood, sitting on the platform late at night with my Mum, waiting for the midnight home and watching the mail and newspapers arrive by van. All that's changed, the station too, bars, restaurants, no longer just the BR buffet. I like it.

I have been to many stations and this is one of the very best. It is warm in winter. Its architecture is magnificent. It has an enormous range of shops and eating places. Of course, they are mostly quite expensive but the same is also true of all the less nice stations. Oh, and they also have trains that go to many places including Brussels, Brighton and Bedford.
Not a bad train station all in. Clean, there's a few shops, toilets, seats/benches and not forgetting the trains. What else could you need?

The station itself is great, clean compared to most too but, missing my train because I can't park puts a damper on the situation. Mainly because it was caused by people dropping off and having a lovely chat as they do so. Traffic was backing up all the way to the lights several hundred yards towards tesco because the drop off area is completely inadequate.
Better range of shops these days but still freezing platforms.!
I think this train station is good because you can catch a train from here

Already paid for a ticket and this pig wouldn't let me threw I needed to go out to get my bike so I could go home and he has being rude ignoring me I'm being an overall nark I'm not happy and I don't think I'll be travelling with southwesternrailway ever again.

The worst station to ever be stuck at or even go to, delays are daily and paying up to £10 to be stuck here is the worst - if you can jump the barriers or not pay by all means do so the service here is the worst I’ve ever seen ever

Staines is located in the Staines-upon-Thames area, the station is served by Southwest Trains, with kind staff, working facilities, and clean platforms Staines is a great station used by commuters and travellers, Staines-upon-Thames is among one of my favourite towns in Britain because of how quiet it is, there are plenty of shops nearby and lots to do.

I'm a carer for disabled children, whilst trying to get a child in a very heavy, specialised buggy onto the train the doors shut on the buggy with the child and their chair half in half out, about 4 staff members watched and didn't help or offer any assistance, A member of the public came to my aid. Staff there were useless when I needed them.
OK little station, shame about the older female member of staff #NoCustomerSkills
Barriers take the biscuit wait for ages for the barriers to open then train eventually arrives and pulls away waiting another 5 min for barriers to open . not happy :-(
Good choice of beers and ciders. There were quite a few folk enjoying one of their pies. Informative staff
Excellent station there is a great café and bar here as well.
Great station, nastalgia everywhere
It is always a pleasure using this train station because of the staff.Always so helpful,polite and funny too.Facilities are good too and it's always pretty clean.

All usual facilities, try arrive early and go to the famous buffet bar for a few quality real ales and lagers and the waiting for the inevitable " sorry to announce message won't be such a bad thing for once!!
this is a beautiful city. I arrived on an eventful day, where the whole town seemed happy to join in!
Amazing train station. Same as the city of Stamford. Old and historical buildings makes sense of the great Britain ages

Charming station, totally in keeping with the town which is a reminder of an England largely gone. I guess Stamford escaped many of the ravages of industry and its decline, the scars of which so mar the north and midlands. The luftwaffe and town planners have done their worst elsewhere but luckily this place survived intact. Unfortunately the car is the scourge of the town now, and if the centre could be free of traffic it would make this a better place to visit.
A beutiful village and very relaxing

Sweet little station... like going back in time... The chap behind the counter was incredibly sarcastic, condescending and unhelpful when my mother’s Senior Railcard would not display on her phone. He went on to say that management should never have allowed railcards on an app!!!

Quite a pleasant spot with some change in scenery from one end of the platforms (town) to the other (country, or near enough). Staff equally amiable. Level crossing at one end of the station and small car park across the road. Ticket office currently undergoing renovation. Easy wheelchair access.
Me and the lads head here when we gonna run down ops that aint local
Are u abaibol?
Reliable and aptly located. Live departures avaible and there are attendants ready to help. Toilet facilities available and warm enclosed space for harsh weather. Wheelchair friendly.

I fly at least once a month within Europe, but hadn't been to Stansted for years.  Great experience.  Easy trip out from London on the Stansted Express, very quick and efficient security check, to arrive in a welcoming and modern airport with all the facilities you need while you wait for your flight. Made flying simple.  On our way in to London we were off the plane, out of the airport and on the train in less than 25 minutes.

Three times in a row now immigration did now like my electronic passport, although it is accepted by the machines in at all three other airports I have transited in the same period.
Then you need about more than an hour from arriving at the airport to the gates. In the past heathrow was always my most hated airport, but Stanstedt is topping this easily now.

Firstly airports around the world have one thing in mind to get you in and out as quick as possible. 
For you to be able to shop and buy thing within a airport is a privilege. Stansted was never set out to be a massive hub for world travel it was a vital military airport during the war  but despite arguments from locals and activists it has become one of London's most popular airports. 
Its set to double in size and like it or lump it all the people who moan about everything will yet again travel from hear time and time again so eat your humble pie because as long as you want cheap flights you'll have to take them how they come..
Only slightly depressing. Leon, Burger King, Prêt etc. Could do with a kids play area.
Adequate station. Well signed, mostly clean. Ticket office is not always open but there are ticket machines on both platforms. A small amount of parking is available.
No barriers
Really good
It is not a very nice station, very basic with few benches ticket office is closed a lot and so is the fish shop and has barely any shelter, not the best station
The most isolate, in the middle of nowhere station. There is literally nothing. They could bother adding a coffee shop - it would make the experience of being there less depressing.
It's a dump

Clean and friendly station on the main line to London Bridge Northbound and Dover Priory Southbound. There is a small kiosk inside selling drinks, snacks and papers etc. There are toilets. Like most London commuter trains parking is incredibly expensive!
There's a taxi rank here and not much else, the wheelchair facilities are good, with a lift on the bridge over to the platforms.

Train station with 2 platforms and trains that go through are operated by Great Western Railway

It has the train service to/ from Bristol Temple Meads to Avonmouth/Severn Beach (cheap train tickets)  and  to/from Bristol Temple Meads (BTM)  to Bristol Parkway (BP)

If going to BTM or BP then there are the options for changing to services further afield 

With the relaying of 2 extra tracks and the introduction of new trains (teething problems allowed for) the problems of delays are easing BUT this does not mean that they are either  still liable to delays or cancellations or any other problems such as staffing and problems beyond their control!!

Great station that can be used for changing which I have done but the new bridge especially for disabled or bikes is extremely long - an could be the 2nd longest in the UK!!

Information boards are up and real time information as long as it is working

No ticket machine so buy your ticket on the train

I love the murals that are on the platform was you come out of BTM
If I could close my eyes whilst driving through there, I would. The graffiti artists think they own something by simply 'tagging' it, and they're welcome to it…all of it
Train arrived on time, pleasant journey to Bristol Temple Meads then on to Bath
Very convenient train service, just wish there were less delays...
Nice views but the shelters are a bit small and rainy

I use Starbeck station almost every day, (twice normally), and it's pleasant enough for a tiny station. Both platforms have fully enclosed shelters, (one with a ticket machine), live "train time info" displays, several flower planters, a bike shelter (plat 1), subway between platforms, and the planters are reasonably looked after. No facilities but lots of good shops, public toilets, and a regular bus stop very close by. Trains only stop for a few seconds so be quick, and organised!
It's a branch line and the rolling stock is generally rubbish - not even worth scrap value - that's what lets it down. Hence, one star removed. But the station is fine for the service it's expected to provide.  Pete (Ibex022).

New Class 170 "TurboStars", (only 4 trainsets so far), have improved the traveller comfort level significantly.  Roll on the next twelve, (if we ever get them!).  Pete B 02/06.  (Updated 06-11-18)

Now, a new shelter and some welcome upgrades, like a ticket machine on both platforms.  If every service was a 170 TurboStar I'd give it 5 stars, (for a tiny branch line station).  Also, now a Costa Coffee cafe, right opposite, if you like your coffee etc!  Improvements - that I like.  Pete B (06-11-18)

Many minor upgrades, but most noticeably, the "new", (new to us - ex-ScotRail), rolling stock.  What appears to be a 170TurboStar, (3-car set), on almost every service.  16 sets in total now, I hear?  These are light-years ahead of the ancient early 1980's shocking "sheds" they replace.  There is a rumour saying that these trainsets often run 2-3 minutes late.  It is also rumoured that this is due to the gearing they have, (they are rated for 100mph).  However, the whole line (YRK-HGT-LDS) is limited to 65mph, and with many localised speed restrictions down to 20 or 30mph!?  So, they never get out of second gear.  Designed for speed? - Yes!  Acceleration - No!
Who cares?!  Just take one of those very comfy seats, and relax in the silky smooth quietness of a Class 170TS, (1st class if you are lucky!).
Big seats - big doors - mains power / USB / tables - this we like!
And well overdue!    Pete B (Ibex022)    23/06/2019
Nothing special near this station except a large park
Amazing and peaceful little place close to Windermere. Loved my one day visit there, reminded me of the English countryside I'd read about in the books.
Great little village with lots going on and some great unique businesses and hub of creativity.
Beautiful place.
Handy little station - especially useful for visiting Hawkshead Brewery.
Very good little station

I'm a big fan of rail travel, though the prices these days are absurd. But this is a review of the Stirling Train Station, not the train network. Anyway, there's a decent cafe here, the ticket office seemed - to me at least - like a friendly place if you need to buy a ticket, and the ticket machines themselves work well - I never saw one that didn't work.

But most importantly for people like me, this is a station that still carries some of the romance of the old train network. It's kept clean and looks well-supervised by the station staff, but above all else it retains the charm and attractiveness of the stations of my youth and of my nostalgic dreams.

Stocksmoor railway station, sits on the railway line that heads towards Huddersfield in one direction, and towards Barnsley in the opposite direction.

There is a small car park (on the Barnsley bound platform side), that can accommodate about 5 or 6 cars, and also there is a single space for a disabled car to park here. If there is insufficient car parking spaces, people (and their cars) can always be parked right outside the railway station on the road that goes over the bridge nearby.

It should also be noted that there is a drop-off area, right near the platform for trains heading towards Barnsley.

It is quite clear to see, that there is is a good level of security here, because there are are closed circuit television cameras here.

Although there are no official bike racks, they do have some bicycle boxes nearby, which I presume have padlocks on them.

This railway station has the facility to buy tickets here, courtesy of an electronic automated ticketing machine.

This railway station does have digital information boards to indicate when the next trains are likely to arrive here.

Wheelchair access is available on both platforms, although it must be said that any wheelchair passenger wanting to get on the platform for Huddersfield bound trains, will find it really quite difficult, because the slope from the main road down to the platform itself, is really quite steep (perhaps with a gradient of somewhere between 10 and 20%).

Both platforms do have areas where people can sit down (and wait for their trains), and that also includes covered waiting areas.

What was nice to see, was that in the covered waiting area (on the Huddersfield bound platform), passengers can sit in the shelter and look at the digital information board which resides inside the covered waiting area, which is a nice touch I must admit.
It's a very quaint village it has a train line running through going from Sheffield to Huddersfield and has all the facilities needed for a village.

Sugar Loaf station: Wales' quietest station draws more people
It has a famous-sounding name, but Sugar Loaf in Wales is a world away from its namesake in Brazil that tourists flock to.

The railway hideaway, a few miles north of Llandovery, used to average one visitor every 36 hours - and that made it one of the quietest stations on the UK railway network.

But over the past year, numbers have increased as people have visited to get a ticket from the station, with one couple even getting engaged there.

Don't bother trying to access the top car park of you have a lowered car as the metal speed bump will do a number on your car! No problem with the bottom, larger car park though. Same if you have a high sided vehicles, as the to car park has a 2 metre max clearance barrier.
Always on time

No seating and shelter, the ticket machines only accept card/contactless payments and it's located in the middle of scenic nowhere, bar the Kingsferry Bridge and Bypass bridge up above. 

At least the station has step free access and buses stopping right outside. Yay?
Very small unstaffed halt next to the Kingsferry Bridge on the Sittingbourne to Sheerness line

For customers going into London at peak times the station should be accessible to us, I was unable to get my ticket in the morning I later went back in the afternoon and it was closed. I then arrived 20mins early the next morning before my train departs so I would have enough time to make my purchase,  arrived at 7:00am, once again it was closed. I had to take the risk of travelling into London without the correct ticket. If I accrued a fine it wouldn't be paid by me as it's not fault of my own. This has happened several times and in having to Jump off the train halfway through my journey to try find a station that I could potentially purchase a ticket into London. I am a every day working person and I am being left to go the extra mile because my local station chooses when it wants to be open, it is extremely frustrating. I really hope this will be fixed,  maybe try hiring more than 1 staff member.

What a pitiful station. No step free access, limited seating and shelter, a part time staffed ticket office with only a ticket machine not accepting cash payments and no visual displays telling you when when the next train is. Completely unacceptable for today's standards of a railway station.

This station have no ramp or lift to access with a buggy or for disable people. Quite unexpected situation in 2017!

Absolutely SHOCKING behaviour from member of platform staff today. The poor girl was left in tears and no way to get even to another station with a lift or disabled acces. I called a cab for her and her mother arranged to meet her and get her home. Very small station, manned less and less these days, but at least it's kept clean and tidy. hoever, the waiting areas need some serious work, and the facilities are basicly non existant. Things not to look for: phones, shops, toilets for more than one person at a time, or an ATM. but at least you can get a taxi some times.

A typical small town station with a limited hours ticket office, though there's a ticket machine outside the main entrance. Parking and bike storage is available. It does have a good Indian restaurant attached if you're interested.
Sway is alright but we just the post office

A very small station with a ticket machine serving some local area near Southampton airport. Trains stop here every hour or so and the station lacks any noteworthy features worth mentioning. Local buses stop nearby to the town centre.

Travel to London from here once a week.. 90£ a day.. soo expensive...

Normally quiet station in a convenient location. Only issue is the small number of parking spaces. Although 24 hour parking is only £2
Ticket office not open At 13.15 on Friday and no opening hours displayed.
Nicely kept station with a good service. Safe car park and ideal for getting to Newark and Lincoln.
Could benefit from a couple more stopping services.

Plenty of facilities, though expect prices to be high and products to not be majorly varied. However station is mostly quiet and relaxed and staff are helpful. Peak times may be much faster paced. I prefer this station to Bristol Temple Meads.

The station itself seems to be good with places to get a coffee and snack available on all platforms. Unfortunately they are not available late evening. Again toilets are available on both platforms. All platforms are accessable step free with lifts to both platforms  and also a lift from concorse level to the short term car park. There is a drop off area on Station Road  although some people do seem to use it as a parking area. There is a short term car park offering 20 minutes free parking which is great when you are meeting someone from a train. Plenty of options to buy tickets from machines or from the booking office.

Swindon train station is located close to the bus station and town center. You can easily walk here from both these places. The station has a multi story building. It has all the facility including ticket counter and station master office. You can use ticket vending machine 24 hour. Platforms have shades to save from rain. The station can reached from all parts of Swindon by bus.

Welcome to Swindon! Shame the outside of the station looks terrible with a disused office block with boarded up windows. The station itself is quite nice with sheltered waiting areas, toilets and food outlets.

I haven'y used the station. My comment relates to the lack of signposting. Being a stranger to the area the roads around the town are good, if you know where you are going. BUT, if you don't, and are reliant on the signposts they are practically non existent on the roads  until practically there. Compare this to the outlet centre, which is signed for miles around.

The alterations to the platform areas are poor: the shelters are smaller, drafty & much less comfortable overall. Friendly staff, can even pick up revered tickets here at last (which is great) watchbout for relatively short hours where staff are in ticket office however. Not sure the loos are open when there's no-one in the ticket office.

Opening hours are 07:00 - 13:30 Mon-Sat and closed all day Sunday. Considering a lot of guards don't know how short the opening hours are from here be prepared to be interrogated as to why you didn't buy a ticket from the ticket office.
Clean station friendly staff and train on time .😁
Yeah it’s not bad

Lovely station when the sun is shining, long platforms, plenty of seating. Pleasant little coffee shop too with a good range of snacks, seating area and Monmouth Coffee served at a reasonable price. Almost worth being early for your train or missing it and waiting for the next one.
Great station three train Services stop here

The station has the bare essentials for what you expect for a small commuter train station. None of the platforms here have step free access as it's only accessible via a footbridge or a stepped footpath. 

There's a ticket office and ticket machines provide on platform 1 as well as a small café open some of the time. Seating and shelter is minimal but adequate, better on platform 1 as that has a waiting room.
At Syston Station Have good platform 1 and 2 systems East Midlands Trains For Leicester to Lincoln Central
This is a good spot for spotting trains although the station itself could do with more trains stopping at it which may mean another platform would be needed. :)
VERY GOOD NOTHING MORE TO SAY!

A basic railway station on the Midland Main Line. HSTs pass through daily and steam trains pass through from time to time.

A minimal halt of a station with minimal facilities located in a village north of Oxford. Has a dreadful service pattern of one train every two hours in each direction and is somewhat accessible. Only good thing is that it's close to the Oxford Canal Walk.

The station desperately needs more attention given from the railway services.

Taffs Well is steeped in history. The old Walnut Tree Viaduct and cutting are still evident in the woods.
Not bad
Nice  quiet train station
I have no idea, just wanted to post some photos!  It's a request stop, but it looks efficient.

Seems to be an alright parkway station with four trains an hour to Birmingham and Walsall. Ramped footways provide step free access, buses stop nearby, lots of parking spaces provided and ticketing facilities too. Downside is the platforms lack alot of seating and shelter.

Barely any facilities, no step free access, trains prone to delay and cancellations and a footbridge so steep it's awkward to use. The new platform isn't helpful if it's just closed off with no seating and shelter too. Hard to take this station seriously at all.

Frequent trains and clean, fairly decent facilities. Ticket office and heated waiting room located in station building on westbound platform, where there's also a small shop serving snacks and hot drinks (though nothing decaf). Bike rack, small car park and pick up/drop off area between platforms. Generally fairly busy, with trains to/from Manchester Airport being especially popular.

The best station if you want the south end of Stockton which lies a ten minute walk across the River Tees. Reasonable facility, but what you see today is a car park occupying what used to be the station building. Looking east toward Middlesbrough lies scrub land where up till the 1980s stood a motive power depot and an enormous shunting yard.
Station is a bit small but bring huge convenience to people with various equipments and lovely staff

I went to pick up my train tickets this afternoon and the guy who served me was so helpful and lovely. It really makes a difference when people go out of their way to make your day. 

The name on the receipt was Andy.

It's a nice station with a traditional footbridge, probably listed, and a ticket and information office. There is a crossing for disabled people. Upgrading for bridge two, Selby Road, and by implication access to / from the Hull platform seems to be a nightmare for inserting the ramp.
Thanks you so much for helping me out
Fairy good station for the most part
Excellent service. Prompt and efficient. pleasant drivers.
The station has an office. Tickets, passes and information are available from it.

I am a city based citizen and this train station blew me away. I saw things here I have never seen before - a real strange place. That being said, I have never heard of this place or even knew of its existence until a business appointment brought me to this place in the middle of nowhere. This is a one platform train station heading in the direction of either Yeovil or Weymouth. Whichever the direction of your travel, when the train is slowly approaching the station, you need to flag it down - the same way as sticking your hand out to stop a bus at a bus stop, failure to do this could result in the train not stopping unless a passenger on the train wants to get off at that station. I found the station to be quiet primitative in comparison to some of the London stations. Within the shelter area is located an old and possibly out of fashion/out of date but in working order British Telecom pay phone which only accepts credit cards to make calls. Personally, looking at the machine I wouldn't trust it to put my card into that. I had an hour to kill waiting for the Weymouth train to arrive and since I was the only person at the station, I was a bit more curious at this lonesome station. I also noticed within the shelter housing, was placed a train ramp for disabled wheel chair users which is used to assist wheel chair user to get off the train. My biggest puzzle and to the time of writting this review, how is this station a disabled/wheelchair bound user friendly? There is a massive high flying staircase which takes you up to the road or down to the station. I saw no lift service here, this station is not manned, no CCTV, so how does a disabled wheelchair bound person navigate from this station or to this station.
? That ramp although fitted to make it look like the station is compliant with requlations I dont see how it does? I really don't see the point of that ramp!!! This station is NOT disabled person wheel chair bound friendly and I would advise all persons as such to avoid this station like the plague. There is no digital display board advising the next train due, but there is some type of system to keep you in touch with staff in the civilised world. This is the type of station I would have concerns about using at night.
An attractive little country railway station on the Heart of Wessex Line. Loco hauled charter trains pass through occasionally.

This is to warn other parents because staff at Thornton heath station obviously do not tell you.

Not enough ticket machines especially as sometimes there isn't a member of staff selling tickets. The old British Rail customer service ethos overlaid with the profit motive of a private company operating in a monopoly.

The highlights:

- "Coffee Station" provides brilliant customer service. A shame it's on the platform rather than outside as a standalone unit.

The cons:

- There have been a few instances now where the self service ticket machines have been out of order and there has been nobody to man the ticket office. I'd have to go back over the bridge to the other side of the station to use the other self service machine (assuming that one didn't break either).

Six years after commuting from here regularly I can happily say that it's just as good as it was on day one.

There's free parking which gets fairly full on weekdays but is nonetheless a good thing to have considering the space they have to work with. The dropping off area by the station has an incredibly obnoxious coffee van that blocks a lot of the space, but I can't really fault the station itself for that. There's still just about room to manoeuvre and get dropped off safely.

The station is clean and tidy, which is an achievement considering that nothing else is Coventry is. They repainted the handrails and overpass recently, which fixed up the looks of the station further.

There is a self-serve ticket machine outside, and while this used to be incredibly temperamental, recently it seems to have been fixed and works consistently. The ticket office is usually manned as well, which is good.

There are covered waiting areas on both platforms, though they're smallish and could use some expansion; this particularly applies to platform 2.

Overall, uhh... yeah, good station.
